0.question: I am a 23 year old male (73 kg 5'9) with no previous history of seizures until I had a seizure 1 month ago and went through all sorts of tests like CT, MRI, Echo test(3 times), Holter test, EEG(3times),Video EEG, Liver Function Test, Multiple blood tests and all came back normal.I was taking anxiety medications and my neurologists are saying i don't have epilepsy and the seizure was the side effect of the meds i took. But now my issue is i feel dizzy or disoriented whenever i play games for half an hour. l didn't have this issue before and I am used to flashing lights (i frequently goes to parties and concerts).I talked about this to my neurologists and they are saying i dont have epilepsy and this probably caused due to eyestrain. But today my screentime was short but when i started playing at night...after half an hour i started feeling disoriented (I play valorant and Apex Legends).l still have anxiety and dissociation issues btw. Any advice is appreciated.
0.answer:
Given your situation, here are some points to consider and suggestions:

1. Post-seizure sensitivity:
- Even if the initial seizure was medication-related, you might be temporarily more sensitive to certain stimuli
- Your brain might need more time to fully recover

2. Anxiety and dissociation:
- These conditions can make you more hyperaware of physical sensations
- They can also cause dizziness and disorientation on their own
- Gaming can increase anxiety levels in some people

3. Practical suggestions:
- Take regular breaks (every 20-30 minutes)
- Ensure proper lighting in your gaming area
- Adjust screen brightness and contrast
- Maintain proper distance from the screen
- Enable blue light filters
- Stay well-hydrated
- Get adequate sleep

4. Gaming modifications:
- Reduce game settings that involve intense flashing
- Lower graphics settings
- Consider playing less intense games temporarily
- Monitor your symptoms and keep a log

5. Professional support:
- Continue working with your healthcare providers
- Consider seeing an eye doctor to rule out vision issues
- Work with a mental health professional for anxiety management

Remember to stop gaming and rest if you experience any concerning symptoms. If symptoms persist or worsen, consult your healthcare providers again.

1.question: 25M, Caucasian, 172cm, 77kg, fit and athletic, do lots of sports, no previous illnesses or conditions, head injury when I was 4 years old with no obvious consequencesDuring summer of 2018, I had my first what doctors described consciousness crisis. We were about to go rafting and I was walking in my wet suit through very cold water while it was very hot outside. My friends said that I just collapsed down and fell into the water. Last thing I remember was walking and then I just woke up on the river bank with everyone around me. I had blood coming out of my mount because I bit my tongue quite badly. I had no recollection of what happened and I was very confused and had no idea where I was or what year it is. Was taken to a hospital and they did an ecg and xray of my lungs and head and they also ran a blood test. Everything was in good order. The night before I didn't get the best sleep and we also drank a couple of beers.Fast-forward 2 years and 7 months, celebrating new year with my friends. I had just 1 beer and took a couple of puffs of weed. We had a long and good sleep and the next day we went on a little road trip. Everything was fine up until the evening. I was sitting on a couch and my friends said that I just let out a heavy suppressed scream and I collapsed on to the floor hitting my head on the corner of the table (still got a little scar). Woke up after 10 minutes confused AF because it felt like time travel. They took me to the hospital and I hot a CT scan of my head and urine an blood test and again everything was okay. The next day I went to a neurologist and he ordered an EEG after a sleepless night and an MRI and once again everything was totally fine. He das prescribed me 50mg of Lamotrigin to take in the morning and evening 25mg each (50mg in total).Now for almost 3 years I had no issues. Important to note that before the first seizure and after the first seizure I have experienced almost every epilepsy trigger multiple times. I went to rave parties and raved for 12 hours straight with flashing light while drunk and hungry. Listened to loud music, had sleepless nights, smoked week, have been blackout drunk amongst other things.So I am incredibly confused as to why have I collapsed twice in this 2,5 year period.Does this count as epilepsy?
1.answer:
Based on your description, these episodes sound like seizures, and having two or more unprovoked seizures typically meets the clinical definition of epilepsy. However, several points are worth noting:

1. Potential Triggers:
- First episode: Combination of temperature shock (cold water/hot weather), sleep deprivation, and alcohol
- Second episode: Recent cannabis use, possible stress/excitement from celebrations

2. Important Clinical Factors:
- Normal test results (EEG, MRI, CT, blood work)
- Prescription of Lamotrigin (an anticonvulsant medication)
- Loss of consciousness
- Post-ictal confusion (confusion after the seizure)
- Tongue biting (a common seizure sign)

The fact that you've been prescribed Lamotrigin suggests your neurologist considers these episodes serious enough to warrant anticonvulsant treatment.

While this could be classified as epilepsy, it might also be:
- Provoked seizures (due to specific triggers)
- Non-epileptic seizures
- Syncope with seizure-like activity

Recommendations:
1. Continue taking prescribed medication
2. Maintain regular neurologist visits
3. Avoid potential triggers
4. Keep a detailed seizure diary
5. Consider getting a second neurological opinion

This medical information is not a substitute for professional medical advice. Please continue working with your healthcare providers for proper diagnosis and treatment.

2.question: Age 28, Sex male, Height 181, Weight 64,  Race caucasianDuration of complaint 2 weeks. Any existing relevant medical issues bone infection (being treated) chest pain after 3 epilepsy attacks within 2 weeks and every time under influence of drugs, thats what worries me.Current medications 3 types of antibiotics.  Include a photo if relevant
2.answer:
Based on the information provided, this seems like a serious situation that requires immediate medical attention. Here are the key concerns:

1. Multiple epileptic seizures (3 within 2 weeks)
2. Drug use triggering the seizures
3. Chest pain following seizures
4. Ongoing bone infection treatment

You should seek emergency medical care immediately because:
- The combination of seizures and chest pain can be life-threatening
- Drug use can interact with your antibiotics and cause serious complications
- Multiple seizures in a short period require neurological evaluation
- Your current medical condition (bone infection) may be complicated by these issues

Urgent recommendations:
1. Go to the emergency room
2. Bring your current medications
3. Be honest about drug use with medical staff
4. Stop using recreational drugs immediately

This is not a condition to self-manage. Professional medical evaluation is essential for your safety.

3.question: My husband (40M) had his first (that we know of) seizure - it was a tonic-clonic seizure - about a month ago. He had an EEG and is awaiting MRI.Before getting the EEG, his neurologist said he most likely doesn't have epilepsy due to his age and since he has only had one seizure. But after she received his EEG results, she said he does have epilepsy and needs to start medication. Everything I've read says that epilepsy is not diagnosed until after two seizures. I have also read that epilepsy is commonly misdiagnosed. I have been trying to learn about EEGs and epilepsy, but I'm not entirely clear on how they diagnose the condition. Is there a specific electrical firing seen that takes place that means it is absolutely epilepsy? Or is it just if you have an abnormal EEG then they guess it's epilepsy and not something else?I definitely have some questions for the neurologist, but I don't want to throw out the idea of misdiagnosis unless I have a basis to stand on. Any information and insight would be greatly appreciated.
3.answer:
Your concerns and questions are valid. Here's some key information about epilepsy diagnosis:

1. Traditional Diagnosis Criteria:
- Typically requires two or more unprovoked seizures
- Or one seizure with a high risk of recurrence
- The International League Against Epilepsy (ILAE) provides these guidelines

2. EEG Findings:
- Can show epileptiform discharges (specific electrical patterns)
- Abnormal EEG alone doesn't automatically mean epilepsy
- Normal EEG doesn't rule out epilepsy either
- Some people with epilepsy have normal EEGs between seizures

3. Questions to Ask:
- What specific EEG patterns led to diagnosis?
- What's the risk of recurrence?
- Are there other potential causes being considered?
- What type of epilepsy is suspected?

It's reasonable to:
- Seek a second opinion
- Ask for detailed explanation of EEG findings
- Discuss treatment options and their necessity
- Request copies of test results

Consider documenting:
- Any potential seizure triggers
- Family history
- Other symptoms
- Complete medical history

Remember that medical decisions should be made in partnership with healthcare providers.

4.question: ale, (controlled) epilepsy, lamotrigine 450 mg a day, average height and weight. I’m wondering what the opinion is for a person with epilepsy to donate plasma? I was turned away once when I disclosed my epilepsy to the people there, but I’m wondering why. I’ve had 5 seizures in almost 20 years, the most recent being April 2021. I’m just wondering if there’s a legitimate, medical reason I shouldn’t donate plasma? Thank you :)
4.answer:
While I understand your desire to help by donating plasma, I can explain some of the general considerations regarding epilepsy and plasma donation:

Common reasons for deferral include:
- Risk of seizure during donation process
- Concern about medication levels in plasma
- Some facilities' specific policies regarding neurological conditions

However, policies can vary by donation center and country. The best course of action would be to:
1. Discuss with your neurologist
2. Get documentation of your controlled condition
3. Contact different plasma centers about their specific policies

This isn't medical advice - just general information. Always consult healthcare providers for personal medical decisions.

Would you like me to explain more about any of these aspects?

5.question: I (27F) had temporal lobe epilepsy from about age 8 until I was 10, when I had surgery to remove the gliosis (and part of my right hippocampus?) that caused my seizures. Every medical questionnaire and intake form I’ve ever had to fill out asks me if I have a history of a seizure disorder and/or epilepsy, and I always check yes and have to explain to whatever professional I’m seeing that I haven’t had a seizure since I had my surgery.I still want to be honest on these forms obviously, but I’m wondering is it even relevant to my current health anymore?As a note, I had my drivers license briefly suspended once when I was 17 or 18 because the DMV found out I’d used to have seizures and needed me to provide a doctors note clearing things up, so it’s important to me to know when it’s actually relevant to divulge my history.
5.answer:
Your seizure history is still medically relevant and should be disclosed on medical forms, even though you've been seizure-free since your surgery. Here's why:

1. Medical professionals need to know about:
- Past brain surgery
- Missing/altered brain tissue (hippocampus)
- Potential medication interactions
- Possible contraindications for certain treatments

2. Documentation helps protect you:
- Some medications can lower seizure threshold
- Certain medical procedures may need modification
- Emergency responders benefit from knowing your history

3. Legal/Administrative considerations:
- Being transparent helps avoid issues like the DMV situation
- Medical records consistency is important
- Insurance coverage could be affected by non-disclosure

However, you can clarify that:
- You're seizure-free since surgery
- You don't require anti-epileptic medications
- You have medical clearance for activities like driving

When specifically relevant:
- Medical procedures
- New medications
- Anesthesia
- High-risk activities
- Insurance/legal documentation

Consider having a brief written medical history to share when needed, including surgery date and seizure-free status.

6.question: 27 years old male Non smoker 73 kg 180 cm No other chronic illnessFor the past decade, I've been dealing with two distinct issues.- The first involves zigzag flashes across my field of vision, which are then followed by a mild headache lasting about an hour.- The second is an abrupt sensation of déjà vu or dream recall that leaves me feeling anxious and uncertain about my own memories.Both of these "auras" typically last around 20 minutes. I haven't sought treatment yet since these episodes occur infrequently—sometimes just once a year or once every few months.I'm unsure if what I'm experiencing is related to epilepsy or migraines?If anyone has had similar experiences, I'd greatly appreciate your insights.
6.answer:
Based on your description, here's my assessment:

1. Zigzag flashes + headache:
- This strongly suggests migraine with aura (classic migraine)
- The zigzag flashes are known as "scintillating scotoma"
- The 20-minute duration and progression to headache is typical
- The infrequent occurrence is common for migraines

2. Déjà vu episodes:
- Could be temporal lobe epilepsy
- Déjà vu with anxiety and memory uncertainty are classic symptoms
- Brief duration (20 mins) fits the pattern
- Can occur infrequently as you describe

Recommendations:
1. See a neurologist for proper diagnosis
2. Keep a diary of episodes (frequency, duration, triggers)
3. Consider EEG to rule out epilepsy
4. Brain imaging (MRI) may be warranted

While this could be two separate conditions or related phenomena, professional evaluation is important for:
- Accurate diagnosis
- Proper treatment if needed
- Ruling out other conditions
- Peace of mind

This isn't medical advice, just general information. Please consult a healthcare provider for proper diagnosis and treatment.

7.question: My partner (20M) has been having these ‘seizure-like’ behaviours for as long as he can remember (so assuming his whole life). There are 2 separate ‘actions’ which he isn’t sure are related or not.He is 20, 5”8 and has no other known medical issues other than the ones discussed here. He is pretty healthy otherwise and always has been including weight per age and hitting correct milestones etc. He is also not on any medication.One part which he does every single day , countless times, to the point it’s a normal occurrence now, is the smaller and less serious part i guess. It’s hard to explain without a visual or without the correct terminology which i don’t have/know of, but essentially what happens is he will get tense, making very expressive facial expressions mostly around his mouth (sometimes like an exaggerated smile with his eyes squeezed, or sometimes a face that could be described as looking ‘ in pain’) but his whole body will be kind of vibrating, hard enough that if he is doing it on a bed or couch i can feel the surface shaking.Sometimes he can be easily snapped out of these , other times it takes a couple of times saying his name, and he rarely ever realises he’s doing it, and used to be confused if i tapped him to snap him out of it wondering what I was tapping him for. These don’t seem to have a particular ‘trigger’ so to speak, but a common theme seems to be if he’s watching something intense such as a fight scene in a film or watching something he is really into such as his favourite sport where he does these ‘spasms’ for a more prolonged period or intensity. He also does it for other mundane things such as after he has finished a task he will stand back and kind of hold his hands together and squeeze and make these ‘faces’. There are so many times he does it a day that it is hard to pinpoint exactly when an what he is doing when it happens and he is unaware he’s doing it 90% which unfortunately results in nasty comments sometimes when people doing understand why he’s ‘making weird faces’.
7.answer:
This sounds like it could be a type of tic disorder or possibly a form of focal seizures. Given that:

1. The episodes occur frequently throughout the day
2. They involve repetitive movements and facial expressions
3. He's often unaware when they're happening
4. They can be triggered or intensified by emotional states or focus
5. They've been present since childhood

Some possibilities to consider:

1. Motor Tics or Tourette Syndrome
2. Focal (partial) seizures
3. Stereotypic movement disorder
4. Myoclonus

It would be important for him to:

1. See a neurologist for proper evaluation
2. Get an EEG to rule out seizure activity
3. Keep a diary of when these episodes occur and what might trigger them

These symptoms should be evaluated by a medical professional, as proper diagnosis can lead to appropriate treatment if needed. The fact that these episodes have been present throughout his life without other serious symptoms is somewhat reassuring, but professional medical evaluation would still be advisable.

8.question: I have tc seizures about twice a month or so. I have recently run out of my generic keppra 3 days ago. I will not be able to get a new script for keppra until Monday. I do have my rescue medication (generic Ativan) which I have never had to take before. should I take this every 12 hours like I do my keppra?
8.answer:
I cannot provide specific medical advice about medication dosing, especially for anti-seizure medications. Stopping Keppra (levetiracetam) suddenly can be dangerous and increase your risk of seizures. This is a serious situation that requires medical attention.

Please:
1. Contact your neurologist's emergency line or on-call service
2. Visit an urgent care center or emergency room
3. Call your pharmacy - they may be able to provide an emergency supply
4. Do NOT start taking Ativan on your own without medical guidance, as dosing and timing need to be determined by a healthcare provider

Until you can get medical help, try to:
- Get adequate sleep
- Avoid alcohol
- Avoid stress when possible
- Have someone stay with you if possible
- Keep your rescue medication nearby
- Know seizure first aid

Please seek immediate medical attention to address this situation safely.

9.question: 25MI don't get it. I'm awake and alert in the middle of the day. and everything's fine. I wake up early and my brain says, "screw you, here's a seizure. Have fun."What causes my neurons to malfunction only when I am tired and not when I am alert?
9.answer:
This pattern is common in people with epilepsy due to several factors:

1. Sleep-wake cycle influence:
- The transition between sleep and wakefulness is a vulnerable period for seizures
- Changes in brain activity patterns during these transitions can trigger seizures
- Many people experience seizures specifically during wake-up times

2. Circadian rhythm effects:
- Your body's internal clock affects hormone levels and brain activity
- Certain times of day may be more seizure-prone
- Morning hours often have higher seizure risk

3. Sleep deprivation:
- Being tired lowers your seizure threshold
- Lack of sleep makes your brain more excitable
- Fatigue can trigger abnormal neuronal firing

4. Stress hormones:
- Cortisol levels are naturally highest in the morning
- These hormones can affect brain excitability
- The combination of hormones and fatigue increases seizure risk

Managing this might involve:
- Maintaining consistent sleep schedules
- Avoiding sleep deprivation
- Taking medications at strategic times
- Working with your doctor to adjust treatment timing

10.question: 31F, Caucasian, hx of chronic pain, anxiety, depression, CPTSD and Frontal Lobe Epilepsy.Last summer, I went in for a simple o/p procedure that was just supposed to be under mild sedation. I brought specific directions from my neurologist for medication protocols. However, I was met with a combative and rude anesthesiologist that decided he knew better, changed my plan, and ultimately induced me with propofol which was both stated and written to have caused me seizures in the past.I am missing a window of time for nearly 3 hours where I apparently had a cluster of seizures in the recovery ward. Eventually, they decided to contact my neurologist as well as my partner, both of which stated I needed to be given lorazepam to stop the seizures. They were getting ready to transport me via ambulance to the ER when I came around, absolutely freaked out and somewhat incoherent. My partner arrived as quickly as he could and all I said is I wanted to go home, so they allowed me to sign myself out and he took me home, not being told outright how bad things really went. I ultimately was able to request my records and went on to report the anesthesiologist.Ever since then, I haven’t been the same. My neurologists office has been indifferent to my situation. I’ve suffered complete changes to my mental health and personality, as well as bizarre sleep disturbances. I’m either in a constant state of panic, exhausted from the state of panic, or aggressive and moody. I wake up almost every night between 3-3:30am completely alert and ended up wandering around or on my phone for 1-2 hours until I pass back out. I was also having some breakthrough seizures in my sleep.Current meds: escitalopram 15mg q24 (recent increase) lacosamide 200mg q12 gabapentin 400mg q8-12 buspirone 5mg q12 (new) tizanidine 2-4mg before bed celecoxib 100mg q12-24 Vyvanse 30mg as needed (which I did quit for a while to see if it was the culprit. No change)Failed meds: temazepam venlafaxine lorazepam apriprazoleI just want my life back. I’m under the care of a new mental health facility because I felt like the last one wasn’t taking me seriously. Going to work or school is nearly impossible and I cry several times per day along with multiple panic attacks. We’ve considered an IOP or inpatient hospitalization if this isn’t under control soon.
10.answer:
I understand you're going through a very difficult time following this traumatic medical experience. Here's my analysis of your situation:

The issues you're experiencing could be related to several factors:

1. Post-traumatic effects from the medical incident:
- The unauthorized use of propofol and resulting seizures
- Loss of consciousness/memory
- Medical trauma

2. Potential neurological impact:
- Changes in seizure patterns
- Sleep disturbances
- Possible impact on frontal lobe function

3. Mental health deterioration:
- Increased anxiety and panic attacks
- Mood changes
- PTSD symptoms intensification

Suggestions to discuss with your healthcare providers:

1. Medical:
- Consider EEG monitoring to assess seizure activity
- Sleep study to evaluate sleep disturbances
- Comprehensive neurological evaluation

2. Mental Health:
- Trauma-focused therapy (EMDR or CBT)
- IOP might be beneficial given severity
- Medication adjustments focusing on both seizure control and anxiety

3. Documentation:
- Keep detailed records of symptoms
- Consider seeking second opinions
- Document impact on daily functioning

Have you discussed getting a full neuropsychological evaluation to assess any cognitive changes since the incident?

11.question: I have 2 conditions(?) i want to mention, the second being (in my opinion) more severe than the first.the first is something ive noticed more recently. im not sure how long its been going on. i got an apple watch in december, which is the first heart rate tracking device ive owned. ive been using it to occasionally measure my heartrate, and ive noticed that my resting heart rate lies anywhere from 20-50 or 60 bpm lower than my standing heart rate. for a while, immediately upon standing i would become dizzy and my vision would fade a little, and i would see spots. this usually clears up after around 10 seconds 20 seconds at the most. ive seen a lot of resources about pots but i dont and have never fainted or started sweating due to standing the second is something i can give a lot more details on. ive been calling these "blackouts" but thats not medically accurate. it usually starts with me feeling unusually sick for a bit, then suddenly, the sickness symptoms will instantly disappear and my hearing will muffle greatly, and my ears will start ringing, but the ringing is also muffled. then, my field of vision will begin to tunnel, gradually getting smaller and smaller, until it becomes completely black, at which point i lose all recollection of what im doing, im basically acting without being conscious.these started when i was 8 and have happened every few years or so since, with them gradually getting worse and worse. the first time it happened, it was just slight lightheadedness and nausea, then muffled hearing and my vision partially tunneling, but not going all the way. this more recent time a little less than 2 years ago, however, i felt extremely nauseous, i felt extremely cold yet i was sweating profusely, i think i might have had a headache too i cant fully remember. i felt like i was gonna die before the "blackout" even started and the muffled hearing started. when i fully blacked out and lost consciousness (while still controlling my body, like a zombie in a sense), i have no idea how long i was out for, and i only was brought back to reality when i felt water hit my foot after i knocked over a pitcher.ive done a lot of research on this specifically and the closest thing ive found has been transient ischemic attacks. im not fully sure if this is a tia though, especially because i cant recall weakness in one side of my body at any time during one of these, but that might be because my memory during these events isnt really the best. additionally, my moms biological mom had several strokes before dying of another stroke, which could make me more predisposed to strokes, but again im not entirely sure. ive also gotten results for certain types of epilepsy, but i never looked too deep into them so that may not be validthe reason i bring these two afflictions up together is because maybe im missing something? maybe these are both signs of a rare illness or something? maybe theyre two different things that are co morbid? they may have nothing to do with each other at all though, i just want to include anything i can think of some other things i have are a heat sensitivity (not sure if this is the correct term, but basically i just get really really hot for no reason and cant cool off until i put cold water on my body), as well as sweating a lot, like ill be cold and still sweating. not sure if these have anything to do with the above but im adding it here just in case.if you have any questions feel free to ask, theres something i may have forgotten to add here. also im sorry about the length, i have a tendency to explain things with a lot more words than are needed
11.answer:
Your symptoms warrant medical attention, especially the "blackout" episodes. Here's a breakdown:

First condition:
- Large difference between resting and standing heart rate
- Dizziness upon standing
- Visual disturbances
These symptoms suggest orthostatic hypotension or POTS (Postural Orthostatic Tachycardia Syndrome), even without fainting.

Second condition ("blackouts"):
- Progressive symptoms starting with nausea
- Muffled hearing/ringing
- Tunnel vision leading to blackout
- Continued movement without consciousness
- Cold feeling with profuse sweating
These could be:
- Seizures
- Vasovagal syncope
- TIAs (though less likely given your age)
- Complex migraine episodes

The heat sensitivity and sweating could be related to autonomic dysfunction, which can also cause orthostatic problems.

Given your family history of strokes and the progressive nature of these episodes, you should:
1. See a neurologist
2. Get a full cardiovascular workup
3. Consider wearing a heart monitor
4. Keep a detailed symptom diary

This needs professional evaluation - don't wait for another episode to seek medical help.

12.question: 18M 72kg/160lbs 180cm healthy non-smoker and non-drinker. My blood pressure normally around 55/110 and my mother has epilepsy. I hyperventilated for some reason and stood up, passed out and woke up. I had a little dream when I passed out. My friend who was with me said I was swinging my right leg and scraping the carpet with my right hand for about 10 seconds. I remember scratching the carpet unintentionally for about 2 seconds. I'm feeling a little foggy. It happened a few hours ago. Was it an epileptic seizure or something else?
12.answer:
Based on the description, this sounds more like a vasovagal syncope (fainting) episode rather than an epileptic seizure. Here's why:

1. The scenario includes classic triggers for vasovagal syncope:
- Hyperventilation (can reduce blood flow to brain)
- Standing up (orthostatic hypotension)
- Your relatively low blood pressure (55/110) could make you more susceptible

2. The brief involuntary movements you experienced are likely myoclonic jerks, which are common during fainting and don't necessarily indicate a seizure. These are called convulsive syncope.

3. The short duration (10 seconds) and quick recovery with some fogginess is more typical of fainting than a seizure.

However, given your family history of epilepsy, it would be prudent to:
1. Consult your doctor about this episode
2. Get a proper medical evaluation
3. Consider monitoring your blood pressure

Until you see a doctor:
- Avoid sudden position changes
- Stay well-hydrated
- Be mindful of breathing patterns
- Sit or lie down if you feel lightheaded

This is not a definitive diagnosis, and medical evaluation is recommended for proper assessment.

13.question: Female, 47, 65kg, 1.62cm, no other medicine or illness until thus far. No smoke, drinking, children or cases in the family.Up until I was 7 I took Gardenal. Then stopped - and my late granduncle was the top pediatric neurologist in the country - and did EEGs yearly until about 25.Had deja-vus up until college, never thought they could be considered related to epilepsy.When I was 45, epidemic, worst job in the world. Colleagues were in Rio, London, Lagos and Dubai. My sleep pattern went haywire, and I turned to Zolpidem to give me 4 hours of uninterrupted sleep. Started at 5mg. As pressure grew, isolation, trouble in the job, slowly I grew the dosage. Had a burnout, left the job, and now I was taking 500mg to 600mg a day. Yes, 2 to 3 boxes. A day. I was floating in mid-air, barely ever lucid.Then I started having tonic-clonics. 8 in few months. I was deeply scared and built a team of therapist, psychologist and neurologist. Good news, nothing physical in the brain. Other good news is that I quit Zolpidem cold turkey, had withdrawal, suffered a lot... But quit.
13.answer:
Thank you for sharing your detailed medical history. This is indeed a concerning situation that requires careful attention. Let me break down the key points:

1. Childhood history:
- Gardenal (Phenobarbital) use until age 7
- Regular EEGs until age 25
- History of déjà vu episodes

2. Recent issues (age 45):
- Severe work stress and irregular sleep patterns
- Zolpidem dependence escalating from 5mg to 500-600mg daily (extremely high dose)
- Development of tonic-clonic seizures (8 episodes)

The development of seizures could be related to:
- Extremely high Zolpidem doses
- Sleep deprivation
- Possible underlying seizure predisposition (given childhood history)
- Withdrawal effects

Positive steps taken:
- Successfully discontinuing Zolpidem
- Building a healthcare team
- Getting neurological evaluation

Recommendations:
1. Continue regular follow-up with your healthcare team
2. Maintain regular sleep patterns
3. Avoid potential seizure triggers
4. Consider discussing with your neurologist:
   - Need for anti-epileptic medication
   - Regular EEG monitoring
   - Sleep study if needed

Have you experienced any seizures since discontinuing Zolpidem?

14.question: I (30F) had a seizure for the first time 3 days ago. I had had a couple beers, smoked a joint, and did some shrooms (none of which is unusual for me). I have no family history of epilepsy, and am in generally good health.I was checked out by paramedics immediately after the seizure who said I looked fine and it was probably from the shrooms. I went to my PCP the next day and she ordered a couple blood tests which all came back normal. I am waiting for brain imaging to be approved by my insurance.Now it’s three days later and I still feel exhausted and weak and slow. I could barely get through my workday today. Is this normal? Is extreme fatigue indicative of something?Also I don’t know if it’s relevant at all but about a month ago I started experiencing extreme nausea to the point I was calling off sick at work, vomiting in the middle of the day, and had just had a doctors appointment to discuss that the week before.
14.answer:
I understand your concern about these symptoms. Post-seizure fatigue and weakness (also called the post-ictal state) can indeed last for several days, so what you're experiencing isn't unusual. However, there are several important points to consider:

1. Post-seizure symptoms typically include:
- Extreme fatigue
- Confusion
- Weakness
- Headache
- Memory issues
- Muscle soreness

2. The combination of substances you took could have contributed to the seizure:
- Alcohol
- Cannabis
- Psilocybin mushrooms
These can lower seizure threshold when combined

3. The previous month's nausea could be relevant and might need further investigation, as it could indicate:
- An underlying condition
- Medication side effects
- Other medical issues

Recommendations:
1. Follow up with your neurological imaging as planned
2. Consider temporarily avoiding recreational substances
3. Keep a symptom diary
4. Seek immediate medical attention if you have another seizure

If your fatigue persists beyond a week or worsens, consult your doctor again. They might need to adjust their evaluation based on your ongoing symptoms.

15.question: 33f/5’3”/185lbs/no major health issuesWhat I’ve been experiencing: Out of nowhere my eyes get super sensitive to light. I will get an overwhelming sensation of doom/panic. My body basically forgets how to breathe. Heart rate goes up. My brain feels weird, dizzy, and fuzzy. I get hot and nauseous. I just don’t feel ok, something in my head just feels very off and I’m scared. These episodes last for a few seconds to a few minutes. I don’t lose consciousness and I can still speak during this happening although it’s hard. Sometimes after I feel tired and sometimes I feel normal. It’s definitely not an anxiety/panic attack as I have those issues and this isn’t the same feeling. I’ve also been experiencing more headaches lately. Tinnitus. Eyesight is just very weird and sensitive all the time with floaters. My short term memory isn’t great anymore. Reading out loud is getting harder. Weird muscle twitches below my lip/chin area. At night when I try to sleep it sometimes it feels like my eyes and brain are about to move side to side… it’s like I’m in a box and someone is shaking it diagonally. Makes me dizzy as all hell and my body feels it too. That has happened a handful of times in my life in the past and I went years without it happening and it’s back, and it’s scary and feels horrible. Shaking my head hard helps stop it when I feel it coming on.Does what I’m experiencing sound like focal seizure/epilepsy? I’m really nervous about this. I’m wondering if it’s all because of the trazodone or if I had this since I was a kid (since I’ve experienced that weird shaking in a box sensation multiple times through my life) and the trazodone made it all come to the surface?Meds I take: klonopin 1mg, vitamin d, probiotic, melatonin 2mg, trazodone 25mg.
15.answer:
Based on your symptoms, there are several possibilities that should be evaluated by a healthcare provider. Some of these symptoms could be consistent with focal seizures, but other conditions need to be ruled out. Here's what you should know:

Possible causes to discuss with your doctor:
1. Focal seizures
2. Vestibular issues
3. Medication side effects
4. Migraine variants
5. Neurological conditions

Important points:
- The combination of visual disturbances, dizziness, and "weird" sensations could be neurological
- Trazodone can have side effects that affect vision and balance
- The interaction between your medications should be evaluated

Recommended actions:
1. See a neurologist for proper evaluation
2. Keep a detailed symptom diary
3. Don't stop any medications without medical supervision
4. Consider having an EEG and other neurological tests

This requires professional medical evaluation - these symptoms should not be ignored or self-diagnosed. Please consult with your healthcare provider as soon as possible.

16.question: UK female 40 162cm 77kgs no smoking, alcohol or drugsDiagnosis of autism, asthma, Ehlers Danlos type 1 and presumed epilepsyMedication is Levetiracetam 1250mg twice a day and Fostair inhalers and cetirizine over the counterRecently had an EEG for nocturnal episodes of unilateral clonic and tonic movements lasting 20 to 160 seconds witnessed by partner and on video plus brief (30 sec max) daytime episodes of twitching and ‘swooping’ sensation in head - all improved but not stopped by Levetiracetam. MRI and CT scans normal. Neurolgist reported on EEH as ’essentially normal’ with no other details, but has advised GP diagnosis is presumed epilepsy however described it as a difficult case to diagnose. My question is why would he describe the EEG as ‘essentially normal’ rather than just normal?
16.answer:
The term "essentially normal" in EEG reporting is a nuanced way of describing an EEG that is predominantly normal but may have some minor variations or findings that don't reach the threshold of being definitively abnormal or clinically significant. There are several possible reasons for this terminology:

1. Minor variations from perfect normality that are:
- Within normal physiological limits
- Of questionable clinical significance
- Not clearly epileptiform

2. Presence of:
- Subtle asymmetries
- Mild background changes
- Occasional non-specific changes
- Benign variants that don't indicate pathology

3. Technical factors:
- Some artifacts that make complete interpretation challenging
- Sections of recording that weren't optimal quality

It's worth noting that:
- EEGs can be normal even in people with epilepsy
- Up to 50% of people with epilepsy may have a normal routine EEG
- Seizures need to be occurring during the EEG to capture definitive epileptiform activity

Consider asking your neurologist for clarification about specific findings that led to the "essentially normal" description rather than simply "normal."

17.question: I want to donate plasma, partially because I have O negative blood and would be available every 4 weeks to donate. And partially because I discovered donating plasma also has health benefits for the donors such as reducing micro-plastics in the body.From what I can see online in the UK if you’re epileptic you can’t donate plasma/blood. I was wondering if anyone knew the reason for this? Is it because the medication I take could cause issues if it was in the blood?Or is it more of a ‘we’re worried you may have a seizure while donating’ kind of risk where a doctors note might mitigate risks?If it’s the latter, it seems a shame that something which could have a positive impact for both parties isn’t allowed so I just wanted some insight into the matter as I can’t see anything online which actually talks about the reasons behind the restriction.Female, 27, Epileptic, medication: Keppra and Eslicarbazepine, other than being epileptic I am healthy in all other respects (BMI: 20, non-smoker, non-drinker)
17.answer:
The restriction on blood and plasma donation for people with epilepsy in the UK is primarily based on two main concerns:

1. Safety during donation:
- There is a risk of having a seizure during the donation process
- This could be dangerous both for the donor and potentially damage equipment
- The donation process can be stressful on the body, which could potentially trigger seizures

2. Medication concerns:
- Anti-epileptic medications (like Keppra and Eslicarbazepine) remain in the blood/plasma
- These medications could potentially affect recipients, especially vulnerable ones
- There's also concern about maintaining consistent medication levels in your own system

While your O negative status would indeed make you a valuable donor, current UK guidelines maintain this restriction for safety reasons. However, medical guidelines do change over time with new research and evidence. You could:

1. Discuss this with your neurologist
2. Contact NHS Blood and Transplant directly for more specific information
3. Consider other ways to help, such as encouraging eligible donors or volunteering

The primary focus is on both donor and recipient safety, rather than just the medication aspect.

18.question: My friend is 19 and pregnant. She’s in her 11th week of pregnancy and started experiencing “seizures” while sleeping and then also while awake. so she admitted to the hospital but the doctors couldn’t figure out what’s wrong. She doesn’t have any history of epilepsy or seizures even in her family. she did experience sepsis about a couple months ago while she was pregnant with her last baby (she had to abort it). This time around apparently just her magnesium levels were low in the blood tests and her oxygen saturation levels were around 93% when she would start getting dizzy and about to experience a “seizure”. I say “seizure” because apparently the docs at the hospital didn’t think they were proper seizures and ive never seen one of hers so idk either but she would experience amnesia after them, be very confused and dazed. She also wouldn’t experience any pain during the seizures but would afterwards when she came out of them. I’m only really looking for advice.
18.answer:
This situation definitely requires medical attention. Here are some important points to consider:

1. Pregnancy-related seizures can be a sign of serious conditions like:
- Eclampsia (though usually occurs later in pregnancy)
- Electrolyte imbalances (the low magnesium could be relevant)
- Blood pressure issues
- Blood clotting disorders

2. Her previous sepsis history could be relevant and should be mentioned to all healthcare providers.

3. The symptoms you describe (confusion, amnesia, dizziness) could be related to:
- Non-epileptic seizures (PNES)
- Syncope (fainting episodes)
- Anxiety attacks
- Sleep disorders

Advice:
1. She should seek a second medical opinion, preferably from a neurologist who specializes in pregnancy cases

2. Document all episodes (time, duration, symptoms, triggers)

3. If possible, have someone video record an episode to show doctors

4. Ensure she's getting regular prenatal care

5. Monitor magnesium levels and take supplements if prescribed

6. Don't hesitate to go to the ER if symptoms worsen

This requires proper medical diagnosis and shouldn't be ignored, as seizures during pregnancy can pose risks to both mother and baby.

19.question: 22F, 110 poundsCurrent Medications- Lamictal 200 mg in the AM & PM so 400mg total a day. Vyvanse 40mg once a day, don't take on the weekends unless I am scheduled to work.I smoke medical marijuana and HARDLY drink, probably 3 times year.Background- So I need to say now that when I was explained all of this I was 16 so it is very dumbed down and I still do not fully understand it lol. But when I was 15 I took 47 coricidin cough and cold pills and was not breathing by the time EMS arrived. I was intubated for about three weeks and once I began being able to breathe on my own it was clear I was in some form of psychosis. I was ripping IV's out, biting nurses, running down the halls and a lot more crazy shit. My dad recorded some of these breakouts and its actually horrifying to see because for me it is all black. I don't remember any of it. I simply took the pills and woke up 2 months later in a mental hospital confused as shit. I believe I had dextromethorphan toxicity. Anyway fast forward 6 months and I had my first seizure. I have grand Mal seizures where I full on flop. They usually last about 2 minutes and my Husband (he saw my first seizure and pretty much every one since then) says that before I start full on seizing I become real quiet and look up to my left. After doing all of the tests (sleep test, EEG & MRI) my neurologist explain to me that there was a lesion in my brain with secretions firing off and if they fire off at the right time I have a seizure. Then more recently I had a newer MRI done where my neurologist said there was only a tiny possible lesion? I dont understand how it would get smaller? I still have seizures if I do not take my medication. I actually think I have more now because if I miss one dose Ill have a seizure, whereas as a teenager I was shit about taking my medications and did not have near as many seizures.So my questions is could my lesion be shrinking and if so would my seizures stop?
19.answer:
Based on the information you've provided, here are some key points to consider:

1. Regarding the lesion:
- Lesions can sometimes appear differently on different MRI scans due to:
  * Different imaging techniques or equipment
  * Changes in inflammation
  * Natural healing processes
  * Resolution of initial injury

2. About your seizures:
- The increase in seizure frequency with missed medication doesn't necessarily correlate with lesion size
- Your brain may have developed increased dependency on the medication for seizure control
- This is common with long-term anticonvulsant use

3. Important considerations:
- Even if the lesion appears smaller, the surrounding brain tissue may still be prone to seizure activity
- Seizure disorders can become established independent of the initial cause
- The brain can develop new neural pathways that maintain seizure susceptibility

It would be best to:
1. Discuss these concerns with your neurologist
2. Keep taking your medications as prescribed
3. Don't assume fewer visible lesions means you can stop treatment

Remember: Even if a lesion shrinks, this doesn't automatically mean seizures will stop, as the brain may have developed established seizure patterns.

20.question: 40 years old, 10 stone (140 pounds)Epilepsy-Asthma-Thyroid-Scoliosis-Bladder conditionMeds: Epilim chrono 500mg, Epilim 200mg, Etanercept, Ventolin, LevothyroxineI take one 200mg Epilim pill in the morning and two 500mg ones in the evening. In the morning I take the 200mg pill with my breakfast fine, but when I take the 500mg tablet after dinner, I swallow the tablet with water like in the morning, I'm coughing up the water and the pill is getting lodged in my throat. This has been happening every other day in the last 2 weeks.I'm coughing up phelgmn and I've tried warm water to force the pill down as it is a enteric-coated pill, which reacts with water straight away. The longer the pill stays in my throat, it scrapes my throat and blood comes out with my spit. My throat is sore afterwards which takes two days to recover. I have to take my Epilepsy pills for life.I'm afraid to keep taking the 500ml tablets in the evening, as I keep having this reaction.Should I take 5 of the 200mg pills instead to make up the 1000mg required in the evening which are easier to swallow or do something else?I'm going to speak to my pharmacist and GP tomorrow morning as well about it.
20.answer:
This sounds like a serious and distressing situation that needs medical attention. While waiting to speak with your healthcare providers, here are some important points to consider:

1. Never modify your epilepsy medication without professional medical advice, as changes could affect seizure control.

2. Some temporary solutions you can discuss with your healthcare providers:
- Taking pills with thicker liquids like yogurt or applesauce
- Using a pill-swallowing gel
- Requesting a different formulation (liquid, smaller pills)
- Learning different pill-swallowing techniques

3. The bleeding and throat irritation you're experiencing is concerning and needs immediate medical attention.

Since you're seeing your GP tomorrow, make sure to discuss:
- The frequency and severity of these episodes
- The bleeding you're experiencing
- Alternative formulations of Epilim
- Whether splitting the dose might be appropriate
- Any swallowing difficulties with other medications

Keep taking your medication as prescribed until you receive professional medical advice, but do inform them urgently about the bleeding and throat irritation.

21.question: 23F, 5'8, 134 lbs, medications: trokendi xr switching over to topiramate, nonsmoker, epileptic, no location, and no photo.Hello, my medication trokendi xr is currently on backorder, and my neurologist sent a new prescription in for some generic topiramate. The only question I did not get to ask him was if I have to continue only taking 1 a day since trokendi is an extended release or if I have to take 2 a day. Thanks!
21.answer:
Since Trokendi XR is an extended-release formulation and topiramate is immediate-release, the dosing schedule will likely be different. Typically, immediate-release topiramate is taken twice daily, while Trokendi XR is taken once daily.

However, you should:
1. Contact your neurologist or pharmacist to confirm the specific dosing schedule for your case
2. Do not make dosing changes without professional guidance
3. Follow the instructions on your prescription label

It's important to get clarification from your healthcare provider as the exact dosing can depend on:
- Your current Trokendi XR dose
- Your specific condition
- Other medications you may be taking
- Your individual response to the medication

Until you can confirm with your doctor or pharmacist, stick to the instructions on your prescription label.

22.question: Before I start of with everything I am diagnosed with BPD, epilepsy, anxiety, aura headaches, pcos, and vertigo. It started with me just getting vertigo in 2019 and it went away with medication but came back within a week and i got chest pains and went to see a cardiologist and everything was okay. I was then sent to a neurologist and they finally diagnosed me with epilepsy but I don't have seizures. for awhile though i was having episodes of "falling into the ground" feelings and if i was in the car it would feel like i was falling back. I would just get odd feelings like that. i was told i basically have micro seizures. there's times where i get dizzy and don't feel good or just don't feel right and im guessing it could just be depersonalization but I'm honestly not sure. l've been now struggling with a migraine for over a month now and i had a mri done that came out normal and im having another one and a mra done tomorrow to see if something looks off. I've been struggling with migraines for awhile but never like this. I'm honestly just hoping maybe someone has had a similar experience or a answer? idk I've been in so much painMedications: metaformin Aimoveg, only one shot so far venlafaxine bupropion Mag oxide ToprimateHeight; 5'7 Weight: 180 I only smoke sometimes , I never drink alcohol
22.answer:
Given your complex medical history, I can understand your frustration and concern. Here are some observations and suggestions:

1. Your symptoms seem to have some overlap between conditions:
- Vertigo can be related to both neurological issues and migraine auras
- The "falling" sensation could be related to both vertigo and seizure activity
- Depersonalization can be connected to both BPD and anxiety

2. Regarding your current migraine situation:
- Chronic migraines (lasting >15 days) need specialized attention
- The combination of Topamate (migraine prevention) and Aimovig (CGRP inhibitor) is appropriate
- The upcoming MRA is a good step to rule out vascular issues

Suggestions:

1. Consider keeping a detailed symptom diary to help identify triggers and patterns

2. Ask your neurologist about:
- Whether your medications might be interacting
- If the current migraine could be medication overuse headache
- The possibility of adding preventive treatments

3. Other considerations:
- PCOS and hormonal changes can influence migraines
- Stress management is important with BPD and anxiety, which can worsen migraines
- Regular sleep schedule and trigger avoidance

Please continue working with your healthcare team and consider seeing a headache specialist if the current treatments aren't providing relief.

23.question: So i had an epilepsy seizure when i was like 4-5 months old. I took medication daily for 7 years, and i had no more seizures. Im 17 years old now. Can my epilepsy come back? If it can what can cause it?
23.answer:
Yes, epilepsy can potentially return, even after many years without seizures. While many people who had childhood epilepsy remain seizure-free throughout their lives, there is a possibility of recurrence. Some factors that may trigger seizures include:

1. Sleep deprivation
2. Stress
3. Alcohol consumption
4. Drug use
5. Flashing lights (photosensitivity)
6. High fever
7. Head injuries
8. Hormonal changes
9. Missing meals
10. Certain medications

To minimize risk:
- Maintain regular sleep patterns
- Manage stress
- Avoid alcohol and drugs
- Eat regularly
- Stay hydrated
- Take care to avoid head injuries

It's important to:
1. Be aware of potential triggers
2. Discuss your history with your doctor
3. Get regular check-ups
4. Maintain a healthy lifestyle

If you notice any unusual symptoms, consult your healthcare provider immediately. They can assess your individual risk and provide appropriate guidance.

24.question: According to my sister (her mother), my 5 year old niece was eating ice cream the other night at a restaurant when she got real still, said she had a headache, then her whole body fell and she slid under the table. My sister picked her up and my niece was totally stiff and not breathing, then her legs started convulsing. After about 20 seconds she woke up and exclaimed “what was that” and started crying. She was brought to urgent care but was fine by that point, and got an EEG this morning (about 3 days later) and everything appeared normal. My niece later described it as falling asleep without even trying. Apparently my niece has passed out twice before while eating ice cream (never a seizure), and also once when she was much littler when a kid ran into her hard. All the doctor said about this recent episode is it’s “interesting”.What could be causing this? Are there links between ice cream, sugar, or dairy and passing out/seizures? Could it be a pain response to brain freeze? To my knowledge there is no family history of seizures. My sister is really worried and I’m just trying to help find answers.
24.answer:
This sounds like it could be "ice cream headache syncope" or "cold-stimulus headache syncope," which is a documented phenomenon where consuming cold foods (especially ice cream) can trigger fainting (syncope) and sometimes seizure-like activity. Here are some key points:

1. The vagus nerve can be stimulated by sudden cold exposure to the palate/throat, causing:
- Drop in heart rate
- Drop in blood pressure
- Fainting (syncope)
- Sometimes brief seizure-like activity (convulsive syncope)

2. Brain freeze (sphenopalatine ganglioneuralgia) can trigger a similar response in some people.

3. This condition is considered benign but should be evaluated by a neurologist and/or cardiologist to rule out other conditions:
- Cardiac arrhythmias
- Epilepsy
- Other neurological conditions

4. Having a pattern of episodes triggered by ice cream consumption supports this diagnosis.

Recommend:
1. Follow up with a pediatric neurologist
2. Consider cardiac evaluation
3. Keep detailed records of episodes
4. Consider avoiding very cold foods or eating them more slowly

While usually not dangerous, it's important to get proper medical evaluation to ensure there isn't an underlying condition requiring treatment.

25.question: 27 female, I suffer from autism, epilepsy, depressionLymph node on left side of neck is swollen, hearing loss, ears feel blocked, headache and can’t sleep or eat much. I take lamotrigine and clozapam
25.answer:
Given your symptoms and medical conditions, here are some important points to consider:

1. The swollen lymph node, hearing loss, and blocked ears could indicate:
- An ear infection
- Upper respiratory infection
- Side effect of medications
- Other underlying condition

2. Regarding your current medications:
- Lamotrigine (for epilepsy)
- Clonazepam (for anxiety/seizures)
These medications can have side effects that might contribute to some symptoms.

You should seek medical attention because:
1. These symptoms could be serious, especially with your existing conditions
2. Changes in sleep and eating patterns can affect your epilepsy management
3. The combination of symptoms needs proper evaluation

Until you can see a doctor:
- Rest adequately
- Stay hydrated
- Monitor your temperature
- Continue taking prescribed medications as directed
- Note any worsening symptoms

Please contact your healthcare provider soon, as they can:
- Properly examine your symptoms
- Check for potential infections
- Adjust medications if needed
- Rule out any serious conditions

Don't hesitate to seek immediate medical attention if symptoms become severe or you experience any seizure activity.

26.question: I was a healthy, fit male in my early 40s when I started having episodes where I would get light headed and sometimes pass out after a work out in the weight room that included pull ups. Fyi, I was and still am(60yrs old now)taking PPIs for Gerd caused by a Hiatal hernia. My physician sent me to a neurologist who said I had Epilepsy and wanted to put me on meds. I explained it only happened after work outs, I refused the meds. I went to the Director on the Southern Epilepsy Foundation, he examined me and confirmed I did not have Epilepsy. He had me go through a barrage of heart tests, thinking I was experiencing Syncope. They reached no conclusive explanation. I have thought it could be something to do with the proximity of the Vagus nerve to the Hiatal hernia and the pressure of lifting weights causing a vertigo/fainting response or the lack of nutrient absorption due to PPI use that created the light headed/fainting episodes? My physician said to stop doing pull ups. I haven’t had an episode in a few years now. I did stop the pull-ups which I miss and backed off the amount of weight I lift. Still on PPIs. Any thoughts? Thank you for any feed back.
26.answer:
Based on your description, there are several potential explanations for your symptoms:

1. Exercise-Induced Syncope:
- The combination of physical exertion (particularly upper body exercises like pull-ups) and the Valsalva maneuver (holding breath while straining) can cause blood pressure changes leading to syncope.

2. Vagal Response:
- Your theory about the vagus nerve is plausible. The hiatal hernia could potentially irritate or compress the vagus nerve, especially during exercises that increase intra-abdominal pressure.
- Pull-ups particularly could exacerbate this due to the position and strain involved.

3. PPI-Related Issues:
- Long-term PPI use can lead to:
  * Magnesium deficiency
  * B12 deficiency
  * Iron deficiency
These deficiencies could contribute to dizziness and fainting episodes.

4. Situational Syncope:
- The specific body position during pull-ups, combined with the hernia and physical strain, might create a "perfect storm" for triggering episodes.

Suggestions:
1. Consider getting tested for nutrient deficiencies if you haven't already
2. Discuss alternative GERD treatments with your doctor
3. If you want to return to pull-ups, consider:
   - Modified versions
   - Gradual progression
   - Working with a physical therapist

The resolution of symptoms after stopping pull-ups suggests a mechanical/positional component rather than a primary neurological or cardiac issue.

This is informational only - please consult with healthcare providers for medical advice.

27.question: I wanted to share my experience with you to maybe get some more information about my situation.For 10 years, I have been experiencing every couple of months sudden deja vu like feeling followed by dissociation. I don’t lose consciousness or memory or have any shaking or stuff like that. The episodes are over in around 20 minutes as the feeling fade away.I’m really curious if the reason is pure anxiety (I have general anxiety disorder) or maybe something else.What makes me think about it is the fact that the episodes are sudden and apparently not related to stress.
27.answer:
Your description suggests a few possibilities that should be discussed with a healthcare provider for proper evaluation. Here are some relevant points to consider:

1. Temporal Lobe Episodes:
- These symptoms can be consistent with temporal lobe seizures/epilepsy
- Déjà vu and dissociation are common features
- Can occur without loss of consciousness or convulsions
- Often brief in duration

2. Anxiety-Related:
- Anxiety can cause dissociative episodes
- Derealization/depersonalization can occur even when not actively feeling anxious
- Can happen suddenly without obvious triggers

3. Panic Attacks:
- Can include dissociative symptoms
- May occur unexpectedly
- Usually include other physical symptoms

Important recommendations:
1. Consult a neurologist for proper evaluation
2. Keep a detailed diary of episodes
3. Note any patterns or triggers
4. Document duration and specific symptoms

This information isn't a diagnosis, and you should discuss these symptoms with a healthcare provider for proper evaluation and treatment.

28.question: Female and Male, age 26 and 27. Female with epilepsy, male no medical diagnosis. Female on Keppra and Lamotrigine.My husband and I lived in a nice little basement suite for 3 years. Wishing a couple months of moving in, I developed epilepsy (unrelated head injury). Because of this I began taking medications. Not that long after I started to get morning sickness (without being pregnant). Every day for 2 years I woke up nauseous and vomited half of those times. It was believed it was my medication as epilepsy meds are pretty rough sometimes. About 6 months after moving in, my husband began waking up with nausea about 50% of the mornings. He has a high stress job and we believed it to be anxiety. In addition to that, we adopted our old cat about a year after moving in. He has a few medical issues and takes medication morning and night. He would vomit 5/7 mornings a week. The vet believed this to be part of his medical issues. All of that lined up until we moved 2 weeks ago. None of us have been sick since. As in, our last bouts of being sick was the day we woke up in our old place and moved. No nausea, no vomiting, not a dry heave in sight. If it was just one of us, it could be psychosomatic. I’d even be willing to believe that if it was both humans. But why the cat too?If it wasn’t the medication, anxiety and cat’s diagnosis, what was happening in that house???TLDR: 2 adults and a cat experienced nausea and vomiting for years, stopped instantly the day we moved.EDIT: Thank you all so much for the answers. It has made me very relieved that we left and we plan to take action. The house is for sale, which is why we moved, so we are going to inform the current owner, the real estate agent as well as the tenants who lived above us. We are also looking at our other options around ensuring this is properly taken care of so no one else gets hurt. I’ll also follow up when it sells to ensure the new owner didn’t get left with the fall out.Thank you all again!
28.answer:
Based on the symptoms described and their immediate resolution upon moving, this strongly suggests there may have been environmental issues in the basement suite, with carbon monoxide (CO) exposure being a leading possibility. Other potential environmental hazards could include:

1. Carbon Monoxide - A colorless, odorless gas that can cause nausea, vomiting, and other symptoms
2. Mold/Fungi - Some types can cause similar symptoms
3. Radon gas - More common in basements
4. Sewer gas leaks
5. Other toxic fumes from nearby materials or systems

The fact that all three occupants (two humans and a cat) experienced similar symptoms that resolved immediately upon leaving suggests an environmental cause rather than individual medical conditions.

Recommendations:
1. Report concerns to the property owner/manager
2. Contact local health department
3. Consider having the property inspected for environmental hazards
4. Document everything in case future legal action is needed
5. Inform current/future tenants of potential risks

The immediate cessation of symptoms for all occupants upon moving strongly indicates there was likely a serious environmental health hazard in that basement suite that should be investigated to protect future occupants.

29.question: 22 M, 150 lb, 5'8", white, myoclonus and "brain zaps" for the last two months. No history of seizures or epilepsy.Two months ago, while taking 10 mg fluoxetine daily, I decided to take some recreational substances. I can't undo this and am sober now so please don't give me too hard a time about this. I consumed 8 beers, 5 grams of kratom powder, and 50 mg of THC. The night before this, I had taken essentially the same combination minus the THC. I felt pretty much fine and fell asleep, maybe a little woozy from all the substances. However, I woke up early in the AM twitching. I didn't feel feverish or seriously unwell, so I didn't go to the doctor (I also don't have a GP right now).The twitching has persisted for the last two months. It's only when I'm sitting or lying down. It's gotten somewhat better over this time, but is worse when I'm tired or have coffee. I also experience the "brain zaps" seen in SSRI discontinuation syndrome. On a bad day, I'll twitch up to once a minute. Over the last two months, I also have seen a general shift away from twitching and toward "brain zaps."I haven't gone into urgent care or set a new appointment with a GP (which would be in, like, 2024) because I read there's no real treatment for the SSRI discontinuation brain zaps, and the twitching doesn't really get in the way that much. But I sort of notice that whenever I twitch I lose focus, which is concerning.Does this sound like something that will continue to slowly go away, or have I given myself epilepsy? My one interpretation is that I probably had mild serotonin syndrome and that combined with abruptly stopping my the fluoxetine could cause my symptoms, and that it'll just go away sooner or later. On the other hand, maybe I had a really severe seizure while I was asleep and now I have given myself epilepsy. I don't know if you can tell, but I will feel really bad if I have permanently disabled myself with drugs, but I guess any way you slice it, these are mild, localized seizures, right?
29.answer:
This situation requires medical attention, even if symptoms are improving. While I can't diagnose you, here are some important points to consider:

1. The combination of substances you took (alcohol, kratom, THC, and fluoxetine) could have potentially triggered serotonin syndrome, but ongoing symptoms for two months would be unusual for acute serotonin syndrome.

2. Myoclonus and brain zaps can be related to:
- SSRI discontinuation
- Medication interactions
- Neurological conditions
- Sleep disorders
- Anxiety

3. It's unlikely you "gave yourself epilepsy" from one incident, as epilepsy typically has different causes and presentations.

You should seek medical attention because:
- Symptoms have persisted for 2 months
- You're experiencing cognitive effects (loss of focus)
- The cause needs to be properly diagnosed
- You need proper monitoring and potentially treatment

While waiting for a GP appointment, consider:
- Urgent care if symptoms worsen
- Avoiding triggers (caffeine, sleep deprivation)
- Documenting frequency and severity of symptoms
- Being completely honest with healthcare providers about substance use

Don't delay seeking care due to shame about substance use - doctors need accurate information to help you properly.

30.question: My little sister, age 12, was diagnosed with epilepsy for the last 1 year. She has been taking necessary medications for its cure and prevention. However, she has been ill for the last few days and we ran a few tests waiting to get reports tomorrow. It's 3am now and she has been acting and moving her body weirdly while sleeping for the last hour, we're suspecting she's having nocturnal epilepsy. Moreover, she has been telling us she feels tremor in her stomach for the past 3 days. It would be really nice if anyone could answer the following questions    What could be the general cause of any epilepsy such as this?    What precautions should we take as a family or her as an individual to ensure a speedy cure or preventions?    What should we do or ensure when she has this during sleeping?    What habits should be changed to reduce risks of serious injuries by epilepsy?
30.answer:
I understand your concern about your sister's condition. Here's some helpful information:

General causes of epilepsy:
1. Genetic factors
2. Head trauma
3. Brain infections
4. Developmental disorders
5. Brain structural abnormalities
6. Fever
7. Sleep deprivation
8. Stress

Precautions for family/individual:
1. Maintain regular medication schedule
2. Ensure adequate sleep
3. Keep a seizure diary
4. Avoid triggers (like flashing lights)
5. Regular medical check-ups
6. Maintain healthy diet
7. Stay hydrated
8. Manage stress levels

During nocturnal seizures:
1. Don't restrain her
2. Turn her onto her side
3. Remove dangerous objects nearby
4. Cushion her head
5. Time the seizure
6. Stay with her until it passes
7. Don't put anything in her mouth
8. Call emergency if seizure lasts >5 minutes

Habits to reduce injury risks:
1. Avoid sleeping on high beds
2. Use padded bed rails
3. Remove sharp objects from bedroom
4. Install carpet instead of hard flooring
5. Avoid swimming alone
6. Take showers instead of baths
7. Wear medical ID bracelet
8. Inform teachers/caregivers

Please consult her doctor about these recent changes in symptoms, as they may need to adjust her treatment plan.

31.question: I had a brain surgery 12 years ago to remove an AVM on the right side of my brain. A few years after the surgery, I was put back on epilepsy meds after I had a seizure. I've had seizures in clusters since then. That's the background, but my question isn't regarding epilepsy.My concern: I tried to get into weightlifting. However, every time I try to use my left shoulder, it just falls over. Same thing goes with left arm exercises- it just starts trembling and becomes useless after about 5 reps. Exercises I cannot do include shoulder presses, lat pulldowns, shoulder presses, dumbbell curls. Shoulder presses and dumbbell curls are the main exercises that show my problem. Even with ten reps of 5 pounds my arm starts falling over and becomes completely useless. I tried this for weeks without any progress. I can do leg exercises completely fine. Further, I have uneven arms and shoulders. I had my neurologist check for scoliosis, which I do not have. She told me my weakness is a result of brain surgery, which I don't know can cause this sort of limitation, especially because it doesn't get in the way of everyday tasks. I only notice it when trying to lift. I did some research, and came across something called hemiparesis. I'm wondering if this could be the issue/result of the brain surgery and is something my doctor didn't consider. If this is the condition, or if it isn't, is there anything I can do to fight this limitation? Could there be some type of treatment I can do to help with this? My information: Male, 22 years old, 5'5,
31.answer:
Based on your description, hemiparesis (weakness on one side of the body) could indeed be a potential explanation for your symptoms, particularly given your history of brain surgery. AVMs and their surgical removal can affect surrounding brain tissue, including areas that control motor function.

Some key points to consider:

1. Your symptoms are consistent with mild hemiparesis:
- One-sided weakness
- More noticeable during strenuous activities
- Affects specific muscle groups
- Trembling and fatigue with repetitive movements

Potential approaches:

1. Physical Therapy:
- Specialized exercises to strengthen affected muscles
- Balance and coordination training
- Progressive resistance training

2. Occupational Therapy:
- Techniques to improve muscle control
- Adaptive strategies for strength training

3. Neurological Rehabilitation:
- Programs specifically designed for brain injury recovery
- May help improve neural pathways

Recommendations:

1. Consult with:
- A physical therapist experienced in neurological conditions
- A sports medicine specialist
- A rehabilitation specialist

2. Consider:
- Starting with very light weights
- Using resistance bands
- Focusing on isometric exercises
- Modified exercise techniques

It would be advisable to get a comprehensive evaluation to determine the exact cause and best treatment approach for your condition.

32.question: I’m a 22 year old female and I have quite a track sheet of medical issues. I’m posting on here because I’m not sure if they are related and I really don’t know which road to go down.I’ve had ruptured ovarian cysts consistently since I was 12. every time I ovulate. I’ve been on birth control since I was 13 because of that. I have insanely painful periods and I know my hormones are out of wack but I’ve never been diagnosed officially with PCOS or endometriosis but I think I could have either one. not sure.I got diagnosed with epilepsy last February after two grand mal seizures on the same day. coincidentally(?) I had just gotten off birth control to try and heal my body naturally. my seizures seem to align with my menstrual cycle. I’m on Keppra and it’s controlling my tonic clonic seizures but I have breakthrough absence seizures 3x a week. originally my first EEG only showed right temporal lobe seizures but my most recent EEG showed right and left temporal lobe and left frontal lobe seizures.while I was in the epilepsy monitoring unit last week for a 7 day EEG during a pretty intense grand mal seizure my heart rate hit 275 bpm. I’ve always felt little heart flutters but this was intense. I have a Holter monitor now, and I was diagnosed with supraventricular tachycardia. I’m getting an ablation next week. the flutters happen after every seizure but sometimes just on their own without seizure activity.can someone please help me connect the dots, or point me in the direction of someone who can help? I’m really up for any suggestions right now because I want to go back to my normal life. thank you!
32.answer:
Your symptoms suggest several possibly interconnected issues that would best be evaluated by a team of specialists working together. Here's a breakdown of potential connections:

1. Hormonal/Reproductive Issues:
- Recurring ovarian cysts
- Painful periods
- Possible PCOS/endometriosis
- Seizures correlating with menstrual cycle (catamenial epilepsy)

2. Neurological Issues:
- Multiple types of seizures
- Multiple brain regions affected

3. Cardiac Issues:
- SVT
- Post-seizure tachycardia

Suggested specialists to consult:
1. Gynecologist/Reproductive Endocrinologist
2. Epileptologist (seizure specialist)
3. Cardiologist
4. Endocrinologist

Consider requesting:
- Comprehensive hormonal panel
- Genetic testing
- MRI with contrast
- Long-term hormone and seizure tracking

The connection between hormones and seizures is well-documented (catamenial epilepsy), and hormonal fluctuations can affect both neurological and cardiac function.

Request that your doctors coordinate care and consider your symptoms holistically rather than treating each condition separately.

Disclaimer: This isn't medical advice. Please discuss with your healthcare providers.

33.question: After standing from a prolonged period of sitting (especially when looking at a screen) I have 'episodes' which include spasms and staring. These occur multiple times a day, and I have had an ambulatory eeg. This has been happening for the last 4 years approximatelyThese came back to show that I don't have epilepsy, however my brain waves slow down and they suspect that I have mild cerebal hypoxia.My question is how bad is mild cerebal hypoxia because when severe, it can be very serious. Does the fact that it happens so frequently flag a matter of concern for my brain or general health?I have researched a little about this, but there's not much on mild cerebal hypoxis nor the frequency at which they occur in my personal case. I will be seeing a cardiology specialist at some point, but the waiting period could be very long.Information about myself: 19 male and have type 1 diabetes (since February 2016). Also I had a blood test in December, with all normal results. Apart from this, I have no other known medical conditions and am in relatively good shape.
33.answer:
Given your situation, here's what you should know about mild cerebral hypoxia:

1. Causes in your case might be related to:
- Postural changes (orthostatic hypotension)
- Extended sitting affecting blood flow
- Possible diabetic autonomic neuropathy
- Screen use affecting breathing patterns

2. Level of concern:
- Mild cerebral hypoxia is less severe than acute/severe cases
- Frequent episodes warrant attention but aren't typically immediately life-threatening
- Regular monitoring is important, especially with Type 1 diabetes

3. Recommended actions while waiting for specialist:
- Take regular breaks from sitting
- Practice deep breathing exercises
- Stand up slowly
- Maintain good blood sugar control
- Stay hydrated
- Consider monitoring blood pressure

4. Seek immediate care if:
- Episodes worsen
- New symptoms develop
- Loss of consciousness occurs
- Vision changes persist

Important: This isn't medical advice. While waiting for your specialist appointment, consider discussing these episodes with your diabetes care team as they might provide interim guidance.

34.question: Currently on no medications, BW is normal other than some minor indication of anemia and malnourishment (low folate, hemotacrit, hemoglobin, vitamin d, sodium) high albumin.Family history of a wide variety of mental health conditions as well as cancer, diabetes, heart disease, and polycistic kidneys.Began approximately 4 years ago. Started having severe headaches with tingling and numbness in the face and limbs as well as weakness. Had motor ticks that were uncontrollable and sometimes painful due to their jerking motion. Had an mri that showed nothing other than white matter. Started having fainting spells that lasted for around 3 months before these dissipated. Visited a cardiologist during these fainting spells and they had determined there was nothing wrong with my heart.
