Had first convulsions during tonsil surgery which the doctors had said were a result of them trying to bring me off of sedation, they ended up having to re-sedate me for a few hours (no memory of this occurrence). The doctors who had done the surgery advised me to visit a neurologist since this would not have happened without a neurological problem present. Visit the neurologist that had diagnosed my migraines and was referred for an EEG. EEG showed normal brain activity and doctors said there were no findings that indicated anything wrong and there was nothing they could do for me. Motor ticks still present. Started having a strange sensation in head which were sometimes, but not always, accompanied by convulsions with loss of consciousness until current times. One of the most recent occurrences was when pulled over by a cop after dark(i was a passenger) and (i’m assuming) the flashing lights caused me to collapse and convulse (i wouldn’t consider this a reaction to stress since I have been pulled over during the daytime and had no issues). These convulsions most frequently occur when under the influence of substances, though they do occur at times when I am sober. Constant fatigue which may be due to anemia, and sleep 12 hours or more each night. Issues with long-term and short-term memory, as well as weakness in the limbs. Also have had gastrointestinal issues which i’m not sure if they are relevant or not: nausea and stomach pain after eating anything. Have had some issues with UTI’s. All doctors I have visited have told me there is nothing wrong and make me feel as if they just believe i’m looking for free pills(or a hypochrondiac) but I am still having these issues so i’m not sure where to go from here. pls help
34.answer:
Based on your symptoms and history, here are some potential considerations and next steps:

1. Consider seeking evaluation for:
- Epilepsy (despite normal EEG, as some types don't always show on routine EEG)
- Conversion disorder/Functional neurological disorder
- Photosensitive seizures
- Chronic fatigue syndrome
- Dysautonomia/POTS (given fainting spells)
- Nutritional deficiencies (given your lab results)

2. Recommended specialists:
- Neurologist (different one for second opinion)
- Epileptologist (seizure specialist)
- Hematologist (for anemia)
- Gastroenterologist (for GI issues)
- Psychiatrist (to rule out/address any mental health components)

3. Suggestions:
- Keep a detailed symptom diary
- Video record episodes if possible
- Get comprehensive blood work
- Consider long-term EEG monitoring
- Request referral to a major medical center/teaching hospital

4. Important:
- Address nutritional deficiencies
- Avoid driving until seizures are controlled
- Identify and avoid triggers
- Consider getting a medical alert bracelet

Always seek emergency care if symptoms become severe or life-threatening.

35.question: Hi all, I don’t know if Im looking in the right place but wanted to get some advice I have these “fits” where for about 10 seconds I can’t control my left side of my body or speak, it usually cause my arm to go up in the air, and my face to scrunch up, I am fully conscious and aware of what is happening during these episodes but I can’t control them, I am able to tell when I am about to have one, they normally happen when I stand up to fast, and jumped unexpectedly, or when I’m very nervous, I have had an EEG and an MRI scan about 4 years ago nothing showed up and no epilepsy was diagnosed either. I am not on any medication or anything, my doctor could not diagnose me and just told me to live a healthy lifestyle. I am just desperate to put in the right direction to try find a diagnosis and a solution as it is so embarrassing and it affects my day to day life. Thank you for your time
35.answer:
I understand your concern about these episodes. While I can't diagnose you, these symptoms sound like they could be related to several conditions that should be evaluated by healthcare professionals:

1. Focal seizures (even with normal EEG)
2. Movement disorders
3. Functional neurological disorder (FND)
4. Transient ischemic attacks (TIAs)
5. Conversion disorder

Given that previous tests were inconclusive, consider:

1. Seeking a second opinion from a neurologist
2. Seeing a movement disorder specialist
3. Keeping a detailed diary of episodes (timing, triggers, duration)
4. Recording an episode on video if possible
5. Getting updated tests as symptoms may have changed in 4 years

Important red flags that warrant immediate medical attention:
- Increasing frequency or severity of episodes
- New symptoms
- Episodes lasting longer than usual

Please consult a healthcare provider for proper evaluation and diagnosis, as this is not a substitute for professional medical advice.

36.question: [21M] epileptic from quemotherapy, and 5 years cancer free.Is there a variation that could allow me to safely take them? For instance "lf you have X specific kind of epilepsy, or if you aren't taking X medication you can take them" Does the dose matter? I have read people say that would have seizures when microdosing but not when doing high doses. How does that work? Thank you so much!
36.answer: I cannot give specific medical advice, especially regarding substances. The safest approach is to consult your neurologist and oncologist to discuss any new treatments. They can evaluate your seizure risk and medication interactions based on your specific medical history and current situation.

37.question: I am 20M (age,sex) and currently on lamotrigine (150mg/day)I was ‘diagnosed ’ with epilepsy over two years ago. (When I was 18) I have never been evaluated for adhd.In the two years I started noticing some attention problem. (Adhd-like symptom).. Being distracted by other things, etc sometimes it could be ‘fixated’ to something even it’s not important and I was Chasing deadlines for assignments etc. I just cannot get my mind off those shits and start procrastinating things that are very important .I tried different methods such as setting my phone’s wall paper to a photo I took, the view of a famous university I’ve been looking forward to admit to. It only worked for a very short period of time. Not until the very last moment then I starts to regret and do whatever I can to complete the assignment/ important things.These behaviors is driving me crazy, also my GPA.I feel very nervous about meeting the conditional offer from the famous university because all of this. I really needed the offer and cannot afford losing it.I spoke to a counselor at my college and she thought, despite she doesn’t think I have adhd, but considering I have epilepsy. Maybe I could seek advice from a doctor, but a specialist consultation can cost a lot…
37.answer:
Your situation sounds challenging, and it's understandable that you're concerned. Here are some important points to consider:

1. Medication Effects:
- Lamotrigine can affect concentration and cognitive function in some people
- These side effects should be discussed with your neurologist

2. Epilepsy and ADHD:
- There is a known connection between epilepsy and attention problems
- Some symptoms can overlap
- It's important to get proper evaluation

3. Immediate Steps:
- Talk to your neurologist about these symptoms
- Consider requesting a referral to a specialist
- Document your symptoms and their impact on your daily life

4. Study Strategies:
- Break tasks into smaller, manageable chunks
- Use timer techniques (like Pomodoro)
- Create a structured study schedule
- Find a study buddy or accountability partner
- Use multiple reminders and alarms

5. University Concerns:
- Contact your university's disability services
- They may provide accommodations
- Be proactive about communicating your challenges

Consider discussing with your primary care physician first, as they might be able to help or provide a more affordable pathway to specialized care.

Remember: Don't self-diagnose. These symptoms could be related to epilepsy, medication, stress, or other factors. Professional medical evaluation is important.

38.question: Hey, so I am male, early 30s, white. Currently taking : Lamictal 400mg Fluoxetine 10mg Omeprazole 40mg Gabapentin 300mg 3x day as needed Vitamin D DX : Bipolar type 2 Social phobia (not sure exactly how my psych phrased it) Anxiety Abdominal epilepsy Acid reflux Tobacco (on/off), marijuana use, almost never drink or use any other drugs. I will do my best to be brief. I have had serious mental health issues since I was a child. First suicide attempt was at 7. Institutionalized at 15 for suicidal ideation, and have had therapy since then. I restarted medications at 21. I have had a lot of bad experiences with medical professionals. Very abusive docs when institutionalized. My last doctor told me to treat my bipolar disorder with a multivitamin. The doctor before prescribed me an anti depressant, had a manic episode, then changed to lamictal 100mg. He also called me a drug seeker because I wanted muscle relaxers to treat a weird medical episode that was causing severe neck pain. This turned out to be abdominal epilepsy. I have used urgent cares on rare occasion to get antibiotics, etc. But I haven't had a pcp since I was 20. How can I find a PCP that is comfortable working with mental health patients? What do I need to have done to get on track? I am aware that I am extremely high risk for suicide, between bipolar, loss of a sibling to suicide, childhood sexual abuse. I feel it's more important than ever to get a grip on my physical health so I can have a long life with my wife and my parents, and live to take care of them in their golden years. Currently see a therapist and a psych for med management. I'm also working with my therapist now to work through my problems with seeking medical care. Any other questions I am happy to ask.
38.answer:
Thank you for sharing your story and being so open about your experiences. It's great that you're taking proactive steps to manage both your mental and physical health. Here are some suggestions for finding a PCP and getting on track:

Finding a PCP:
1. Ask your psychiatrist and therapist for recommendations - they may know doctors who are experienced with mental health patients
2. Contact your insurance company for a list of in-network providers
3. Look for medical practices that specifically advertise integrated or collaborative care
4. Consider calling offices ahead of time to ask about their experience with mental health patients

Getting on track:
1. Start with a complete physical and baseline blood work
2. Get up to date on vaccinations
3. Schedule any age-appropriate screenings
4. Establish regular dental care if you haven't already
5. Consider working with a specialist for your acid reflux/abdominal epilepsy

Questions to ask potential PCPs:
1. Are they comfortable coordinating care with your mental health providers?
2. How do they handle medication interactions?
3. What's their communication style?
4. How do they handle after-hours concerns?

Have you considered using resources like local medical societies or patient advocacy groups to help find provider recommendations?

39.question: My bf is a 33M, 220 lbs, history of epilepsy, high cholesterol, has high blood pressure on occasion, ADD, allergy to augmentin, and kiwi. He takes lamotrigine, phenobarbital, Lamictal. He vapes, never drinks, and smokes marijuana on occasion. He hasn't had a seizure in three years fortunately. He went to the Dr yesterday and his Dr told him his med levels are at a level 2 when they should be at around a 7. Dr showed him that the levels dropped to dangerous levels in three years despite an increase in meds in those years. Any insight in what this could be? He's waiting on more blood tests.
39.answer:
Several factors could potentially explain the drop in medication levels despite increased dosage:

1. Drug metabolism changes:
- Weight changes
- Age-related metabolic changes
- Liver function changes
- Drug interactions with other medications or substances

2. Medication interactions:
- Vaping and marijuana use might affect how the body processes these medications
- Other medications or supplements could interfere with absorption

3. Compliance issues:
- Missing doses
- Timing of doses
- Taking medication with/without food when it matters

4. Absorption problems:
- Gastrointestinal issues
- Changes in diet
- Generic vs. brand name medication changes

It's good that more blood tests are being done. The doctor may want to:
- Check liver function
- Review all current medications and substances
- Evaluate absorption issues
- Consider adjusting medication type or dosage
- Monitor compliance

Keep tracking any symptoms or changes, and ensure all healthcare providers know about all medications and substances being used.

40.question: Age: 21 Sex: Female (But I go by He/Him) Height: 5'3 Weight: 106lbsOver the past few months I've been seeing a psychiatrist and she's put me on numerous pills. The first set of pills were Wellbutrin XL 300mg (One I'd already been taking) Venalafaxine ER 37.5mg, Hydroxyzine HCL 25mg, and Ondansetron 4mg. So far my only "diagnosed" issues are depression and a very severe panic/ anxiety disorder so these were meant to help me avoid panic attacks, mood swings, depression and nausea. However, I also explained that sometimes I smoke weed, she said I should avoid it, but occasionally it'd be fine. Same with Alcohol. So far alcohol has been just fine, but when I did weed It was a horrifying experience for me and my family. My body wouldn't stop shaking, all of my muscles felt tight and for some period of time I couldn't move and my breathing was very forced? I also was hallucinating bad. I kept asking my mom to look at my stomach because there was an air bubble that would travel to my heart and kill me. And I was so afraid I was going to die, but my mom kept assuring me that I was fine and that I was probably just tripping and that I needed to sleep. But I was so scared and didn't want to die alone so I slept in her room. It's been a few weeks since then and I haven't touched anything weed related since. But I still feel... Like ever since then I'm not exactly the same? I've been more suicidal than I've ever been in my life, and my muscles and joints feel bruised and I can barely stand to go grocery shopping my body feels so tired and in pain like I've run a marathon. Like I explained this to my psych and she didn't really seem to care. She's now got me on Oxcarbazepine 150mg that I take 2 times daily, along with everything else I was taking. I still have to take the Venalafaxine, but I'm weaning off of it. But so far I am still anxious, suicidal, and in more pain than I've ever been. And every now and then I'm seeing things like a weird grey cloud with a face in my bedroom or I'll think my hands are turning grey when they aren't.
40.answer:
I understand you're going through a difficult time. Here are some important points to consider:

1. Drug Interactions:
- The combination of antidepressants (Wellbutrin, Venlafaxine) with cannabis can increase the risk of serotonin syndrome and adverse reactions
- These medications can also intensify anxiety and paranoia when combined with THC

2. Your symptoms suggest:
- Possible serotonin syndrome
- Post-traumatic stress from the bad cannabis experience
- Potential medication side effects
- Possible underlying conditions that need attention

Important recommendations:

1. Seek immediate medical attention if you:
- Continue having hallucinations
- Experience worsening suicidal thoughts
- Have severe physical symptoms

2. Consider:
- Getting a second opinion from another psychiatrist
- Requesting a complete medical evaluation
- Being completely honest about all substance use with your healthcare providers

3. For immediate support:
- Contact the National Suicide Prevention Lifeline (988)
- Have someone stay with you if you're feeling unsafe
- Visit the nearest emergency room if symptoms become severe

Don't ignore these symptoms - they're serious and deserve proper medical attention. Your current psychiatrist's response seems inadequate given the severity of your symptoms.

41.question: As a preface, just want to include that I do have a doctor's appointment scheduled for these issues, but just wanted to get other people's opinions to see if I'm overthinking things. 5'10, about average weight, no drug use except nicotine. These symptoms precede any nicotine use, and seem unaffected by it. I have no history of seizures in early childhood, although a lot of the symptoms I list below have affected me since I was about 10. I do seem to have a family history with epilepsy, although I don't know all of the details. A few weeks back, I was reading a book -- and at one point, the author went into detail about Temporal Lobe Epilepsy. Interested by the concept, I looked it up, and found that many of the symptoms seem to line up with what I had called my migraine auras for years. Random tastes or smells, always enjoyable but never lasting for more than 5 seconds. Bursts of euphoria for absolutely no reason, gone within a minute or two. Strong dissociation at times, linked to no negative events, just out of nowhere. I thought this was interesting but didn't investigate it further until I thought about my sleep issues. If I don't sleep well, and attempt to nap later in the day, sleeping is sometimes nearly impossible. I'll instead be essentially semi-conscious, in a dream-like state, seeing random events unfold. When I "wake up" from these, my body feels as if it's buzzing, I feel completely exhausted, and I have no memory of the specific things I saw other than they occurred. I have no idea how long these moments last. And, the last issue, also sleep related and usually occurs again if I'm tired and attempt to nap -- I'll be able to fall asleep, but as I wake up, I'll feel locked-in, similar to sleep paralysis. I feel that same buzzing again, throughout my head and torso, and my head particularly seems to move around quickly. A couple weeks back this resulted in me (luckily, not too painfully) hitting my head against the wall. I only truly remembered that happening the next evening. As far as I remember, I went back to sleep after it happened with no further incidents. Thanks for any advice or opinions you may have :)
41.answer:
Based on your description, it would be very reasonable to discuss these symptoms with a neurologist, as several of them could indeed be consistent with temporal lobe epilepsy (TLE) or other seizure disorders:

1. The sensory phenomena you describe (tastes, smells) could be consistent with simple partial seizures
2. The brief episodes of euphoria could be temporal lobe seizures
3. The dissociative episodes could be seizure activity
4. The "dream-like states" with post-episode confusion and exhaustion could be complex partial seizures
5. The "buzzing" sensation and involuntary movements during sleep could be seizure activity

Some important factors that make this worth investigating:
- Family history of epilepsy
- Symptoms starting in childhood
- Multiple types of episodes
- Connection to sleep/fatigue
- Episodes of altered consciousness
- Post-episode confusion and memory loss

When you see your doctor, try to provide:
- Detailed descriptions of episodes
- Frequency of occurrences
- Any patterns you've noticed
- Family history details
- Timeline of symptoms

They may recommend:
- EEG (possibly including sleep study)
- MRI
- Neurological examination
- Referral to a neurologist

You're definitely not overthinking this - these symptoms warrant professional evaluation.

42.question: Male 31 non smoker 6’1” 250lbs, no history of epilepsy/seizuresI have always had sensitivity to lights while driving, especially at night. Things such as normal car headlights and signals have not caused a problem, however when it’s been raining or wet it causes the lights to be reflected off the pools of water it often disorients me and causes a dizzy feeling. I am in An area where it doesn’t rain now and yesterday had to drive through a tunnel covered with a crazy amount of LED lights, and with them reflecting off the cars I became almost instantly overwhelmingly dizzy and nauseous and had to pull over for 15 minutes for it to stop. I am not sure what is causing it, but I am afraid to drive at night or in certain areas because of this issue.
42.answer:
What you're describing sounds like it could be photosensitivity or light sensitivity (photophobia), which can be related to several conditions:

1. Migraine sensitivity: Even if you don't get headaches, light sensitivity can be a migraine-related symptom

2. Visual stress/Meares-Irlen Syndrome: Sensitivity to certain light patterns and reflections

3. Vestibular issues: Problems with the inner ear system that controls balance

4. Eye conditions such as:
- Astigmatism
- Other refractive errors
- Eye strain
- Dry eyes

Recommendations:

1. See an eye doctor (optometrist or ophthalmologist) for a comprehensive eye exam

2. Consider seeing a neurologist to rule out neurological causes

3. In the meantime:
- Wear polarized sunglasses while driving
- Use anti-glare coating on prescription glasses if you wear them
- Avoid driving at night when possible
- Take regular breaks during night driving
- Keep your windshield clean to reduce glare

These symptoms should be evaluated by a healthcare professional to determine the underlying cause and appropriate treatment options.

43.question: Hello :) 26, male, 5'9, 87kg, Indian, generalised epilepsy for eight years, currently taking lamotrigine; I drink and live in the UK. I've had generalised epilepsy since I was 14, and it hasn't improved. I've had the same neurologist since I was diagnosed, and he told me nothing different to this date. It sucks because the only thing he ever tells me is they don't know the cause. At this age, it's still shit that I'm still not allowed to drive, I have seizures about once a month, and it worries me when I travel abroad or even at work. I would like to see if you guys have any advice, any different opinions or anything else that could help me. Thank you very much :)
43.answer:
Hello! I understand your frustration with living with epilepsy, especially when it impacts daily activities like driving. Here are some suggestions that might help:

1. Consider seeking a second opinion from another neurologist
- Different specialists might have different approaches
- Medical knowledge advances over time

2. Medication management:
- Discuss with your doctor about adjusting your lamotrigine dosage
- Consider exploring other anti-epileptic medications or combinations
- Keep track of when seizures occur to identify patterns

3. Lifestyle modifications:
- Maintain regular sleep schedule
- Manage stress levels
- Consider reducing alcohol consumption as it can interact with medications
- Regular exercise
- Avoid known triggers

4. Safety measures:
- Use medical ID jewelry
- Install seizure detection apps
- Inform colleagues about your condition
- Travel with a companion when possible

5. Support resources:
- Join epilepsy support groups
- Connect with epilepsy organizations in the UK
- Consider counseling to help cope with the emotional aspects

Have you identified any specific triggers for your seizures? Also, have you tried any other medications before lamotrigine?

44.question: 22F, 5’5, 173lb, whitehi there! weird thing happened last night and i’m nervous and hoping someone might have some input for me. i recently started taking prozac (10mg) in conjunction with lamictal (125mg) (which i’ve been on for about 6 weeks) for MDD. i’ve had a huge decrease in appetite which has led to me forgetting to eat a lot. yesterday i ate very little - almost nothing, without realizing. i was smoking weed with my partner and i started to feel really unwell. i have a low tolerance so i didn’t think much of it. i remember telling him i wanted to lay down, and next thing i knew i woke up to him holding me and saying my name over and over. he asked me a bunch of questions about my surroundings and personal information (address, birthday, etc.) to make sure i was aware and coherent. he said i was sitting there, mentioned i wanted to lay down, and then my body stiffened/seized up and i slid down the chair backwards until i was on the floor and he started trying to wake me up. he said in total, i was out for less than a minute, but he was worried i was having a seizure. while i was out, i was having what felt like a short lucid dream where i was rolling down a mountain, if that’s important. when i came back to my senses, i was sweating a lot, and was nauseous. i laid on the floor for a little bit until i felt okay, and then went to bed. today i feel fine.i figured i just fainted bc i hadn’t eaten and i was smoking, but i know serotonin syndrome can cause seizures so i’m just feeling very anxious and wondering if i’m worrying over nothing. i’ve never fainted or had a seizure so i don’t really know what either one feel like.
44.answer:
Based on your description, this sounds more like a vasovagal syncope (fainting) episode rather than a seizure or serotonin syndrome. The combination of:
- Not eating properly
- Smoking cannabis (which can lower blood pressure)
- New medication
likely contributed to this episode.

However, since you're on multiple medications that affect serotonin, you should:
1. Contact your prescribing doctor to report this incident
2. Start eating regular meals
3. Be cautious with cannabis use while adjusting to new medications
4. Monitor for any serotonin syndrome symptoms (confusion, agitation, high fever, heavy sweating, tremors)

While this doesn't seem like a typical seizure or serotonin syndrome episode, it's always better to be safe and have your healthcare provider evaluate the situation, especially with recent medication changes.

Until you can speak with your doctor, make sure to:
- Eat regular meals
- Stay hydrated
- Consider taking a break from cannabis
- Have someone with you when smoking

45.question: Hi. I’m 22F. So 5 years ago I was diagnosed with epilepsy after a full-tonic (like a stereotypical?) seizure having had myoclonic seizures constantly for like 2 years before then. No one took me seriously until the major one. During the diagnosis and since, I was constantly asked to describe what I NOW know are myoclonic seizures, but no one ever said they were. I was on Lamotrigine (around 100mg morning and night) until 2020, then was on Keppra (500mg morning and night). In 2021 I was told that since i hadn’t had a seizure in over 3 years I could stop medication (which wasn’t actually true- I hadn’t had a full on seizure in over 3 years but I still had myoclonic ones when having sleeping problems but no neurologist seemed to understand that they were seizures?). The ECG came back clear but I was too nervous to stop meds but in 2022 I was recommended to stop meds again and the ECG was clear again too, so I did. From May 2022 I was absolutely fine with zero issues at all. Then one night in September, I was only able to sleep 2 hours and had dozens of myoclonic seizures until I had a full on seizure. Completely out of the blue. I was then put on 250mg Keppra morning and night but the new neurologist prescribed Lamotrigine…but only 25mg every morning. I was fine on 500mg Keppra/day but then ran out and hadn’t been told how to make the switch, so I just replaced the meds. In the days right after, I’d have a small myoclonic seizure while trying to fall asleep but I thought I was just trying to adjust. A few days later though, I woke up (after minimum 6 hours of sleep) and had dozens of myoclonic seizures only seconds apart and I spent hours trying to fight off a major seizure. After a few hours break we went to A&E because I was begging for meds I wasn’t prescribed. They just said to take 25mg Lamotrigine at night so I immediately did. When I went to bed the constant myoclonic seizures resumed from midnight until 5-6am. All day/night I thought I’d have to end my life rather than go more days like this. The next few days got gradually better and the pharmacists were horrified I was prescribed so badly. But ever since then, I have been on 100mg Lamotrigine + 1g Keppra morning then 1g Keppra at night and regularly have myoclonic seizures while trying to fall asleep so have to take Clobazam. Sorry for the novel, but why has everything gone so downhill??
45.answer:
I understand your frustration with this complex situation. Here are some potential factors that might explain why things have gotten worse:

1. Abrupt medication changes:
- Switching between medications without proper tapering
- The very low initial Lamotrigine dose (25mg) was likely insufficient
- Stopping Keppra suddenly can trigger seizures

2. Sleep issues:
- Sleep deprivation is a major seizure trigger
- Your seizures seem particularly linked to sleep problems
- This can create a difficult cycle where seizures affect sleep, and poor sleep triggers more seizures

3. Possible mismanagement:
- Lack of recognition of myoclonic seizures as legitimate seizure activity
- Inadequate communication between healthcare providers
- Premature discontinuation of medication despite ongoing symptoms

Recommendations:
1. Find a neurologist who specializes in epilepsy (epileptologist)
2. Keep a detailed seizure diary
3. Maintain consistent sleep patterns
4. Don't make medication changes without medical supervision
5. Consider getting a second opinion

Please continue working with healthcare providers to find the right treatment plan. Consider seeking an epilepsy specialist who better understands your specific type of epilepsy.

46.question: Hi all, yesterday I (20F) went to the beach. I was feeling fine, talking to my family, and then all I remember is laying on my side in the sand with a lot of concerned people around me. Apparently I seized up, fell back into the sand, and was clutching at the air with a pained expression before falling completely unconscious and drooling foam (doing some of my own research, I'm guessing this was a tonic-clonic seizure, as I was "out" for several minutes after the muscle spasms). After waking up, I was unable to tell the medics my age — it was as if I'd forgotten what numbers were, it was scary.I was promptly taken to the nearest ER and spent the rest of the afternoon and early evening doing blood tests, a urine test, an EKG, and a CT scan. So far, everything looks normal. I was given fluids and eventually discharged. Later this week I'll have an MRI done, and I have an unrelated neurologist appointment to follow up about chronic headaches (I will definitely mention the seizure).Since being discharged I've been pretty steady on my feet, just tired and achy in my arms and back. I have some mild tremors in my hands and legs but those predate the seizure. I'm limiting my screen time and will not be driving for a little while. I've also been instructed to lower my dosage of Wellbutrin as it carries a higher seizure risk. I'm staying with my family over the summer, thus I won't be alone if something were to happen at home. My partner is an EMT which gives me more comfort if something were to happen at her place.My first question is: how common is this type of thing? I'd only heard of epilepsy causing seizures before yesterday, and all of my testing so far shows no abnormalities. My second question is: should I wait a while before returning to hobbies like dancing or using my sewing machine? I'm a very careful person but even then, I don't want to endanger myself unnecessarily. Thanks in advance!
46.answer:
I understand you're concerned about your recent seizure experience. While I can't provide medical diagnosis, I can share some general information:

1. Regarding frequency: First-time seizures in young adults can occur for various reasons, including:
- Stress
- Sleep deprivation
- Dehydration
- Medication side effects
- Heat exposure
- Electrolyte imbalances

Not all seizures indicate epilepsy - about 1 in 10 people may experience a seizure in their lifetime.

2. Regarding activities:
It's generally recommended to:
- Wait until cleared by your doctor before resuming potentially risky activities
- Have someone nearby when first returning to activities
- Take frequent breaks
- Stay well-hydrated
- Maintain regular sleep patterns

Important points:
- Follow your doctor's guidance about Wellbutrin dosage
- Keep your upcoming neurology appointment
- Document any symptoms or concerns
- Continue having someone nearby as a precaution

Please consult your healthcare provider for personalized medical advice about returning to specific activities, as they know your full medical history.

47.question: Hello, I am 24 and I was diagnosed with epilepsy around 2 years ago, and prior to this I thought epilepsy was 1) you were born with it, and 2) it was caused due to flashing lights. My epilepsy seemingly comes out of nowhere, it is not caused by ANYTHING. (I don't know my specific weight, this is just for the subreddit rules - I'm the average weight for a UK male) Absolutely nothing seems to triggers my seizures, I have only ever had 1 seizure in public, and that was the first one I ever had. I have been clubs, I have been night clubs, flashing lights do not effect me, they just seemingly occur out of nowhere, and I was hoping someone could give me more information on this kind of thing.
47.answer:
It's a common misconception that epilepsy only develops in childhood or is always triggered by flashing lights. In reality, epilepsy can develop at any age and has many different causes and types. What you're describing sounds like unprovoked seizures, which are quite common.

Some important points about epilepsy:

1. It can develop at any age due to various factors including:
- Head injuries
- Brain infections
- Stroke
- Brain tumors
- Genetic factors
- Sometimes the cause remains unknown (idiopathic epilepsy)

2. Only about 3-5% of people with epilepsy are photosensitive (affected by flashing lights)

3. Seizure triggers can be subtle or hard to identify, such as:
- Stress
- Lack of sleep
- Alcohol consumption
- Missed medications
- Hormonal changes
- Dehydration
- Poor diet

To better understand your specific type of epilepsy, you might want to:
- Keep a detailed seizure diary
- Work with your neurologist to identify any patterns
- Consider getting an EEG if you haven't already
- Discuss different treatment options with your healthcare provider

Remember that everyone's epilepsy is different, and what works for one person may not work for another.

48.question: I am not a doctor, but I know my body and I am no fool. I also try to avoid going to the doctor unless necessary, so I try to make sure I have to go before I do. My doctors tend to mark me up to either being a hypochondriac or having drug seeking behaviour.For example: I have very severe epilepsy, and the Keppra I am on is no longer working; I am having multiple seizures in a row every month along with, almost constant myoclonic jerks in my legs. I asked my doctor to please change me from the Keppra about 6 months ago, when it first started showing signs of no longer working. Last month I had 9 focal-to-generalized seizures without becoming aware between them.In short, pharmaceutical companies tell me to ask my doctor about certain meds, but when I do, they blow me off.Bonus Question: What do you recommend for these seizures? They are almost always triggered by hormones, stress level, and being asleep.Thanks in advance!
48.answer:
Your frustration is understandable, and it's concerning that your medical concerns aren't being taken seriously. Here are some suggestions:

1. Document everything:
- Keep a detailed seizure diary
- Record dates, times, duration, and type of seizures
- Note potential triggers
- Record side effects
- Video record seizures (if possible and safe)

2. Advocate for yourself:
- Bring a family member or friend to appointments
- Get a second opinion from another neurologist
- Consider an epilepsy specialist
- Request your medical records
- Write down your concerns before appointments

3. For hormone-related seizures:
- Consider seeing a neuroendocrinologist
- Track your menstrual cycle (if applicable)
- Discuss catamenial epilepsy with your doctor

Alternative medications to consider discussing with your doctor:
- Lamictal (Lamotrigine)
- Vimpat (Lacosamide)
- Briviact (Brivaracetam)
- Depakote (Valproic Acid)

Non-medication options:
- Vagus Nerve Stimulation (VNS)
- Ketogenic diet (under medical supervision)
- Stress management techniques
- Regular sleep schedule
- Trigger avoidance

Remember: You have the right to quality healthcare and to be heard by your medical providers.

49.question: My partner (28M) used to have over 50 grand mal seizures a month after a car accident. They had their front temporal lobe removed a couple of years ago to reduce them and that seemed to help. I’ve haven’t known him long and we have only been living together for about 4 weeks. He had one grand mal a couple of weeks ago and I made sure to catch him before he fell, laid him on his side, and stayed with him until he came to. I informed his grandmother as well because he lived with her before this and I honestly was scared. Well, today he has had 1 cognitive seizure this morning and now we’re up to four grand mal seizures. His grandmother is telling me this happens sometimes but it’s seriously scaring me. He’s in pain and his family is saying not to call an ambulance because he will lose his license and I know he would hate me for that. I’ve been trying to make sure that he stays hydrated and takes his medicine in the small windows that he’s awake and coherent, but he’s being a jerk to me when he is awake, saying that I’m bothering him and he “doesn’t need any medicine”. I love this person with all my heart and want to get him help, but his family would know more about his condition than I would. I really don’t know what to do. Any advice would be appreciated
49.answer:
This is a serious situation that understandably has you concerned. Here are some important points to consider:

1. Multiple seizures in one day (cluster seizures) can be dangerous and may require medical attention, especially if:
- They last longer than usual
- The person doesn't regain consciousness between seizures
- The person is having trouble breathing
- The seizures are more severe than usual

2. While his family's experience is valuable, their concern about his license shouldn't override his immediate medical needs. Many regions have specific guidelines about driving and seizures, but his health should be the priority.

3. Some practical steps you can take:
- Document the seizures (time, duration, type)
- Contact his neurologist if possible
- Ensure he's in a safe position
- Monitor his breathing
- Keep track of his medication schedule

4. Consider calling emergency services if:
- Seizures last more than 5 minutes
- He has difficulty breathing
- He's injured during a seizure
- He doesn't regain consciousness between seizures
- You notice signs of status epilepticus (continuous seizure activity)

5. His resistance to medication while confused is common after seizures, but medication compliance is crucial.

It would be wise to:
1. Contact his neurologist immediately
2. Discuss with his family about establishing clear guidelines for when to seek emergency care
3. Create an emergency plan together
4. Consider getting medical ID jewelry for him

Remember, protecting his health is more important than his temporary anger about potential consequences.

50.question: gender (male) age (17) can anxiety or stress lead to epilepsy and seizures without being prone to one all your life ?
50.answer:
While anxiety and stress alone typically don't directly cause epilepsy, they can:

1. Trigger seizures in people who are already prone to them
2. Cause non-epileptic seizures (also called psychogenic seizures)

Important points:
- True epilepsy is usually caused by genetic factors or brain injury/trauma
- High stress levels can cause symptoms that may look like seizures but aren't epileptic
- Common stress-related symptoms include:
  - Panic attacks
  - Fainting
  - Muscle twitches
  - Shaking

If you're experiencing concerning symptoms:
1. See a doctor for proper diagnosis
2. Keep track of your symptoms
3. Note potential triggers
4. Don't self-diagnose

It's important to get professional medical evaluation if you're experiencing seizure-like symptoms, as they could be related to various medical conditions that need proper diagnosis and treatment.

51.question: My daughter 13(F).She is 5'6", 120 pounds, white--she's lost 5 pounds in the past 3-4 months and is already quite skinny. She's been complaining about abdominal pain (located 1/2 inch above her belly button and across the whole abdominal area, but has had bouts of localized pain more to the right of her navel) since April and it's worsened in the last 3 months significantly.It's worse after eating and after any activity (including just walking around). She says the pain feels stabbing/throbbing-like. She is not eating much because she does not feel hungry and complains of a feeling like there is a lump in her throat. Today, she had multiple instances of dizziness/lightheadedness and fell down from it.She has an extensive medical history, but her current diagnoses are: Epilepsy (since she was 2, more specifically Abnormal Doose Syndrome) Neurogenic Bladder & Bowel Disorder (not Dysfunctional Elimination Syndrome) Raynauds ADHD Sensory Processing Disorder Neuropathy Temperature Regulation Issues Anhidrosis Generalized Anxiety Insomnia (clinically diagnosed) Additional information on Neurogenic Bladder & Bowel Disorder:She can void on her own, but her bladder is 2x larger than it should be and she was catheterized for 4 years before she figured out how to void on her own. She still does not have proper sensation and VCUG has shown her bladder does not "respond" when full, but she's figured out how to tell and how to make herself void well enough catheterization is no longer necessary.Her colon is also 2x larger than it should be with multiple redundencies, but the placement of them would place scar tissue too close to the rectum and would cause a higher chance of blockages and cause the colon to stretch out again. Her internal sphincters do not work properly (for both bladder and bowel). She is on a high regiment of medications and still only eliminates about every other day.Current Medications: Linzess (290mg/daily) for bowels Lactulose (30mg/twice daily) for bowels    Bisacodyl (5mg every other day and 10mg on the other days) for bowels  MagCalm (magnesium citrate, 4mg/daily) + 32mg/monthly for mini cleanout of bowels (increased to 68mg for full cleanout of bowels)Lamictal (20mg/twice daily) for epilepsyKeppra (1250mg/twice daily) for epilepsyClonidine (5mg/daily) for insomniaDaily vitamin + iron fortification for childrenAll blood work has come back normal so far:CBC Differential with PlateletComp. Metabolic Panel (14)Celiac Test—Negative Sed Rate, WestergrenCMP14+eGFRTSH+Free T4Lipid PanelVitamin D, 25-Hydroxy (this was slightly low) t-Transglutaminase (tTG) IgAt-Transglutaminase (tTG) IgGImmunoglobulin A, Qn, SerumC-Reactive Protein, QuantH. Pylori Test—Negative I know this is a lot of info, but I am open to hearing any ideas. She's in constant pain, it never goes away, just goes from at least a 4 up to 9-10 on the pain scale. No fevers, no vomiting, no nausea.
51.answer:
Given your daughter's complex medical history and current symptoms, here are some considerations that might be worth discussing with her healthcare providers:

1. Possible causes to investigate:
- Gastroparesis (delayed stomach emptying)
- Small Intestinal Bacterial Overgrowth (SIBO)
- Autonomic dysfunction/dysautonomia (given her existing neurological issues)
- Abdominal adhesions from previous procedures
- Chronic intestinal pseudo-obstruction
- Functional abdominal pain syndrome
- Median Arcuate Ligament Syndrome (MALS)

2. Suggested tests to consider:
- Gastric emptying study
- Upper GI series with small bowel follow-through
- Abdominal CT or MRI
- Autonomic function testing
- SIBO breath test
- Endoscopy/colonoscopy
- Doppler ultrasound of mesenteric vessels

3. Immediate concerns:
- The weight loss and dizziness/falling episodes need urgent attention
- The feeling of a lump in throat (globus sensation) should be evaluated
- The combination of pain and reduced intake could lead to malnutrition

Given her neurogenic bowel and bladder issues, there could be additional neurological involvement affecting her digestive system. Consider consulting with:
- Pediatric gastroenterologist
- Pediatric neurologist
- Pain management specialist
- Nutritionist

The symptoms seem to warrant urgent investigation, especially given her weight loss and falling episodes.

52.question: Not sure if this is allowed- (20F/medical MJ patient/white) I've been trying to get this figured out for YEARS now, no one takes me seriously. Does anyone know about temporal lobe epilepsy? For years I've had severe deja vu (I can literally tell what's going to happen before it does) that is accompanied by severe nausea and head tingling/pressure. The pressure is in the occipital lobe and temples, and it never lasts longer than 10 minutes. It'll go on multiple times a day for a week, then disappear for months. I keep logs of what happens during, before and after and how long they last JUST in case. It's not that bad but it really makes me feel like pure shit and like I'm going to die when it happens
52.answer:
This is a valid medical concern and your symptoms are consistent with temporal lobe epilepsy (TLE), particularly what are known as focal aware seizures or auras. Key points about your symptoms:

1. Déjà vu, nausea, and head sensations are common symptoms of temporal lobe seizures
2. The episodic nature (clusters followed by periods of nothing) is typical
3. The short duration (under 10 minutes) is consistent
4. Keeping logs is excellent and will be helpful for medical professionals

Recommendations:
- See a neurologist specifically (not just a general doctor)
- Bring your symptom logs to appointments
- Consider requesting an EEG and MRI
- Continue documenting episodes

These symptoms shouldn't be dismissed. TLE can be subtle but is a real medical condition that often requires treatment. Your proactive approach with logging symptoms is great - keep advocating for yourself with medical professionals.

53.question: I (29F) have been having extremely harsh symptoms lately and am currently undergoing a lot of testing while my doctors try to figure out what is happening. I have been to several doctors and they have different opinions on what’s going on. Because the tests are all coming back inconclusive, I’m hoping this sub can help me.History:I’ve been on antidepressants for over 8 years, my current combination (Wellbutrin & Cymbalta) for over two years without any noticeable side effects. I don’t smoke or do drugs other than the occasional edible. I’m diagnosed with chronic depression and IBS. The consumption of edibles (I’ve tried HHC and THC, to relax and take away pain) seems to worsen my symptoms, even at low doses.Symptoms:Seizures - Started about a month ago, have had maybe one/two per week since. Whether or not they are seizures is debated as my doctors don’t all agree what I have are seizures. One of them called it chorea, another called it focal aware seizures and my psychiatrist says it could be tardive dyskinesia. (I have had a tardive dyskinesia episode once as a reaction to metaclopramide and it didn’t feel at all like this. The uncontrollable movements were restricted to my face and I was perfectly fine mentally.) I have uncontrollable movements all over my body but I’m conscious throughout. The episodes last anywhere from 2 minutes to a half hour. My body feels rigid and the longer it goes on the more I feel like my mind is shattered. I can feel my thought process is impaired during an episode but I’m not unresponsive and can communicate with a lot of effort.Extreme fatigue - I have previously been to doctors because of this (about a year ago). I can sleep for 24 hours straight if no one wakes me up. Doctors suspected narcolepsy but I never actually did the tests because they were too expensive. It was chalked up to my depression.Painful joints - the pain shifts places but the most affected areas are my right hip joint and my hands.Mouth sores - they’re painful and take around a week to heal.Dry chapped lips - this has been happening since I remember, my lips are always dry to the point of pain. For example, if I don’t put on a thick layer of chapstick before bed, I wake up with my lips cracked and bleeding.Low fevers the week before my period - has been going on for about a year. Can’t find an underlying reason for this.Hair loss - something I’ve chalked up to my depression over the years but I now have places where my hair density is really low.Diagnosis - No idea. Rheumatologist says it might be lupus, told me to do blood work the week before my period to coincide with my symptoms worsening.Tests done:EEG - no epileptic activityBrain CT - normalBlood tests all normal, including rheumatoid factor.Haven’t yet done ANA, dsDNA, C3, C4 and a couple other things.Thank you in advance!
53.answer:
Based on your symptoms, it's understandable why doctors are having difficulty pinpointing an exact diagnosis. Here are some observations and suggestions:

1. Possible Autoimmune Connection:
- The combination of joint pain, mouth sores, hair loss, and low-grade fevers does suggest a possible autoimmune condition
- Lupus is a reasonable consideration, which is why your rheumatologist ordered those specific tests
- The ANA test will be particularly important

2. Movement Episodes:
- The disagreement among doctors about whether these are seizures is notable
- Consider getting a referral to a neurologist if you haven't already
- Video recording an episode could be helpful for doctors to better evaluate

3. Medication Considerations:
- The combination of Wellbutrin and Cymbalta could potentially contribute to some symptoms
- Wellbutrin can lower seizure threshold in some people
- Consider discussing this with your psychiatrist

4. Additional Suggestions:
- Keep a detailed symptom diary including:
  * When symptoms occur
  * What makes them better/worse
  * Any potential triggers
  * Correlation with menstrual cycle
- Consider getting evaluated for:
  * Other autoimmune conditions
  * Sleep disorders
  * Vitamin deficiencies (especially B12, D, and Iron)

5. Important Next Steps:
- Complete the ordered autoimmune panels
- Consider stopping cannabis use as it appears to worsen symptoms
- Get a neurological consultation if not already done
- Document episodes (video if possible)

Remember to keep all your doctors informed about what other specialists are saying and testing for.

54.question: I’m 25 with seizures, been seizure free for about 5 years, I’m on 200mg twice a day medication is lamotrigne, I’m a heavy smoker I’m a female I weigh 139lbs I’m 5’6. Can I take shrooms?
54.answer:
I cannot recommend taking shrooms or any illegal substances. More importantly, combining psychedelics with seizure conditions and anticonvulsant medications like Lamotrigine could be dangerous. The interaction between psilocybin and seizure medications is not well studied, and could potentially:

1. Trigger seizures
2. Interact negatively with your medication
3. Create unpredictable effects

Please consult your neurologist about any substances you're considering taking. They can provide medical advice specific to your condition and medication regimen.

If you're interested in alternative treatments, discuss legal options with your healthcare provider.

55.question: I am currently a 27yo (white) male (6ft, 150lb) and starting back when I was early 26yo, I started developing epilepsy—frequent episodes of focal-aware seizures. Around that time, I also experienced a few separate occasions of non-trauma-induced, spontaneous compression fractures that would occur in my sleep (I’d wake up with extreme back pain and unable to move, get out of bed, or walk for awhile).I was subsequently discovered to have numerous fresh compression fractures along my thoracic vertebrae (seven thoracic vertebrae fractured to various degrees—some significantly: 50-70% LOH) along with having low bone density that my doctors described as “osteoporosis” (Z-score -2.4).Since then, over the last year and a half, I have seen many specialists (primary care doctors, neurologist, spine doctors, interventional radiology, and endocrinologist) and have undergone every test possible to investigate why I have low bone density and fragility fractures; but overall, my labs and results come back mostly normal, and no known cause has yet been found.I have a history of being overall healthy, well nourished, and a long-time jogger and physically active. I never smoked or done recreational drugs, and I very rarely drink alcohol or soda. Only medication I have ever been on prior is Lexapro for depression, which I have been taking for past five years. I don’t have any family history of bad bones or epilepsy.Your thoughts?
55.answer:
This is certainly an unusual and complex case, given your age, gender, and overall healthy lifestyle. Here are some thoughts and considerations:

1. Potential connections to explore:
- The temporal relationship between epilepsy onset and bone issues suggests they might be related
- Lexapro (SSRIs) has been associated with increased fracture risk in some studies
- The combination of new-onset epilepsy and bone issues could suggest an underlying metabolic or genetic condition

2. Tests to consider if not already done:
- Vitamin D, calcium, and PTH levels
- Celiac disease screening
- Testosterone levels
- Genetic testing for rare bone disorders
- Complete thyroid panel
- Markers of bone turnover
- 24-hour urinary calcium
- Screening for mastocytosis

3. Other considerations:
- Have you had a bone biopsy?
- Has anyone investigated potential rare genetic syndromes?
- Have your doctors considered the possibility of a paraneoplastic syndrome?

4. Recommendations:
- Consider getting evaluated at a major academic medical center
- Ask about consulting with a metabolic bone specialist
- Consider getting a second opinion from another endocrinologist
- Keep detailed records of all symptoms and their timing

Would you like me to elaborate on any of these points?

56.question: My otherwise healthy son (no known pre-existing conditions other than a deviated septum), 6ft 1, 15M, has been having absent moments for a few months (only recently realised this) but on Monday he had a tonic-clonic seizure. We are yet to get an appointment with a paediatrician but the referral has been made. In 2 weeks time we are due to drive from England to France and will be staying in a fairly remote spot (30 min to nearest hospital). I'm incredibly anxious of the prospect of him having a seizure(s) while we are away, especially as this is completely new to us and we don't have a diagnosis or any treatment options yet.From a medical perspective is cancelling the trip as we start the journey to find out whats going on the right thing to do? Or am I worrying too much? Your constructive opinions/advice would be greatly appreciated.
56.answer:
Your concern is completely understandable. Here are some points to consider:

1. First seizures often lead to medical investigations, but not all people who have one seizure will have another. However, the "absent moments" you've noticed might suggest a pattern of seizure activity.

2. The 30-minute distance to a hospital is longer than ideal but not necessarily prohibitive. Many people with epilepsy live in areas with similar hospital distances.

3. Important considerations for your decision:
- Do you have travel insurance that covers pre-existing conditions?
- Will you have access to emergency services in France?
- Can you communicate effectively with French medical providers if needed?
- Does your son have any triggers identified (lack of sleep, stress, etc.)?

4. If you decide to go:
- Ensure you have travel insurance
- Get a letter from your GP explaining the situation
- Learn basic seizure first aid
- Keep a detailed record of any episodes
- Maintain regular sleep schedule
- Avoid potential triggers

While it would be ideal to have a diagnosis and treatment plan before traveling, this isn't always possible. Consider discussing with your GP for their medical opinion given the specific circumstances.

If the anxiety would significantly impact your ability to enjoy the trip, postponing might be worth considering for peace of mind.

57.question: 22F, white, 5'6 120lbs. Medical diagnoses: Epilepsy, POTS Medications: Lithium(bipolar), Buspirone(anxiety) lamictal(seizure) I had a urinalysis done on December 22 and it showed 25 rbc/ul. (I hadn’t started lithium yet, this was baseline testing). I assumed the blood in urine was likely a kidney stone or something as there were no signs of infection in my urine or blood and I was having some back pain. Figured it was no big deal. My doctor wanted to ensure the blood in my urine was gone so she ordered a repeat urinalysis yesterday and it came back again showing 25 rbc/ul. (I was not on my period either instance) I can’t get a follow up with my doctor for a couple weeks. What will be the likely next steps? Based on my age I know this is likely benign but I can’t find many reasons for blood in urine other than UTI or kidney stones. I currently have no symptoms. I will attach the results in the comments
57.answer:
Persistent microscopic hematuria (blood in urine) can have several causes, and your doctor will likely want to investigate further. Common next steps may include:

1. Imaging studies:
- CT scan or ultrasound of the kidneys and urinary tract
- Looking for stones, tumors, or structural abnormalities

2. Additional urine tests:
- 24-hour urine collection
- Urine cytology to check for abnormal cells

3. Possible referral to specialists:
- Urologist
- Nephrologist (kidney specialist)

Some other potential causes of hematuria include:
- Exercise-induced hematuria
- Medication side effects
- Glomerulonephritis (kidney inflammation)
- Bladder conditions
- Hereditary conditions

Given your age and medical history, it's likely benign, but it's important to identify the cause. Continue monitoring any symptoms and follow up with your doctor as scheduled.

For now, maintain good hydration and note any changes in symptoms or new developments to report to your doctor.

58.question: I'm 19 nonbinary female, 1,53 m high and 66 kg. I got checked for epilepsy when I was 15 (because my aunt has it) but it showed I didn't have any. I was exposed to really bright and fast lights the other day and I started shaking and vomiting, my blood pressure was right like my heart, I felt dizziness, cold and numb. This lasted for like 5 hours I only took some warm tea and ferments (yovis) to help my stomach after all the vomiting. I have problems with my ormons and I take normocis for it. Could it be epilepsy?
58.answer:
While I can't provide a definitive diagnosis (only a healthcare provider can do that), these symptoms could be consistent with photosensitive epilepsy or other light-sensitive conditions. Even if previous tests were negative, epilepsy can develop later in life.

Your symptoms (shaking, vomiting, dizziness, numbness) after exposure to bright, flashing lights could indicate:
1. Photosensitive epilepsy
2. Migraine with aura
3. Vestibular disorder
4. Anxiety response

Important points:
- Previous negative tests don't rule out current epilepsy
- Hormonal changes can affect neurological responses
- Some medications can increase photosensitivity

Recommendations:
1. See a neurologist for evaluation
2. Document any future episodes (timing, triggers, symptoms)
3. Avoid triggering light patterns
4. Mention your hormone issues and medication to your doctor

Please seek medical attention to get properly diagnosed and treated, especially if symptoms recur.

59.question: I am a 34f. Height: 5'7" Weight: Approx. 170lbs. I have a Chiari 1. It has caused a syrinx, roughly the size of a quarter, in the back of my neck. My ears ring 100% of the time, and always have.I have been having frontal lobe seizures, every month, for almost a full decade. They start in Broca's area, are mostly tonic-clonic, and quite often come in clusters. I take meds that help very little, if at all. This past month the ICU had to intubate me because I aspirated on my vomit. I've even ran around outside, naked, once.My husband hasn't been around. He's been in the hospital for his own chronic conditions.I try to keep my head up. Nonetheless, I'm honestly terrified of everything that has been happening.Is my lifespan shortened because of the uncontrolled seizures? Am I a candidate for spinal decompression surgery? Can this surgery possibly control the epilepsy? How much should I worry about SUDEP? What do I do now?
59.answer:
I understand your concerns and fear - you're dealing with multiple serious medical conditions simultaneously, which must be incredibly challenging. While I can provide general information, please remember that specific medical advice should come from your healthcare providers who know your complete medical history.

Key points to address your questions:

1. Regarding life expectancy:
- Uncontrolled seizures can increase health risks
- However, many people with epilepsy live full lifespans with proper management
- Quality of care and seizure control are important factors

2. Chiari decompression surgery:
- You may be a candidate given your symptoms and syrinx
- This decision requires evaluation by a neurosurgeon
- Success rates vary, but many patients see improvement

3. Surgery and epilepsy:
- Decompression surgery might help if seizures are related to Chiari
- However, frontal lobe seizures may need separate treatment
- Consider evaluation for epilepsy surgery if medications aren't effective

4. SUDEP concerns:
- Risk increases with uncontrolled seizures
- Discuss prevention strategies with your neurologist
- Consider safety measures like seizure monitors

Recommended next steps:
1. Consult with a neurosurgeon about decompression surgery
2. See an epileptologist (epilepsy specialist)
3. Consider comprehensive epilepsy center evaluation
4. Discuss medication adjustments with your doctors
5. Implement safety measures at home

Would you like more specific information about any of these aspects?

60.question: i’m currently living with my mom 60F who has had epilepsy for the past 30-ish years. i’ve noticed her memory is declining, especially in the past year or so. it’s not to the point where there could be any sort of formal diagnosis given but it’s starting to concern me. i’ve done some research into the correlation between epilepsy and alzheimer’s (or dementia in general) and from what i’ve gathered the strongest correlation is between focal epilepsy and alzheimer’s due to the damage to the temporal lobe. my mom has tonic-clonic seizures (grand mal) and i’ve been trying to find information on how much her seizures affect the temporal lobe, but i can’t find much and i think that’s partially due to the lack of research. i don’t know who to ask or talk to about this. i don’t want to scare my mom but i’ve scoured google trying to find more information but i can’t seem to find anything. i just have so many questions…is 60 too early to tell? once her memory starts to decline, how long does she have still being lucid? do grand mal seizures damage the temporal lobe in the same way focal seizures do? if that is what’s happening, how do i make her feel loved and comfortable? examples of her memory issues: forgetting what she’s talking about mid sentence (a lot). forgetting the names of people/places/things that she knows well. misplacing/forgetting objects fairly frequently, etc. i don’t except anyone to know all the answers, but any input would be greatly appreciated, thanks.EDIT: i understand with age there’s usually going to be some forgetfulness, but this seems excessive to me. i’m obviously not a professional, just a paranoid daughter, but my father is older and his memory is far better. also, more background: 60F, 5’2, 120lbs, past history of estrogen binding cancer (has had double mastectomy + hysterectomy); she fractured her neck following a seizure in 2017? i’m not sure which vertebre, but she’s made a full recovery. also she’s had her left? hip replaced and currently suffers with nerve pain. on my maternal side, there’s a lot of history of mental illness (including: BP-1 & 2, schizophrenia, OCD, ADHD, major depression, BPD, ASPD, anxiety & panic disorders & some substance abuse - mostly heroin and meth) my mom is only formally diagnosed with clinical depression, and is on medication for both the epilepsy as well as depression. medications include lexapro & lamotrigine (she also briefly was using "speed" which she swears wasn’t meth but there’s a good chance it was)
60.answer:
Your concerns about your mother's memory decline are valid. Here are some key points to consider:

1. Age and Memory:
- While 60 might seem early for significant memory issues, early-onset dementia can occur
- Epilepsy can accelerate cognitive decline
- Long-term use of anti-epileptic medications can also affect memory

2. Seizures and Brain Impact:
- Tonic-clonic seizures can affect multiple brain regions, including the temporal lobe
- Repeated seizures over time can cause cumulative damage
- The temporal lobe is crucial for memory formation

3. Next Steps:
- Schedule a neurological evaluation
- Document memory incidents to share with doctors
- Consider getting a neuropsychological assessment
- Have her depression treatment reviewed, as depression can affect memory

4. Contributing Factors:
- Past substance use
- Family history of mental health issues
- Multiple medical conditions
- Medication interactions

Recommendations:
1. Consult her neurologist about these concerns
2. Keep a detailed log of memory issues
3. Consider involving a geriatric specialist
4. Look into support groups for both of you
5. Focus on creating a structured, supportive environment

Remember: Early intervention is key for managing cognitive decline.

61.question: 43/F, 5', 119lbsSystemic scleroderma, epilepsy, chronic migraines, was tested for MS, results seemed mixed. Some of the specialists felt strongly that I had it, others said I didnt. There were white spots on my brain but maybe that was migraines.When I wake up after not having slept well or not having slept long enough my eyes shake up and down quite a bit. It lasts for a few minutes until I'm up and moving around. Could it be just that my muscles are straining to keep my eyes open while I'm in a state of exhaustion? This has been going on for a few years.Epitol, 200mg/dayTylenol, 1000-2000mg/dayFlexiril a couole of times a dayMirtazapine, 15mg before bed. This one is new, to treat grief/depression that is a result of the death of both my parents in the last two years. Was also havig. Sleep seizures during the depression but they are gone now.Thanks for any input.
61.answer:
The eye movement you're describing sounds like nystagmus, which is involuntary eye movements that can be vertical (up and down) or horizontal (side to side). While fatigue can exacerbate nystagmus, its presence could be related to several aspects of your medical history:

1. Possible causes:
- Multiple Sclerosis (even if not definitively diagnosed)
- Epilepsy
- Medication side effects
- Migraine-related symptoms
- Neurological manifestations of scleroderma

2. Important considerations:
- Morning nystagmus can be worse due to fatigue
- Some medications can contribute to eye movement issues
- The combination of your conditions may be contributing factors

Recommendations:
1. Document when these episodes occur
2. Consider discussing with your neurologist
3. Might need evaluation by a neuro-ophthalmologist
4. Monitor if new medications affect the symptoms

While fatigue can certainly make eye control more difficult, persistent nystagmus should be evaluated by your healthcare provider, especially given your complex medical history.

Is this something you've discussed with your neurologist?

62.question: Bipolar, OCD, TL Epilepsy (I am questioning this, diagnosed with absence seizures but I don’t think this fits) 200mg Topamax 2x daily, 200mg sertraline, 3mg risperidone, 30mg abilify, 1000IU vitamin D, 40mg somac, I was diagnosed with epilepsy when I was around 17-18, but my neurologist just doesn’t really listen to me. He diagnosed me with absence seizures but the problem is I’ve never forgotten a seizure or lost consciousness. Now I’m realising that what he’s called my ‘motor tics’ could be seizures as well. Basically, I have these head jerks where it feels like theres a pulse of electricity in the back of my head usually in the base of my skull on the left side. And my head jerks back and I make a grunting sound, sometimes I jerk back twice. This has been happening for about 10 years but it gets worse when I’m off my meds. But the past week I haven’t really been sleeping and I’ve had the flu and I’ve been unable to twitch and it’s like the feeling is building up in the back of my head and its getting really uncomfortable and making it sometimes hard to breathe. Sometimes painful. The feeling is completely involuntary, kind of like a sneeze, and it feels like when you can’t sneeze. What should I do? My neurologist doesn’t listen to me. I have a GP appointment in 2 days, should I talk to her about it?
62.answer:
Yes, you should definitely discuss these symptoms with your GP. Given that your neurologist isn't listening to your concerns, it's important to seek a second opinion. Here's why:

1. Your symptoms don't match typical absence seizures, which usually involve brief periods of unconsciousness/unawareness

2. The symptoms you describe (head jerks, electrical sensations, grunting) could be consistent with:
- Myoclonic seizures
- Simple partial seizures
- Cervicogenic headaches
- Tic disorders
- Dystonia

When you see your GP:
1. Describe your symptoms in detail
2. Explain the timeline and progression
3. Mention how the symptoms relate to medication and stress
4. Express your concerns about the current diagnosis
5. Ask about getting a referral to a different neurologist for a second opinion

In the meantime:
- Keep a detailed diary of your symptoms
- Note any triggers (lack of sleep, stress, illness)
- Take your medications as prescribed
- Try to maintain good sleep habits
- Avoid known triggers

The building pressure sensation you're experiencing could be serious, so it's important to get proper medical attention and an accurate diagnosis.

63.question: 25 female, overweight, no smoking, on Jardiance, insulin, Copaxone generic. I feel exhausted all day, doesn't matter how much I sleep. I've been asleep for most of the past 3 days. All of my body hurts and even moving my arm is tiring and painful. I find speaking equally exhausting, too, like, I can't even explain. Using my voice is exhausting, too.I have diabetes, multiple sclerosis, epilepsy, digestive stuff and as of new, undiagnosed liver problems. Have an electromyography and heart tests coming.I can't stay sitting. I need to lie down all the time.Had an overdose couple days ago, if that matters.
63.answer:
This situation requires immediate medical attention. The symptoms you're describing could be related to several factors:

1. Recent overdose - This could be causing ongoing effects and needs medical follow-up
2. Medication interactions
3. MS flare-up
4. Diabetes complications
5. Liver issues
6. Post-overdose complications

Please seek emergency medical care immediately because:
- Extreme fatigue combined with pain
- Recent overdose history
- Multiple chronic conditions
- Inability to maintain normal daily activities
- Potential medication complications

Until you can get medical help:
- Monitor blood sugar levels
- Stay hydrated
- Have someone stay with you if possible
- Keep track of symptoms
- Bring current medication list to doctor

Don't delay seeking medical attention as this could be serious, especially considering your recent overdose and complex medical history.

64.question: Age 35, Sex F, Height 5’2”, Weight 135Trying to keep this short and sweet, but can provide infinite additional information/context if requested. I am in good health aside from the growing list of neurological issues I’ve been having after finding a raging enlarged right hilar lymph node this past February. Needle biopsy was negative.I am hanging out on the hospital bed, chillaxing watching tv… and after a few minutes of some kinda medium-mild pain at the top of my spine/base of skull, the following sequence lasted about 2-3 min start to finish, but repeated every few minutes for about an hour:-Right eye involuntarily closes/flutters (~30 seconds) immediately followed by…-Strange ‘out of body/near syncope/like the power is flickering in my brain’ feeling, strong for ~30 seconds, then continues in very brief intermittent waves, immediately followed by…-right leg spasms/shakes/jerks around for ~30 seconds, immediately followed by…-both hands very tingly….And once the tingling fully fades, I feel normal for not very many minutes and the cycle repeats.I could talk/interact during all this except the mini out of body type feeling times. After several repetitions, I began to have right sided facial twitching/numbness along with the eye closing. My speech was affected, I guess because of numbness? Also, I could not lift up either leg as the nurse pressed down until the full end of the cycle. All steps of the cycle grew longer and more intense as the hour stretched on, then resolved somewhat suddenly.Right as all this was wrapping up, the attending neurologist stepped in and without asking any questions or seeing any of this himself, told me not to worry, everything was fine, the eeg looked normal, and started asking if I was anxious or upset about anything. I said no, but what did he think all that was. He says the eeg was normal, therefore it was a psychogenic seizure, not a real one, and I should be happy. I told him that it didn’t really seem like any kind of seizure I’ve ever experienced/heard about, epileptic or not, it seemed like something else entirely and maybe we should try to figure out what? Then he said something about I should mention it to the daytime Dr tomorrow and maybe they could do something on an outpatient basis, but don’t bother him again tonight and if I need anything else, like anxiety medication, ask the nurse. So uh… yeah.Thoughts? Feelings? I briefly caught part of it on video, but have no idea how to post that here.I greatly appreciate any input.
64.answer:
Based on the symptoms you've described, this seems like a complex neurological event that warrants thorough investigation. The sequential pattern and combination of symptoms (eye involvement, altered consciousness, limb movements, tingling, and speech effects) could be consistent with several neurological conditions:

1. Focal seizures with impaired awareness
2. Complex migraine variants
3. Brainstem or cervical spine involvement
4. TIA-like episodes
5. Autonomic dysfunction

The dismissive response from the attending neurologist is concerning, especially given:
- The clear pattern and progression of symptoms
- The objective neurological findings (weakness during testing)
- The involvement of multiple neurological systems
- The history of enlarged lymph node

Recommendations:
1. Document episodes (video when possible)
2. Keep a detailed symptom diary
3. Seek a second neurological opinion
4. Consider requesting:
   - MRI brain/spine with contrast
   - Extended EEG monitoring
   - Autonomic testing
   - Comprehensive blood work

Have you had any similar episodes before or other neurological symptoms?

65.question: We have been working with a neurologist about my son. He’s had tremors since he was a baby, but we were always told he would grow out of them. He did have an actual seizure once, but after a 4 hour EEG, they said his brain activity did not look like epilepsy. Lately, he has been closing his eyes and shaking his head, almost like he ate something super sour. Is that normal? What could it be? Teething? Mini seizure?
65.answer:
Those head-shaking movements could be several things, and it's important to discuss these new symptoms with your neurologist. Some possibilities include:

1. Tics
- Sudden, repetitive movements
- Common in children
- Can include head shaking, eye blinking, facial grimacing
- Often worse with stress or excitement

2. Focal seizures
- Can present differently than typical seizures
- May not show on a standard EEG
- Can include head movements and facial expressions

3. Dystonia
- Involuntary muscle contractions
- Can cause repetitive movements or twisted postures

4. Myoclonus
- Brief, shock-like muscle jerks

Since your son has a history of tremors and one previous seizure, it's best to:
1. Document when these episodes occur
2. Try to video record them
3. Note any triggers or patterns
4. Share this information with your neurologist

The neurologist might recommend:
- Additional testing
- Longer EEG monitoring
- Other diagnostic procedures

This isn't something you should try to diagnose on your own - professional medical evaluation is important.

66.question: Hi everyone. I'm a male in my 30's, was directed by a neurologist to take brain EEG. After looking at the test results my doc told me to speak with an epilepsy specialist, which I m going to next month. This got me worried, so I'd like to ask you to help me interpret the EEG because my doc refused to comment on it before I speak with someone specializing in epilepsy...My symptoms are episodic fatigue, feeling disoriented, concentration and thinking difficulty, sometimes trembling/shivering, a general feeling that's hard to describe but I'd say it's feeling very weird... I can't put it in words... I was never diagnosed with epilepsy before. Please see the EEG result below. I translated it into English with Google Translate as I'm not from an English speaking country. I would appreciate any help. Examination conditions: 19 (9) convexity electrodes, 24-channel PL-EEG bi- and monopolar, at rest, with HV and under flickering light In peace: Above the posterior regions of the brain there is a moderately pronounced, amplitude-unstable, around 10 c/s background activity with individual, slower, interrupting waves and, in some cases, faster-frequency ß-waves, which spreads to the centroparietal and temporal areas and shows incomplete reactivity to attempts to open and close eyelids. Background activity predominates over central and temporal brain areas, frontal low voltage f3 activity. In addition, discontinuous dysrhythmias are displayed regionally left temporal mid-frontotemporal as well as over the front brain regions (maximum T3-F7, F3-FP1) as well as here again and again isolated rudimentary sharp wave complexes. Under flickering light: No activation signs. Under hyperventilation: Slight activation of the regional changes described.
66.answer:
Based on the EEG description provided, here are the key findings:

1. The background activity is:
- Moderately pronounced
- Around 10 cycles per second (normal alpha rhythm)
- Shows some instability in amplitude
- Has incomplete reactivity to eye opening/closing

2. Notable abnormalities include:
- Dysrhythmias (irregular brain wave patterns) in the left temporal and frontotemporal regions
