They last over 10 minutes and she has them up to 10 times a day or even more. She also has them in specific time periods such as 6:30 PM.When we called 911 and sent her to the hospital, she had to keep going back-and-forth and that this has happened five times due to doctors not being able to diagnose her (even though they had witnessed her symptoms). They keep saying things that we are sure that it is not true. Here are the things that they said:“ The episodes that she is having are not seizures.“ “It is probably from depression or some psychological problems.” (my cousin has never suffered from depression or anything like that) The first time that I witnessed one of Fiona‘s episodes in real life was during when we were having a welcoming back party for her. This episode lasted 50 minutes due to the fact that we cannot stand having this back-and-forth situation. It is absolutely heartbreaking and frustrating knowing we could not do anything. It has gone to the point that they have to go to Philadelphia (I assume they have better doctors over there), and they still said that it’s probably due to the medication. She is currently back home and still suffering from this. Again, I’m pretty sure that my cousin is not on any harsh medication whatsoever. All she is actually taking is Tylenol, and it is in moderation. So I am concerned as to if symptoms like this can last this long. In the end I know that this forum is not a place to find a diagnosis, but I hope that I can find an answer here. Just a little piece of assumption of what could she is going through can help my family get through this hard time.
95.answer:
Based on the symptoms described, here are some possibilities to discuss with medical professionals:

1. Functional Neurological Disorder (FND)
- Can cause seizure-like symptoms
- Often triggered by stress or physical events
- Can include multiple neurological symptoms

2. Complex Migraine
- Can include neurological symptoms
- May cause seizure-like episodes
- Light sensitivity is common

3. PNES (Psychogenic Non-Epileptic Seizures)
- Look like seizures but aren't caused by epileptic activity
- Can be triggered by stress or trauma
- Often misdiagnosed initially

Suggestions:
1. Seek a pediatric neurologist specializing in movement disorders
2. Keep a detailed symptom diary
3. Video record episodes for doctors
4. Consider getting a second or third opinion
5. Request comprehensive neurological testing

Important: This is not medical advice, just information to discuss with healthcare providers. The regular timing of episodes (6:30 PM) might be an important clue for doctors to consider.

96.question: Hi there.My husband underwent surgery 2 years ago to remove an encephalocele in his right temporal lobe that was causing seizures. He had no side effects and no seizures, and received permission from his neuro team to begin weaning off meds. He was completely off by March 2021. Last month I woke up to him having a tonic-clonic seizure in his sleep.Today we recieved the results of his MRI."There has been interval surgical repair of right tegmen mastoideum encephalocele, with new small region of encephalomalacia and gliosis in the adjacent right inferior temporal and parahippocampal gyri. Amygdala and hippocampi are otherwise relatively symmetric with normal signal and configuration.No evidence of mass, suspicious enhancement, or epileptogenic focus elsewhere in the brain."Our next appointment with his neurologist is in a week but it feels like a millenia. We are trying to understand so we can prepare ourselves for possible courses of treatment.Is ANY amount of encephalomalacia/gliosis expected following a lesionectomy? Does this result suggest he may just need additional support from pharmaceuticals to control seizures, or are we going to be exploring the possibility of another surgery?  Anything you can offer would help put my mind at ease.Demographics: 34yo male, healthy nonsmoker (6'2, 175lb). Craniosynostosis confirmed (IL11RA variant) and consequently underwent craniofacial reconstructive surgery at age 16. Diagnosed with right temporal lobe epilepsy at age 30. Encephalocele removed from temporal lobe and with medication patient was seizure free for 2 years. July 2021 MRI details new encephalomalacia/glioma near the resection site. Currently on 400mg Vimpat for epilepsy. No other health concerns.
96.answer:
I understand your concern about these MRI findings. Let me help break this down:

1. Post-surgical changes:
- Some degree of encephalomalacia (brain tissue softening) and gliosis (scarring) is actually NORMAL after brain surgery
- These changes are typically expected as part of the healing process

2. The good news from the MRI:
- The amygdala and hippocampi appear normal
- No new masses or obvious epileptogenic foci were found
- The changes appear localized to the surgical area

3. Regarding treatment possibilities:
- The return of seizures after being seizure-free might be related to:
  * Medication withdrawal
  * Natural disease progression
  * Post-surgical changes
- The first approach is usually medication adjustment rather than immediate consideration of surgery

4. Next steps typically include:
- Restarting or adjusting anti-seizure medications
- Regular monitoring
- EEG to assess current brain activity patterns

While waiting for your appointment, know that having one breakthrough seizure doesn't necessarily mean treatment has failed. Many patients achieve good control with medication adjustments.

Would you like me to explain any of these points in more detail?

97.question: 42 F Lamictal, cymbalta, singulair, levothyroxine, Pepcid, ambien 200lbs (significant weight gain in 3 years after injury to cervical spine - unable to run like I used to so I’m confident that is the main reason why) 3-4 drinks per year, past prescription drug use (all prescribed but over used/abused) no addictive medications for almost 2 years besides ambien but now I’m very careful. Quit smoking cigarettes 1 year ago. Use juul 5% nicotine 1-2 pods per day. History: postpartum psychosis, depression, epilepsy, hashimotos, reynauds, allergy induced asthma, thoracic aneurysm, insomnia Last year I made an appointment with a new family doctor due to a move. I was very open and honest about all past health issues and casually asked about my fainting spells. This is an issue that was ongoing since I was 12. After many tests they determined it is epilepsy. It seems to be well controlled now that I’m medicated and I haven’t had an episode/seizure for 10 months. In those months I’ve noticed I started to “feel things I see”. It’s so bizarre and hard to really explain. When I’m really engrossed in a program or movie and I see someone hug, get hurt, temp changes, even sex, I lightly feel the sensation. If I see certain places (like a national geo program) I can smell and feel the environment. I did ask my neurologist about it and she said that she didn’t think it’s a seizure but it’s strange how it started after they are controlled. My question is about synesthesia and if it’s something that is just pseudoscience or if there is concrete evidence on it? Could this be a mental disorder manifesting that will eventually take a downward turn? I have no complaints about the sensations because they are actually pleasant but it does scare me that they aren’t “normal”. Thanks to all the doctors who visit this sub and offer help!
97.answer:
From the information provided, you're describing experiences that align with mirror-sensory synesthesia, which is a real neurological phenomenon, not pseudoscience. Here are key points to consider:

1. Synesthesia is well-documented in scientific literature:
- It involves cross-wiring of sensory or cognitive pathways
- Can be congenital or acquired
- Has been verified through neuroimaging studies

2. Your specific type seems to be mirror-touch/sensory synesthesia:
- Experiencing physical sensations when observing others
- Can include tactile, temperature, and other sensory experiences
- Often includes heightened empathy

3. Relationship to epilepsy:
- Neurological conditions can sometimes trigger synesthetic experiences
- Changes in brain activity/medication might influence sensory processing
- The timing correlation with seizure control is interesting but not necessarily causative

4. Mental health considerations:
- This doesn't appear to indicate a developing mental disorder
- Different from hallucinations or delusions
- Not typically associated with psychiatric deterioration

However, continue monitoring with your healthcare providers and report any concerning changes.

Would you like me to explain more about any of these aspects?

98.question: Hello! I am a 51M and have had left temporal lobe epilepsy my whole life. I weight 130 pounds and I am 5’6”. I recently had an MRI done as I have had increased migraines and headaches. Here are my medications:    Lamotrigine    Topomax    Propranolol    UbrelvyMy MRI report came back and I have noticed new impressions and findings in it. I was wondering if someone could alleviate some anxiety and explain what these things mean. Specifically, the “Brain” and “Impression” portions of the report.Thank you very much in advance. COMPARISON: MRI brain dated 12/05/2018   TECHNIQUE: Multiplanar, multisequence images were obtained of the brain without administration of intravenous contrast.    FINDINGS:   HEMORRHAGE: No acute parenchymal, subarachnoid or extra-axial hemorrhage.    DWI: No evidence of acute or early subacute infarction.    BRAIN: No mass effect or edema. No significant atrophy or chronic microvascular ischemic changes. Few punctate foci of T2/FLAIR white matter signal abnormality on the right.    VENTRICLES: Unremarkable. No hydrocephalus.    CALVARIUM: Unremarkable.    PARANASAL SINUSES: Unremarkable.    MASTOID AIR CELLS: Unremarkable.    OTHER FINDINGS: None.    IMPRESSION:   Few punctate foci of T2/FLAIR white matter signal abnormality on the right which may be related to microvascular ischemic change with demyelinating disease not excluded.
98.answer:
Let me help explain your MRI findings in simpler terms:

The key findings in your report are:

1. Brain section:
- No concerning mass or swelling
- No significant brain tissue loss (atrophy)
- No major evidence of blood vessel-related damage
- They found a few very small spots (punctate foci) of abnormal signal in the white matter on the right side of your brain

2. Impression:
- These small spots could be due to either:
  a) Minor blood vessel-related changes (microvascular ischemic change), or
  b) Demyelinating disease (conditions where the protective coating of nerve fibers is damaged)

The good news is:
- No bleeding
- No stroke
- No tumors
- No hydrocephalus (fluid buildup)
- Overall, these findings are relatively mild

These findings are not uncommon for someone with a history of epilepsy and migraines. However, it would be best to discuss these results with your neurologist, who can:
1. Put these findings in context with your specific medical history
2. Determine if any changes to your treatment plan are needed
3. Explain whether these findings might be related to your increased migraines

Would you like me to explain any specific part in more detail?

99.question: 23M, 6’5 and wondering if liquid nytol is okay to use with a very mild form of epilepsy (no seizures) that is triggered by light.On no other medications but have ADHD and anxiety and can’t sleep anymore
99.answer:
While I understand your sleep concerns, I cannot provide specific medical advice about mixing Nytol with epilepsy, as this requires professional medical judgment. However, I can share some important considerations:

1. Always consult your doctor before taking any sleep medications, especially with epilepsy, ADHD, and anxiety
2. Some antihistamines (like in Nytol) can interact with neurological conditions
3. Non-medical alternatives for better sleep include:
- Consistent sleep schedule
- Dark, cool bedroom
- No screens before bed
- Regular exercise (not close to bedtime)
- Relaxation techniques
- Limited caffeine
- Blue light filtering glasses for light sensitivity

Please speak with your healthcare provider about:
- Your sleep difficulties
- Safe medication options
- Possible connections between your conditions and sleep problems
- Professional sleep assessment if needed

100.question: 50F in Australia, on carbimazole and levetiracetam for Graves’ and epilepsy, respectively. FOOSH injury of the wrist.I tripped over some uneven pavement while running last night and fell on my hands. I got some road rash on one hand, and both instantly went numb. As the numbness wore off, one had was fine, but the other has pain. It hurts to grip things, and most of the pain is near the base of my thumb. Some pain radiates down the inside of my wrist. It’s not horribly painful but was enough to disrupt my sleep a lot last night, because I couldn’t find a comfortable position for my wrist. It also sent a shooting pain when I tried to use my thumb to press the button on my electric toothbrush.I’ve called a local medical centre, and their radiology office is closed for the weekend. They recommended going to the ED if I want an X-ray, but I’m not convinced it’s that urgent. It’s Saturday here now. Is it ok to wait for Monday, or is there any reason I should get it imaged right away?Here’s the damage to the palm of my hand.
100.answer:
Given your symptoms - pain near the thumb base, difficulty gripping, shooting pain with thumb movement, and sleep disruption - it would be prudent to get this evaluated sooner rather than later. While it might not be an emergency, there are several reasons to consider getting it checked this weekend:

1. Scaphoid fractures (a common wrist bone injury from FOOSH) can be difficult to detect early and may worsen if untreated
2. Your medications might affect bone health
3. Early treatment generally leads to better outcomes with wrist injuries
4. Proper immobilization (if needed) shouldn't be delayed

If ED wait times are long, you could try:
- Using a wrist splint
- Applying ice
- Keeping the wrist elevated
- Taking appropriate pain relief

However, if pain worsens or you develop numbness/tingling, seek immediate care. Would you like more specific information about any of these points?

101.question: Epilepsy and lamictal 44 year old female. 215 pounds. Non smoker. Epilepsy. I’ve been diagnosed with epilepsy, juvenile myoclonic epilepsy, since my early 20’s. I would have one maybe a year or so. I started lamictal xr 200mg. First time on meds. Things got better but I still had them. Fast forward to 2019 October I had three in one month. I had my blood levels checked by pcp and neuro. At that point I was on lamictal xr 400mg. My levels have always been around 9ish. These 3 were checked the same time of day. 8/29/19 7.1 10/31/19 6.3 After I changed to newer bottles it was 11/22/19 9.2 These levels were checked because I pushed it. I had this history of always having these pinching headaches in the morning only. I addressed it with my regular neuro that was self pay, 2 others that were through my insurance. All shrugged their shoulders and said it’s fine. When I saw that the 10/31 dropped to 6.3 I for fun decided to start my lamictal bottles that had a later expiration date. The ones I was taking were expiring in 6 months so I went to ones that expiring in 2 years from them. The second opinion neuro said they are actually still good 6 months after expiry. I’m doing better after I changed my bottles out. My regular neuro said that even though expiry date has not passed and that it was older bottles to toss all those and use the newer ones. He used to write double dosage due to saving money so I had a bunch. He had wanted me to increase to 600mg xr but I didn’t because I was scared of making things worse. In April 2020 I finally did and I was in heaven. Morning headaches went away and I was so happy. My neuro shrugged his shoulders and said ok. I thought I was in the clear but I had one in October 2020 most likely due to my recklessly getting less sleep and being under marital stress. I thought great it’s been a year and due to my issues I won’t let it happen again. Now fast forward to June 2021 I had another one. I’m back to bad sleep and marital stress again. I have not had my levels checked but now after that seizure I’m starting to have headaches in the morning. Maybe it’s because I’m stressed again of it happening again maybe because my problems In life haven’t gotten better. My current meds expire a year from now. August 2022. My neuro had explained back then that even though when they were 6 months from expiry it’s possible that there is a somewhat of a decrease in the lamictal that for me it’s pushed me to the edge of it not being as effective for me. So basically my thoughts are is it possible I need to throw out the ones that are one year from expiry? My new ones are June 2023 and I haven’t started those yet. At the nov 2019 visit he first said maybe it’s time of day or fluke but when I told him what I did with newer bottles he then seemed to think the 6 months from expiry were ones that I should throw out even though technically they should be still ok to use. He said let’s say they were manufactured 5 years from expiry that the effectiveness for me is not as good anymore compared to the newer bottles. I haven’t contacted my neuro yet but will be this week. Will see if he’s changed his thoughts on that and maybe he will say one year should be ok and maybe it’s a me thing and nothing to do with my meds. To save money I was trying to finish the ones that expire next year but I would throw those out if a doc thought I should and start new ones. Also odd question. I take xr600 mg a day. Three 200mg pills a day. The new ones will be two xr300mg a day. Would this have any effect blood levels because they are xr and the coating melts at different rate. If they weren’t xr I wouldn’t be asking this question. I haven’t swapped them out to see if the headaches will go away because I was thinking I shouldn’t change the way the dosage is delivered. I just think it was odd. I have 3 seizures in one month and levels dropped. I change to newer bottles and levels go back up again. Also when I started the 600mg dose last year my levels were checked once and they were 12. After this long post my question is should I throw the ones out that expire next year? I won’t be able to get my levels checked anytime soon to see if they have dropped. If you’ve made it this far thanks for reading. Edit the bottles were stored in my dresser. And they were in original manufacture bottle from galxosmithklein gsk
101.answer:
Based on your detailed history, here are the key points to consider:

1. Medication Expiration:
- While medications don't immediately become ineffective after expiration, their potency can gradually decrease
- Your history suggests sensitivity to even slight variations in medication effectiveness
- The pattern you observed with blood levels increasing after switching to newer bottles is noteworthy

2. Contributing Factors to Seizures:
- Sleep deprivation
- Stress
- Potentially reduced medication effectiveness

3. Regarding Your Questions:

About the current medication expiring in August 2022:
- Given your history of sensitivity and previous experiences, it might be prudent to switch to the newer bottles (expiring June 2023)
- The return of morning headaches could be an early warning sign

Regarding XR 600mg (3x200mg) vs 2x300mg:
- Different release patterns could theoretically affect blood levels
- Best to consult your neurologist about this specific change
- If changing, monitor closely for any changes in effectiveness

Recommendations:
1. Switch to the newer medication
2. Maintain consistent sleep patterns
3. Document any changes in symptoms
4. Work with your neurologist on stress management strategies
5. Consider regular blood level monitoring

Always consult with your neurologist before making any medication changes.

102.question: My friend's brother just had a baby several days ago. The mom is in her mid 30s, third time mom, healthy. They have 2 completely healthy kids. The pregnancy was good, although the baby was born about a week after due date. The mom was in hospital during that period as she had contractions periodically but they said there wasn't a need to induce her. She delivered a (seemingly) healthy girl on june 27th (due date was june 19th).While she was in hospital, everything seemed great. When my friend and her brother went to pick the mom and baby up from the hospital yesterday, the baby had a mild seizure while the nurses were doing the final check-up. However, it was dismissed and the baby was allowed to go.Just mere hours after the baby got home, she had two more seizures in the span of 3 hours. The first was around 5pm and the second was around 8pm, after which they took the baby to the hospital. They ran some tests and decided to keep her for the night. She had another seizure in the morning, a stronger one, and it was witnessed by a doctor. The doctor was pretty concerned and ordered some other tests. The brain scan and reflexes were good, brain activity was good. They decided to keep her anyway, just to keep an eye on her. The baby was finally seen by a neurologist this afternoon. The neurologist is an older woman, they say she's very experienced in neonatal care. She basically said that it's nothing, that it happens all the time, that the mom was probably hungry, cold and/or scared so she was shaking during delivery which somehow transfered the shakiness to the baby and it manifested as a seizure (3 days later?). Now, I'm absolutely NOT a doctor, much less an experienced neurologist, but this honestly smells like BS. I also don't have kids and have never given birth. Is this possible? My friend and her family are holding onto what this woman said and I definitely don't want to be skeptical, but I really can't help it. It just sounds so impossible to me and the fact that it happened 3 times in the 24 hours the baby was released just makes me believe that the hospital is trying to save itself from a lawsuit.  Can any doctor, nurse, mother, anyone who had or has heard of a similar experience tell me their opinion? Because I truly wish I could believe it, but I simply don't. Even though the test results are good so far.
102.answer:
You have good reason to be skeptical. While newborn seizures can occur and aren't necessarily indicative of serious problems, the explanation given by the neurologist seems scientifically questionable. Here's why:

1. The timing doesn't make sense - seizures occurring 3 days after birth are unlikely to be related to the mother's state during delivery

2. Multiple seizures within 24 hours is concerning and typically warrants thorough investigation

3. Neonatal seizures can have various causes including:
- Hypoxic-ischemic encephalopathy (lack of oxygen during birth)
- Metabolic problems
- Infections
- Structural brain abnormalities
- Electrolyte imbalances

While it's positive that initial tests are normal, this situation likely warrants:
- Continued monitoring
- Complete metabolic workup
- Possible EEG monitoring
- Further investigation if seizures continue

It would be reasonable for the family to:
1. Seek a second opinion
2. Keep detailed records of any episodes
3. Request copies of all test results
4. Ask for clear explanation of the diagnosis and treatment plan

The family should trust their instincts if they're concerned and shouldn't hesitate to advocate for more thorough evaluation if seizures continue.

103.question: So I'm an 18 yr old Caucasian male (62kg,180cm). Since some months ago, I have constant depersonalization/dereaalization and periods of confusion that really bother me. I went to a neurologist and had an MRI scan(which turned out fine, except for some normal anatomical variants) and I was wondering if my confusion and dpdr can be the result of epilepsy ?(non-convulsive seizures). Thanks!
103.answer:
Depersonalization/derealization (DPDR) can have various causes, and while non-convulsive seizures could potentially be one of them, there are many other more common causes to consider:

Common causes of DPDR:
1. Anxiety disorders
2. Depression
3. Stress/trauma
4. Sleep disorders
5. Substance use
6. Panic attacks

Regarding epilepsy:
- While temporal lobe epilepsy can sometimes cause DPDR-like symptoms, it usually presents with other symptoms
- A normal MRI is reassuring, though it doesn't completely rule out epilepsy
- If you're concerned about seizures, an EEG would be more helpful in diagnosing epilepsy

Recommendations:
1. Consult a psychiatrist/psychologist to evaluate for anxiety/depression
2. Maintain good sleep habits
3. Reduce stress through relaxation techniques
4. Consider discussing with your neurologist about getting an EEG if concerns persist
5. Keep track of when symptoms occur and any potential triggers

Remember: DPDR, while distressing, is often temporary and treatable. Professional help can make a significant difference.

104.question: What would cause a 31 year old Caucasian female w/east European and french-canadian decent who is 5'3 110lbs to have;-Seizures (family history epilepsy, personal history TBI) w/seizure onset being 26.-Chronic low potassium-Chronic borderline and sometimes full anemia-POS ANA 1:320 that had been POS ANA 1:160 for several year but recently has risen-GFR swings on and off from 90 to 70 to as low as 50 in one year and cycling this patten indefinitely-Difficulty w/low glucose however repeat testing and dr deny Diabetic as an option-upon seizure onset new symptoms of small blood clots and bruising. Significant pain in locations followed by relief and brusing in the location.-female doesn't drink (at all) or smoke had been working out regularly last decade until onset of symptoms came with intense fatigue.-Has had 1 child, only complications was significant post birth hemorrhage.-upon seizure onset development of seeing black lines in vision that come and go.-potential stroke upon onset of all above resulting in drop foot right side, eye palsy right side, neuropathy of right side-chronic borderline high MCH-positive Raynauds-Bouts of unprovoked tachycardia with PVC  -aphasia and dysphagia-swelling of joints but negative RA factorTests negative for- -Sjorgens specific -Lupus has been consider however initial workup showed stable c3 and c4 and was dismissed year of all onset. Hasn't had lupus specific retesting since then.Differental offered was MS but cleared on MRIs.
104.answer:
Based on the complex constellation of symptoms and test results provided, several autoimmune or systemic conditions could be considered. Here are some possibilities that should be investigated:

1. Antiphospholipid Syndrome (APS):
- Explains blood clots
- Can cause seizures
- Associated with low platelets
- Can cause strokes
- Often has positive ANA
- Can occur with or without other autoimmune conditions

2. Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE):
- Despite initial negative workup, should be reconsidered due to:
- Rising ANA titers
- Multiple system involvement
- Seizures
- Raynaud's
- Joint involvement
- C3/C4 can be normal in early disease

3. Mixed Connective Tissue Disease:
- Overlapping features of multiple autoimmune conditions
- Can explain many of the symptoms
- Often has positive ANA

4. Vasculitis:
- Could explain neurological symptoms
- Blood vessel inflammation leading to clotting
- Can cause organ dysfunction

Recommendations:
1. Comprehensive rheumatological workup including:
- Anti-dsDNA
- Anti-Smith
- Anti-phospholipid antibodies
- Complete complement panel
- Anti-RNP

2. Hematology consultation for:
- Clotting disorder evaluation
- Anemia workup
- Platelet function studies

3. Regular monitoring of kidney function given GFR fluctuations

4. Neurologist follow-up for seizures and neurological symptoms

The combination of symptoms suggests an underlying systemic autoimmune condition, possibly with overlap features. Continued monitoring and comprehensive evaluation is important.

105.question: My mum (45F, 165cm, 80kg, non drinker, non smoker) moved from India to Australia in 2006. She had her first seizure (tonic-clonic) in 2009 and was diagnosed with Epilepsy which has been reasonably controlled (rarely any tonic-clonic seizures and isolated absent seizures) with Keppara and Trileptal on varying doses over the last 10 years. Her current dose is Trileptal 750mg bd and Keppara 1000mg bd. She also has medications for high blood pressure and high cholesterol. Mum recently went to India for 6 months and after returning, has been dealing with multiple absent seizures a day where she will have a lapse of attention and mental confusion/unable to pay attention. There are also lip smacking and chewing motions also. She has accidentally injured herself during the absent seizures and they seem to occur in periods of stress/anxiety. As a result, the docs are saying there might be a psychological aspect to her epilepsy. She has most of her family overseas so has always dealt with feeling isolated and may be feeling more so since coming back from India. We are getting her in with a pyschologist in the New Year but really want to know if anyone on here can offer any advice on why the medications are no longer controlling the absent seizures and if there might be something we are missing. It has impacted her lifestyle/QoL immensely over the last decade and it is getting worse so if anyone has advice on different ways we can manage this, we would be grateful. Whether it is seeing a different medical specialist, allied health practitioners or things we can implement to ensure her safety. Thank you.
105.answer:
Based on the information provided, here are some potential considerations and suggestions:

1. Medical Management:
- Consider consulting an epileptologist (epilepsy specialist) if not already doing so
- Request EEG monitoring to assess current seizure patterns
- Check medication blood levels to ensure therapeutic ranges
- Consider whether medication adjustments are needed
- Review potential drug interactions with BP and cholesterol medications

2. Potential Triggers to Address:
- Jet lag/sleep disruption from travel
- Stress/anxiety
- Changes in diet/lifestyle between countries
- Time zone differences affecting medication schedule
- Environmental changes (temperature, humidity)

3. Safety Measures:
- Install seizure detection devices
- Use protective equipment during high-risk activities
- Maintain a seizure diary
- Ensure emergency contacts are readily available

4. Additional Support:
- Join epilepsy support groups
- Consider online counseling to connect with Indian-speaking therapists
- Explore community programs for migrants
- Regular video calls with family overseas

5. Lifestyle Modifications:
- Establish consistent sleep schedule
- Regular exercise (under medical guidance)
- Stress management techniques (meditation, yoga)
- Maintain regular meal times
- Stay well-hydrated

Always consult healthcare providers before making any changes to treatment plans.

106.question: Ever since I was a little kid, every few months I get hit with absolutely insatiable vinegar cravings. I will straight up drink it from the bottle and still want more. I also get cravings like this for things that are quite acidic in nature, such as lemons, hot sauce, or tomatoes. As a kid my parents would have to literally cut me off because I would eat so much my lips would turn white, and I’d still want more. I’ll sit down and eat an entire head of lettuce, bundle of celery, full size cucumber, etc with vinegar on it. (Idk if this is important, but I hate apple cider vinegar. My go to is red wine vinegar, but white vinegar or balsamic will also do the trick.) I do imbibe on occasion and have noticed that the last two days after I did get these vinegar cravings, but other than that, I can’t pinpoint any specific triggers.I’m a healthy weight and eat a fairly varied diet, and the only oddities in my bloodwork are low white blood cell counts.I’ve heard that sometimes intense cravings can signal some sort of biological clue for a nutrient that is missing. Could that be something that is going on? I was just curious! This doesn’t really negatively impact my life, it just causes me to get some weird looks sometimes.Details: 23F, 5 ft 3 inches, 130 lbs, Caucasian, acid cravings, existing medical issues (Migraines, IST, mitral and tricuspid valve regurgitation), medications (verapamil and singulair), no drugs, sparingly drink, no smoking.
106.answer:
Your craving for acidic foods and vinegar might be related to a few potential underlying factors:

1. Mineral Deficiencies:
- Iron deficiency (common in women of reproductive age)
- Zinc deficiency
- Potassium deficiency

2. Low Stomach Acid (Hypochlorhydria):
- Some people crave acidic foods when their stomach isn't producing enough acid
- This can affect nutrient absorption

3. PICA:
- A condition where people crave non-food items or unusual food items
- Can be related to nutritional deficiencies

4. Other possibilities:
- Liver function issues
- Blood sugar regulation
- Dehydration
- Electrolyte imbalances

Given your medical history (IST, valve issues) and low WBC count, it would be worth discussing these cravings with your healthcare provider. They might want to:
- Check iron levels
- Review other mineral levels
- Assess stomach acid production
- Look at liver function

While vinegar isn't harmful in moderate amounts, excessive consumption could potentially:
- Erode tooth enamel
- Irritate the digestive system
- Interact with medications
- Affect potassium levels

Consider tracking when these cravings occur to identify any patterns with:
- Menstrual cycle
- Stress levels
- Diet
- Sleep
- Medication timing
- Alcohol consumption

107.question: I’m 19F about 5’3” not sure about my weight but quite small from the UK.So, in the past, I’ve had what I believe to be 3 tonic-clonic seizures. I never actually got medical advice for these because 2 happened after smoking weed and one when my (untrained) friend pierced my nose and I didn’t want my parents to find out about any of these with a trip to the doctors (when they did ever find out they just thought I fainted because it was a hot day etc) These were years ago so I haven’t thought about them much. An hour or so ago my boyfriend was having a normal conversation with me and I started panicking for no reason at all and from past experience felt like I was going to have or had just had a seizure. I got really hot, dizzy, panicky, shaky and just didn’t feel right overall. I felt kind of disconnected if that makes any sense. I thought this might be a focal seizure. A while afterwards though I still didn’t feel normal, I’ve been staring at my room for about 20 minutes just looking around and closed my eyes for 10 minutes with my knees to my chest rocking side to side. I just don’t feel quite normal at the moment and I’m not sure if I could have epilepsy or it could just be my mental health (I have depression, anxiety and occasionally worry I have schizophrenia) but I thought I was doing alright mentally at the moment.Sorry for the long post, as I say it’s my first ever post on Reddit and I’m just very confused about what’s going on at the moment.Any ideas or advice would be great!
107.answer:
Given your history and symptoms, you should definitely seek medical attention. Here's why:

1. Tonic-clonic seizures, regardless of their trigger, are serious medical events that require evaluation
2. The recent episode you described could be:
- A focal seizure
- A panic attack
- Another neurological event
- A combination of physical and mental health symptoms

Professional medical advice is important because:
1. If these are seizures, you need proper diagnosis and treatment
2. Untreated seizures can become more frequent or severe
3. A proper evaluation can help distinguish between neurological and mental health issues

Immediate steps:
1. See your GP for an evaluation
2. Keep a detailed record of these episodes
3. Be honest about your medical history, including past drug use
4. Consider seeing a neurologist

Safety note: Please avoid self-piercing in the future, as it can lead to serious complications.

Until you can see a doctor, ensure you:
- Get enough sleep
- Avoid known triggers
- Have someone with you if you feel an episode coming on
- Don't drive if you're experiencing these symptoms

108.question: Age 33 Sex M Height 5’ 9” Weight 170 Race Caucasian Duration of complaint 3 Weeks Location Distal Tibia/Ankle Any existing relevant medical issues Epilepsy Current medications KeppraI’m about 3 weeks post skateboarding injury and I have this lump on my distal tibia. Seems like it’s off the bone on the medial side. As a skateboarder it’s common to take repetitive shots to the ankle, so I’m not overly concerned. The lump happened to appear after the injury. It wasn’t super painful so I kept on skating after a few more incidents to the same area I decided to take a break. I’m about a week removed from skating and haven’t seen a noticeable improvement. No pain. Just sensitive to the touch. Thanks in advance
108.answer:
Based on the information provided, this sounds like it could be:

1. Post-traumatic soft tissue swelling/hematoma
2. Periosteal reaction (bone's response to repeated trauma)
3. Possible bursal inflammation

Recommendations:

1. RICE protocol (Rest, Ice, Compression, Elevation)
2. Take a break from skating for at least 2-3 weeks to allow proper healing
3. Consider using ankle protection when returning to skating

When to seek medical attention:
1. If the lump continues to grow
2. If pain increases significantly
3. If you develop redness, warmth, or fever
4. If it hasn't improved after 4-6 weeks of rest

Since you have epilepsy and are on Keppra, it's important to ensure your balance isn't affected, which could increase injury risk while skating. Consider mentioning this to your neurologist at your next visit.

The lump is likely benign given the clear trauma history, but if it persists or concerns you, getting an X-ray or medical evaluation would be prudent to rule out any bone involvement.

109.question: Hello, my relative started falling unconscious out of nowhere a year ago. She has been diagnosed with epilepsy due to one shaking seizure. After some time and different pill combinations she is still fainting seemingly randomly but mostly before her period ( she said she noticed fainting every 2 weeks but take it with a grain of salt ). After multiple MR scans and 2 different hospitals in two different towns neurologist said she might have MS and gave her corticosteroids which after about a month they withdrew and said she might not have MS. We are completely lost on what to do and its making her life a living hell as she cant keep a job or/and is dangerous to have one as she hit her head multiple times already. Recently she didnt fall unconscious but sort of lost memory of what she was doing at the moment kind of being on autopilot for a few seconds. Please any help is kindly accepted and feel free to ask away any questions I am happy to answer.Age: 22 Female
109.answer:
This sounds like a complex medical situation that needs careful evaluation. Here are some potential considerations and questions:

1. Have they considered:
- Hormonal influences (given the connection to menstrual cycle)
- POTS (Postural Orthostatic Tachycardia Syndrome)
- Non-epileptic seizures (PNES)
- Vasovagal syncope
- Cardiac issues

2. Has she had:
- EEG monitoring (especially long-term)
- Heart monitoring/ECG
- Blood work to check hormones
- Tilt table test
- Blood pressure monitoring

3. Some questions that might help:
- Does she experience any warning signs before fainting?
- Are there any triggers (standing up, stress, heat)?
- Does she experience heart palpitations?
- Any family history of similar symptoms?
- What medications is she currently taking?

Recommendations:
1. Consider seeing an epileptologist (seizure specialist)
2. Keep a detailed diary of episodes
3. Consider getting evaluated by a cardiologist
4. Might benefit from seeing an endocrinologist

For safety:
- Consider wearing a medical alert device
- Use protective headgear if falls are frequent
- Avoid driving until symptoms are controlled

Would you be able to provide more details about any of these aspects?

110.question: 25F white JME keppra 1gMy epilepsy seems very well controlled with keppra. No complaints.Lately I've been feeling really tired, but I'm getting good sleep. I don't have any signs of seizures when I wake up. It's always been hard to wake up in the mornings, but lately it's been awful. It feels like I didn't sleep at all.I was working today. I closed my eyes to blink, and everything was kinda dizzy, but it went away quick. It's hard to describe, it's kinda like dizziness, but also like everything's... dropping? Melting?It feels like my brain is tripping up just like with a myoclonic jerks, but there's no myclonic jerk. Weird right?I've just been trying to shake it off. I been on keppra for 3 or 4 years. Can it wear off?
110.answer:
Based on your description, here are some important points to consider:

1. Keppra (Levetiracetam) effectiveness:
- While rare, tolerance to antiepileptic medications can develop
- Drug effectiveness can sometimes change over time
- Blood levels should be monitored periodically

2. Your symptoms could be:
- Breakthrough seizure activity
- Side effects from medication
- Sleep-related issues
- A combination of these factors

3. Red flags that need attention:
- New types of symptoms
- Increased fatigue
- Dizziness/visual disturbances
- Changes in consciousness

Recommendations:
1. Contact your neurologist to:
- Discuss these new symptoms
- Check your Keppra levels
- Evaluate if dose adjustment is needed

2. Meanwhile:
- Keep a symptom diary
- Maintain regular sleep schedule
- Don't skip doses
- Avoid triggers (lack of sleep, alcohol, stress)

Please don't ignore these symptoms - while they might be minor, it's better to have them evaluated by your healthcare provider to ensure your epilepsy remains well-controlled.

111.question: Hello, my relative started falling unconscious out of nowhere a year ago. She has been diagnosed with epilepsy due to one shaking seizure. After some time and different pill combinations she is still fainting seemingly randomly but mostly before her period ( she said she noticed fainting every 2 weeks but take it with a grain of salt ). After multiple MR scans and 2 different hospitals in two different towns neurologist said she might have MS and gave her corticosteroids which after about a month they withdrew and said she might not have MS. We are completely lost on what to do and its making her life a living hell as she cant keep a job or/and is dangerous to have one as she hit her head multiple times already. Recently she didnt fall unconscious but sort of lost memory of what she was doing at the moment kind of being on autopilot for a few seconds. Please any help is kindly accepted and feel free to ask away any questions I am happy to answer.Age: 22 Female 5,5 Ft, 160 Lbs Non smoker
111.answer:
This sounds like a complex medical situation that requires careful evaluation. Here are some thoughts and questions:

1. Given the correlation with her menstrual cycle, has she been evaluated by a gynecologist? This could be related to:
- Hormonal fluctuations
- PMDD (Premenstrual Dysphoric Disorder)
- Catamenial epilepsy (seizures related to menstrual cycle)

2. Has she had:
- EEG (both routine and extended monitoring)?
- Tilt table test?
- Heart monitoring (Holter monitor)?
- Blood work to check for:
  * Electrolyte imbalances
  * Thyroid function
  * Blood sugar levels
  * Vitamin deficiencies (especially B12)

3. The "autopilot" episodes sound like possible absence seizures or temporal lobe seizures. These can be different from the more obvious convulsive seizures.

4. Have other conditions been considered such as:
- POTS (Postural Orthostatic Tachycardia Syndrome)
- Vasovagal syncope
- Psychogenic non-epileptic seizures (PNES)

Recommendations:
1. Consider seeing an epileptologist (seizure specialist)
2. Keep a detailed diary of episodes including:
   - Time of day
   - What she was doing
   - Any triggers
   - Relationship to menstrual cycle
   - What she ate/drank
   - Sleep patterns
3. Video recording episodes if possible (safely)
4. Consider wearing a medical alert device

Has she seen any other specialists besides neurologists?

112.question: 28F 5’6” 225lbs non smokerA little less than a month ago, I had two seizures in the span of 24 hours due to postpartum eclampsia. I have never had a seizure before, and from what I understand, I shouldn’t have one again because it was due to the high blood pressure caused by the eclampsia.The neurologist at the hospital put me on Keppra for a month just to be safe and prevent more seizures while my body recovered from the eclampsia. 1000mg twice a day.Well, I am off all blood pressure medications and have stabilized from the eclampsia, and now it’s getting to be time to come off the Keppra and I am worried about what it will be like coming off.I’ve read things about Keppra causing a lot of side effects when you come off it, which is very scary to me seeing as a lot of the day I am alone with my newborn and I cannot be in an unfit state during that time.I don’t think I’m at risk for going off the Keppra triggering a seizure, right? Because it was a one time thing caused by high blood pressure? And my blood pressure is now under control? That’s what scares me the most. Being alone with my newborn and having another seizure because I got off the meds. Should I ween off the meds or have I been in them a short enough time and the fact that I’m not epileptic makes it safe to come off them without risking serious side effects?I am talking with the neurologist I saw at the hospital who prescribed me the Keppra, but he’s been very nonchalant, not really getting back to me, and doesn’t seem to understand my really big concerns because I am alone with a newborn for a lot of the day and I need to be 100% certain that coming off Keppra will not interfere with my ability to care for him.
112.answer:
Based on the information provided, here are some key points to consider:

1. Your seizures were caused by postpartum eclampsia (a temporary condition) and not epilepsy
2. Your blood pressure is now stabilized and you're off blood pressure medications
3. You've only been on Keppra for about a month
4. You have valid concerns about caring for your newborn

Generally, the risk of seizures should be low since:
- The underlying cause (eclampsia) has been treated
- You have no prior history of seizures
- The Keppra was prescribed as a precautionary measure

However, it's still important to:
1. Get clear instructions from your doctor about tapering off
2. Have someone with you when first reducing/stopping the medication if possible
3. Monitor for any concerning symptoms

Since you're not getting adequate responses from the neurologist, consider:
- Consulting your OB/GYN who treated your eclampsia
- Getting a second neurologist opinion
- Having your primary care physician involved

For peace of mind, you might want to arrange for someone to be with you during the first few days of medication changes.

113.question: Prefacing with comorbidities: obese, diabetic, hypertension 75 inches, 300lbs Early March, I had an episode where I felt what was almost like an electric shock in my right hand, followed by a similar sensation on the left side of my head. I fell unconscious, and the next thing I know, the EMTs are at my house. My wife states that I was convulsing, and, at one point, not breathing during the attack. After standard workups, they found a 8mm lesion on my brain. televisit Neurologist told me that it didn't look like cancer and that 'no neurosurgeon is going to operate on this.' Either way, I was scared. Went to a well-reputed hospital, and saw a neuro-oncologist. He felt this was serious, and ordered a functional MRI as well as a Stealth MRI. I was really happy to receive the results that this was not brain cancer, and was in fact vascular in nature (literally, anything but brain cancer, right?). I was referred to a neurosurgeon who deals with things more vascular in nature. He's ordered a diagnostic cerebral angiogram, which I'm getting tomorrow. CTA showed a narrowing of my carotid artery, and he suspects it was a dissection. Either way, I'm simultaneously being treated by a neurologist at the same hospital as the aforementioned neurosurgeons in case this was a seizure (my initial diagnosis). I did not tolerate keppra well (rage), and am now on Vimpat. Almost every night, I have these episodes where I have this 'pit of my stomach' that I recognize as how I felt right before I had my initial attack. Questions: Are these seizures, or could this issue completely vascular in nature? Can a dissection/TIA cause seizures? What about the initial attack? Looking up TIA online, I'm not seeing it presenting in this manner. Will I be on these seizure meds forever (They make me feel awful, with brain fog, etc.)? Did I develop Epilepsy at age 35?
113.answer:
Based on your detailed description, here are some key points to consider:

1. Regarding the initial episode:
- The presentation (electric shock sensation, convulsions, loss of consciousness) is more consistent with a seizure than a typical TIA
- However, vascular events can trigger seizures as a secondary effect

2. About the vascular findings:
- Carotid dissection can indeed cause both TIAs and seizures
- The 8mm lesion could be related to the vascular issue and might have become an epileptogenic focus

3. Concerning your nightly symptoms:
- These could be:
  * Auras (pre-seizure warnings)
  * Anxiety related to the initial event
  * Small vascular events

4. Regarding medication:
- Duration of anticonvulsant therapy would depend on:
  * Whether seizures continue
  * The underlying cause and its treatment
  * Risk factors for recurrence

Given your complex case, you should discuss with your doctors:
1. Results of the cerebral angiogram
2. Whether the lesion could be causing focal seizures
3. The possibility of trying different anticonvulsants with fewer side effects

It's too early to definitively say if this is lifelong epilepsy, as treating the vascular issue might resolve the seizures.

Disclaimer: This is general information and not medical advice. Continue working with your healthcare team for personalized treatment.

114.question: Why does my head feel like it’s slightly shaking when I put my hands on my forehead and press them down into my pillow ? I am 21M, I am 21 and a male, 5’9 roughly in height, I weight roughly 60 KG, I take epilepsy medication called Epilim 6 tablets per day in the morning and the evening, I’m a non smoker, I am white/ Caucasian, I don’t use drugs, my issue is twitching problems, this issue started on the 27th of September and has lasted till this day, it has happened in Leeds the United Kingdom. I have only had absence seizures before which nobody ever noticed, the neurologist that I saw in Poland this summer said it’s very likely that I will only have absence seizures my whole life. 5 days ago I noticed that my leg started slightly twitching, I noticed this physically and I don’t feel it unless I see it, 2-3 days ago I felt my left arm slightly twitching. When I put my head into my pillow in a certain position or against my bed I feel like it’s slightly shaking, other wise I get no other feeling from my head. 5 days ago I started getting small weird twitches in my left upper arm and right leg nowhere else in my body, the doctors that I saw today and yesterday said that Yesterday when I was sleeping I felt that a weird shaking feeling in my body at night but honestly unlike the other feelings this might have not even happened, I’m not sure that it did happen. I saw two doctors about this yesterday and both said it’s probably from stress and the doctor yesterday said it’s the fasciculation of muscle from stress. They booked me in with a neurologist but it might take 3 week. What’s wrong with me ?
114.answer:
Based on your description, several factors could be contributing to these symptoms:

1. Stress and Anxiety
- Stress can cause muscle twitching (fasciculations)
- Anxiety can heighten awareness of normal body sensations
- Both can cause sleep disturbances and muscle tension

2. Medication-Related
- Epilim (Sodium Valproate) can have side effects including tremors
- Changes in medication levels could affect symptoms

3. Fatigue and Sleep Issues
- Lack of proper sleep can cause muscle twitches
- Fatigue can increase neurological symptoms

4. Possible Physical Factors
- Electrolyte imbalances
- Vitamin deficiencies (particularly B12, magnesium)
- Dehydration

Recommendations:
1. Continue taking your medication as prescribed
2. Keep your upcoming neurology appointment
3. Try stress-reduction techniques (meditation, deep breathing)
4. Maintain good sleep hygiene
5. Stay hydrated and maintain a balanced diet

The doctors' assessment of stress-related fasciculations seems reasonable, but it's good that you're getting checked by a neurologist to rule out other causes. If symptoms worsen significantly before your appointment, contact your healthcare provider.

115.question: About a month ago i smoked a little weed with my friends at a pool and when i got out i started feeling extremely light headed so i went to go sit down on a lounge chair next thing i knew i was on the ground everything was completely black and i couldn't see or hear anything all i could feel was my body flopping around uncontrollably and i couldn't stop it. The whole experience only lasted about 15 seconds but it felt like 15 minutes then out of nowhere i was able to stand up and my vision cleared and i was fine if anyone has any experience with or knows why this happened please help me im scared there could be underlying health issues i never knew about (i smoke fairly frequently and it never happened prior to this incident or after any help would be greatly appreciated)Edit: mods removed my first post for not adding this so age and gender 16m weight 132lbs height 6'3 no medical issues aside from psychological and im on no medications
115.answer:
This sounds like it could have been a syncope episode (fainting) possibly combined with a seizure-like event. Several factors might have contributed:

1. Rapid position changes (getting out of pool)
2. Cannabis use (which can affect blood pressure)
3. Possible dehydration/heat
4. Your height (6'3") makes you more susceptible to orthostatic hypotension (blood pressure drops when standing)

Important recommendations:
1. Consult a healthcare provider for proper evaluation
2. Be honest about the cannabis use with medical professionals
3. Consider stopping cannabis use as your brain is still developing at 16
4. Watch for any similar episodes

Note: I'm not providing medical diagnosis, just information. Please seek professional medical attention to rule out any serious conditions.

116.question: Today the mathematics docent in my university, who is approximately 60 years old, froze for some 20 sec leaning on his desk, then his face's right half made something like a smile, and he turned his head slightly rightwards, for some 15 sec, and as we were just realizing something's wrong, he burst out in short unnatural laughter, moving his hands away from the desk, then stiffened and fell back. He hit his head at the board; of course, we called ambulance. I was out to wait for it, but after accounts of my colleagues who stayed with the docent, he was unconscious for 5-7 minutes, foam from his mouth, and as I could myself see, blood had run from within his left ear (the medics who came commented than it could be that he got a skull fracture from the hit in the board rim which is metallic; his skin on the front left of his head where he apparently hit the board was reddish, scratched from the rub; although it appeared to me that he must rather hit the board with the rare of his head). He was desoriented, not sure how much he understood, but he answered negatively when they asked him if he had epilepsy. I read this whole afternoon about strokes and epilepsy but none of the various descriptions seems to match what I witnessed (esp. the disturbing laughter). Some idea?
116.answer:
This sounds like it could have been a focal seizure that progressed to a generalized tonic-clonic seizure, possibly caused by various underlying conditions. The initial symptoms you described (freezing, facial asymmetry, unnatural laughter) are consistent with what's known as a focal onset seizure, which can sometimes involve:

1. Gelastic seizures (seizures characterized by sudden, inappropriate laughter)
2. Focal aware seizures (where consciousness is initially maintained)

The progression to falling, unconsciousness, and convulsions suggests the seizure became generalized (spread to both sides of the brain).

The blood from the ear could indeed be from trauma from the fall, as the doctors suggested.

Given his age and that this was apparently his first seizure, possible underlying causes could include:
- Stroke
- Brain tumor
- Head injury
- Cerebrovascular disease

It's crucial that he receives a full neurological workup to determine the underlying cause, as new-onset seizures in older adults often have a serious underlying cause that requires treatment.

This is all speculative - only his doctors can make a proper diagnosis after appropriate testing and examination.

117.question: So I am a 26 y/o male and I was just diagnosed with epilepsy about a year ago.  went to my current neurologist and he prescribed me Lamotrigine tablets for the seizures. He only prescribed them in 6 month increments and will not renew the prescription until I come in for another appointment. Currently I am on my last month of the prescription and had not scheduled an appointment yet. I tried to renew the prescription through my pharmacy, but the Dr declined the renewal request. I was able to make a last minute appointment for tomorrow but that seems a little wrong of him to do that. What if I was unable to schedule an appointment before my prescription ran out? I know it’s on me to reschedule the appointments but this is potentially life saving medication for me. These are not opiates or amphetamines. I just didn’t know if this was the norm or if the Dr is being unnecessarily difficult. Thank you for any clarification on this.
117.answer:
This practice is actually quite common and standard for many neurological medications, including anticonvulsants like Lamotrigine, for several reasons:

1. Monitoring: Regular check-ups are necessary to:
- Monitor drug effectiveness
- Check for side effects
- Adjust dosage if needed
- Conduct necessary blood tests
- Evaluate overall seizure control

2. Legal/Medical Guidelines: Many physicians are required to see patients regularly to continue prescribing certain medications, even if they're not controlled substances.

3. Standard of Care: Regular follow-up is considered best practice for epilepsy management.

However, most neurologists will:
- Remind patients when follow-up appointments are needed
- Have emergency protocols for patients who are running low on medication
- Provide a short-term bridge prescription if needed

While it may seem strict, this approach helps ensure proper medical care. That said, you could:
- Ask about their policy for emergency situations
- Set up appointment reminders
- Schedule follow-ups well in advance
- Discuss concerns about appointment availability with your doctor

Your frustration is understandable, but this practice is generally meant to protect patient safety rather than being unnecessarily difficult.

118.question: I was recently diagnosed by a neurologist with partial epilepsy. the symptoms I had were burning sensation in the back of my head and neck and my back, memory and concentration problems and tightness inside of my head, I felt it in the beginning in the top of my head back in 2017, and starting from 2018 it transferred to the bottom inside of my head. I got prescribed Zeptol 200mg (Carbamazepine) and one for memory and concentration and another for something else (I'll update this with the other prescriptions, I'm writing this from work because I'm on the verge of quitting). I previously thought that I had a problem with my neck or something that has to do with my spine. I have gone to several neurologists and this is the only one that mentioned partial epilepsy. The previous ones all said it was nothing to worry about. I, today have dementia. I have trouble following courses or job meetings or anything. Sometimes I forget the name of people around me. I should mention as well that I feel something really tight in the bottom back of my head. After some research I found that a part of the brain called hippocampus is the one responsible for short term memory processing. It's been a week and a half using Zeptol (200mg). I started with one a day for a week. Now the second week I increased it to two, just as my neurologist said. I still don't feel the benefit that I wanted, to gain back my short term memory. Is the damage done to my short term memory reversible, or am I gonna be like this for the rest of my life?eventually having Alzheimer in my 30s?
118.answer:
I understand your concerns about your cognitive symptoms and diagnosis. Here are some important points to consider:

1. Medication Response Time:
- Carbamazepine (Zeptol) can take several weeks to reach its full effectiveness
- The dose may need adjustment to find the optimal level for you
- It's important to be patient during this initial treatment period

2. Memory Issues:
- Memory problems can be a symptom of epilepsy itself
- Some memory issues might be temporary and improve with proper treatment
- Anti-epileptic medications can sometimes affect cognition as a side effect

3. Important Considerations:
- Early-onset Alzheimer's is very rare
- What you're experiencing may be related to:
  * Epileptic activity
  * Medication side effects
  * Stress and anxiety
  * Sleep issues
  * Other underlying conditions

Recommendations:
1. Continue working closely with your neurologist
2. Keep a detailed symptom diary
3. Consider getting a second opinion from an epilepsy specialist
4. Don't stop taking medication without medical supervision

It's important to:
- Be patient with the treatment process
- Communicate all concerns with your healthcare provider
- Consider psychological support to help manage anxiety about your condition

Remember: Many people with epilepsy lead normal, productive lives with proper treatment and management.

Please discuss your concerns about memory loss with your neurologist, as they can best evaluate your specific situation and adjust treatment if needed.

119.question: Yet another EDIT: I fainted today on my way to the store and was brought into the hospital. They did a bunch of tests, and realized I was having from 6-10 "silent" seizures a day. I probably had them when I was younger too and they just went away, and came back due to my lack of sleep in the past couple of weeks and anxiety. I honestly didn't even know that was a thing until yesterday, so thank you all. They also did a GI and said that I might have gastroparesis, which would explain pretty much all my symptoms when it comes to weight-loss, and I have an appointment for a gastric emptying study in 2 weeks from now. Thank you all!EDIT: I've called them brain zaps my whole life, but I didn't know that was an actual medical term for something completely different. Its not the withdrawal kinda zaps, it's like a loss of consciousness that I get, but still stay standing up.EDIT 2: No, I don't have an eating disorder. Doctors have no idea why I lost my appetite and can't keep food downSo I really don't know how to explain this without sounding absolutely insane.
119.answer:
This seems to be a follow-up post where someone discovered they were experiencing silent seizures and potentially has gastroparesis. Let's break down the key points:

1. The person fainted and was taken to hospital
2. Tests revealed they were having 6-10 "silent" seizures daily
3. The seizures may have occurred in childhood and returned due to:
   - Lack of sleep
   - Anxiety
4. They were experiencing what they called "brain zaps" (but not the kind associated with medication withdrawal)
5. They've been diagnosed with possible gastroparesis, which would explain:
   - Weight loss
   - Difficulty keeping food down
   - Loss of appetite
6. They have a scheduled gastric emptying study in 2 weeks

This post appears to be an update to a previous discussion where they were trying to understand their symptoms. The discovery of silent seizures and possible gastroparesis seems to have provided some answers to their health concerns.

120.question: Age:18 Sex:F Weight:46 kg Height:1.61 cm So i have had histories of deja vu, it usually doesn’t last long. I don’t have them a lot, sometimes more sometime less. I have a huge fear of brain tumor/epilepsy so i am always looking out for symptoms. I also randomly get dream flashbacks. Sometimes at night, doesn’t happen that often, i get like weird head/body vibrations/buzzing and then i try to go to sleep, i start having nonsense thoughts and i can’t sleep. My ears are buzzing right now and so is my head. My heart sometimes gets on a higher rate and i wake up from this mildly depersonalized. I fear that this mighr turn into a grand mal seizure. I have had no history of seizures before. I am so scared to sleep right now fearing that something might happen. It’s probably about a year that this situation while i am trying to sleep happens. Wold really love to have an EEG bit when i went to the neurologist a year ago he only diagnosed me with anxiety combined with elements of OCD. He did some reflex/eyesight tests and all came back with no neurological deficit. I’d get an EEG but i am literally such a hypochondriac that my parents are concerned and i just went through blood tests and i don’t want to worry them again! If anyone has any idea i’d be so glad :)
120.answer:
Based on the information provided, your symptoms appear to be more consistent with anxiety and possibly sleep-related issues rather than epilepsy or a brain tumor. Here's why:

1. Deja vu is common in the general population and doesn't necessarily indicate a neurological problem
2. The vibrations/buzzing sensation you describe sounds like hypnagogic hallucinations, which are normal experiences that can occur while falling asleep
3. Your symptoms coincide with anxiety and health-related fears
4. A neurologist has already examined you and found no neurological deficits
5. The combination of anxiety and OCD can cause physical symptoms and heightened body awareness

Some suggestions:

1. Practice good sleep hygiene
2. Try relaxation techniques before bed
3. Consider working with a mental health professional to address anxiety and health-related fears
4. Continue regular check-ups with your primary care physician
5. Keep a symptom diary to track patterns

Remember, grand mal seizures typically occur without warning and don't have the gradual onset you're describing. If you're still concerned, discuss these fears with your regular doctor, who can determine if further testing is needed.

The fact that these symptoms have been present for a year without progression to serious neurological events is reassuring.

121.question: 23 AFAB in Canada, 500mg keppra 2x daily, 50mg lamotrigine daily, recently given Tylenol 3’s, Zofran, and torodol to take. Hi all! I’m 23, have endo, PCOS, gastroparesis, and epilepsy. I had my first excision laparoscopy at 17, was on birth control until it gave me a stroke, did the whole Lupron then Orillissa thing for two years until it stopped working, had an IUD until it got embedded into my uterus, and now I’m lucky to be the patient of an excision specialist willing to do a hysterectomy and excision surgery within the next 6-9 months. I’ve done pelvic physiotherapy too, and eat gluten free since it significantly reduces my pain (might be celiac, haven’t been tested). I’m currently having pain way worse than usual and I’m convinced it’s my left ovary (sharp left lower quadrant pain but it radiates to the back, across my abdomen, with some rebound pain but not significant). I went to the ER and they could see some of the ovary, could see that both ovaries had “multiple follicles” (I presume this is my PCOS, unsure how many they mean by multiple) but couldn’t tell if it was torsion or not, gave me IV morphine in a 1L bolus, sent me home with the T3’s and zofran with instructions to come back if it didn’t get better for another U/S and a CT. (Urinalysis and US ruled out urinary concerns, idea behind the CT was to rule out diverticulitis I believe). No pregnancy or STI risk. Ijust went back and saw a doctor who ridiculed me, suggested birth control, wouldn’t let me speak, and said “I guess we can give you morphine, this is the problem with you pain patients”. He also suggested prescribing more narcotics which I repeatedly said I want to rule out torsion instead of being given even more narcotics. He said torsion would make me vomit, but I’m on zofran. My family doctor is off until September, my pelvic physiotherapist is booked until September, I’ll try calling my surgeon tomorrow. But what the hell do I do in the meantime? I’m in excruciating pain and I don’t want to be chewing on codeine. I’m just so frustrated. I’m an active 23 year old grad student, I’m so close to getting rid of these useless organs, but I’m sitting here passing out from pain. My main concern is that my seizure risk increases as I’m in more pain, my second concern is developing a drug dependency. Any advice is welcome.
121.answer:
Given your complex medical history and current situation, here are some suggestions:

1. Documentation and Advocacy:
- Document all your symptoms, including timing and severity
- Keep track of medication usage
- Record any dismissive medical encounters
- Consider bringing an advocate to future ER visits

2. Pain Management (Non-narcotic):
- Ice/heat therapy
- Gentle movement if possible
- Deep breathing exercises
- TENS unit if approved by your doctors
- Continue with gluten-free diet

3. Medical Steps:
- Contact your surgeon's office immediately
- Ask if they can expedite your surgery given current symptoms
- Request a referral to a pain management specialist
- Consider getting a second opinion about possible ovarian torsion

4. Seizure Prevention:
- Maintain strict medication schedule
- Ensure adequate sleep
- Avoid triggers
- Have someone check on you regularly

5. Mental Health:
- Consider counseling to help manage chronic pain stress
- Connect with support groups
- Practice stress-reduction techniques

Most importantly, don't let dismissive medical professionals discourage you from seeking care. If you feel your symptoms are worsening or you're concerned about torsion, return to the ER and advocate firmly for proper imaging and assessment.

122.question: Here’s my info: 21F, 160lbs, 5’2”, White; preexisting conditions include Major Depressive Disorder, General Anxiety Disorder, and Asthma; non drinker, but I do vape and smoke weed Current medications: Zoloft 100mg 1x/day AM, Adderall 10mg as needed for school/work, Fluticasone inhaler (Advair) 2x/day, Singulair 10mg 1x/day PM, Xyzal 5mg 1x/day PM, Ventolin inhaler as needed, Keppra 500mg 2x/day I made a post about this a few months ago. I went through a few details about these weird “episodes” I’d been having that I later found out were partial seizures. You can read my first post here Anyway, on 10/7 I suffered my first grand mal seizure. I went to the ER and had a CT and bloodwork- both were unremarkable. I was also given Keppra IV, as well as a Keppra prescription 500mg 2x/day. I also had an MRI and an EEG- both unremarkable as well. Since then I’ve had a few more of these partial seizures. They come at completely random times and the doctors were stumped as to why this suddenly popped up. I have no family history of epilepsy, and never had seizures prior to these starting around mid/late 2019. Never had any crazy fevers as a kid, and have not introduced any new drugs etc. since they started. I’m really just making a post to gather more insight and experiences from doctors and other people as well. If anyone has any insight as to what could be causing this, it would be much appreciated. This diagnosis has kinda knocked me on my ass, as I can’t drive for 6 months after my last seizure. While I’m glad my scans/tests were unremarkable, I wish I had gotten some sort of answer.
122.answer:
I understand your frustration with not having a clear answer about what's causing your seizures. Based on your information, here are some relevant considerations:

1. Medication interactions:
- Zoloft and Adderall can potentially lower seizure threshold
- Drug interactions should be carefully evaluated

2. Possible triggers to consider:
- Sleep deprivation
- Stress
- Vaping/cannabis use
- Hormonal changes
- Anxiety/panic attacks (can sometimes be confused with partial seizures)

3. Classification:
- New-onset seizures in adulthood with normal imaging suggests possible:
  * Cryptogenic epilepsy (unknown cause)
  * Stress-induced seizures
  * Autoimmune epilepsy

Recommendations:
1. Keep a detailed seizure diary
2. Track potential triggers
3. Consider:
- Consulting an epileptologist
- Additional testing (video EEG monitoring)
- Discussing medication adjustments with your doctor
- Evaluating lifestyle factors

Remember: Many people with epilepsy have normal test results but still benefit from treatment.

Would you like me to elaborate on any of these points?

123.question: Basic Information Age: 71 Gender: Male Height: 5’7” Weight: ~70kg Smoking status: Non-smoker for 2 years (smoked for 40 years previously) Medical issues: Advanced liver disease, cirrhosis Duration: Approximately 6-7 years Hi all, My father (71M, about 70kg), was diagnosed with cirrhosis back in 2014 as a result of alcohol abuse. Over the years since, he's had three bouts of esophageal varices (the most recent in January 2020) and four seizures: May 2019, Sept 2019, Jan 19 2021, Feb 23 2021. Things have felt pretty stable since he recovered from his last bout of esophageal varices in 2020, and it was a relatively relaxing year in terms of worrying about his health. While it can be heartbreaking, he has only been drinking a few beers every night and I've had to accept a few years back I can't stop him drinking. During Christmas, he told me he has gone off Xifaxan - which I believe he's been on since January 2020- as he hates going to the bathroom every hour and informed his doctor. He's aware it's for hepatic encephalopathy, however outlines he doesn't need it due to his cognitive functions still relatively in tact: he does the cryptic crossword every day, a sudoku, and can still play a vast range of songs on piano. Moreover, his long term memory of events and trivia seems unchanged. Though, from my observations over the years, there's a decreased lack of insight into the situation, increased short term memory loss, and less fluid intelligence. Following yesterday's seizure, he was prescribed Keppra. I guess what I'm asking is that: is it possible that going off Xifaxan is causing the seizures to return? Can seizures be a symptom of hepatic encephalopathy? Google says it's a rare side effect, but possible. Dad sometimes postulates it's a result of his motorbike accident in 1971 and was recently taking salt tablets due to low salt levels, however I advised him to speak with his GP about this and the GP advised him to stop. So far no doctor has made this connection - or, more accurately, what Dad has told me what the doctor's are saying. He's being sent to a district hospital later this month for an fMRI scan. This is worrying. Usually whenever there's a return to hospital - esophageal varices or seizures - there's a sigh of relief that he survived once again and one doesn't have to worry for while, but now with two seizures a month apart, I'm concerned they'll be more frequent and end up causing a coma and/or death. Ultimately, I asked him today if he would rather have seizures or go to the bathroom every hour. He said he'd rather have seizures as he hated how he felt going to the bathroom. Even if this is the cause, I guess, just like I can't make him quit drinking, I can't force him to go on any medications. Other medication as at November 2020 Propranolol 40 mg antoprazole 40 mg andesartan 16 mg Spiractin 25 mg Mirtazapine 15 mg Thanks in advance.
123.answer:
Based on the information provided, here's my analysis:

1. Relationship between Xifaxan (Rifaximin) and Seizures:
- Yes, stopping Xifaxan could potentially be related to the seizures
- Xifaxan is crucial in treating hepatic encephalopathy by reducing ammonia-producing bacteria in the gut
- When stopped, ammonia levels can rise, potentially leading to neurological symptoms including seizures

2. Hepatic Encephalopathy (HE) and Seizures:
- Seizures can indeed be a symptom of HE
- The cognitive symptoms you've noticed (decreased insight, short-term memory issues) are classic HE symptoms
- Doing crosswords and playing piano doesn't rule out HE, as it can be subtle and progressive

3. Concerning Factors:
- Continued alcohol consumption
- Recent discontinuation of Xifaxan
- Increasing frequency of seizures
- History of low sodium levels (which can also contribute to seizures)

4. Recommendations:
- Urgent discussion with his hepatologist about resuming Xifaxan
- Consider alternative dosing schedules or formulations if side effects are problematic
- Regular monitoring of ammonia levels and electrolytes
- Continue with planned MRI to rule out other causes

The situation requires careful medical supervision, especially given the increasing frequency of seizures.

Would you like me to elaborate on any of these points?

124.question: 19F 167cm 59kg chinese in UK // "passing out" under certain conditions, suspected focal epilepsy?? duration: 3+ years?? (no existing medical conditions, no smoking/drugs etc)  Hi, I'm in a bit of a pinch and desperate for some kind of second opinion /advice on this since I'm travelling back home from uni and can't see a GP until I return in October (personal/family reasons).I've been "passing out" unexpectedly for short periods of time maybe a few times a month for at least 3 years now but only recently cared enough to dig deeper. It seems that it happens when I'm focusing on a bright light/screen in a dimly lit environment (e.g. it's happened every time I went to a concert in the past half year, 7 times, also in the car at night when looking at bright lights, and watching a presentation on a projector in a dark-ish room). Each time it happens I feel a bit dizzy/nauseous and slow, then my eyes roll and refuse to focus, and eventually my head drops and I'm unconscious for a few seconds to a few minutes. When I regain consciousness I feel quite disoriented and often "pass out" again very quickly for several times in succession until removed from the environment. It seems to also take at least several minutes of being exposed to the stimulus before anything happens, in general. I can't really remember accurately since it feels very hazy.
124.answer:
This sounds like it could be photosensitive epilepsy or another light-sensitive neurological condition. Here's what you should know:

1. Immediate recommendations:
