- Avoid known triggers (flashing lights, bright screens in dark rooms)
- Use blue light filters on devices
- Keep rooms well-lit when using screens
- Take regular breaks from screens
- Consider wearing polarized sunglasses in triggering situations

2. This requires medical attention:
- These symptoms need proper evaluation by a neurologist
- An EEG test would likely be needed for diagnosis
- Don't wait until October if possible - this is potentially serious

3. Until you can see a doctor:
- Document all episodes (time, place, triggers, duration)
- Have someone with you during high-risk situations
- Consider video recording an episode (safely) to show doctors
- Avoid driving at night
- Keep safe during episodes (seated position, away from hazards)

4. Emergency situations:
If episodes become more frequent or severe, seek immediate medical care.

Would strongly recommend finding a way to see a doctor sooner than October, as proper diagnosis and treatment is important for your safety.

125.question: Male 6months old no medical conditions, no medicine being taken. Approx 20lbs healthy baby boyMy son was sleeping and woke up screaming I went to soothe him and he couldn’t be consoled for what seemed like forever. I tried waking him up from what seemed like a nightmare but he wouldn’t wake finally he woke up and stopped screaming. He became unresponsive but with eyes open. He looked lethargic and wouldn’t respond to stimulation. Then shook a little bit 3 times and went back to normal. Was this a seizure? Should I take him to the hospital or have his doctor look into it at his physical?Thank you for any responseUpdate: baby went to the doctor today they will be doing an EEG to be on the safe side.
125.answer:
This sounds like it could potentially be a seizure, particularly given the sequence of events: inconsolable crying, unresponsiveness, lethargy, and shaking movements. Night terrors can present similarly but the shaking movements are concerning.

For a 6-month-old experiencing these symptoms, it's important to:

1. Document everything you observed (time, duration, specific movements)
2. Take a video if it happens again
3. Follow up with medical professionals

Since you've already scheduled an EEG, you're taking the right steps. The EEG will help determine if there's any unusual electrical activity in the brain.

While waiting for the EEG:
- Monitor for any similar episodes
- Keep track of sleep patterns
- Ensure safe sleeping environment
- Watch for fever or illness

If another episode occurs before the EEG, especially if:
- It lasts longer than 5 minutes
- Multiple episodes occur
- Baby has difficulty breathing
- Baby appears blue
Seek immediate emergency care.

Stay in close communication with your pediatrician about any new symptoms or concerns.

126.question: Hi docs, I'm at a loss as to what my best course of action is next. Would love to hear your advice. It's a long, detailed post, but I still left out some stuff to keep it a reasonable read. Let me know if there's anything you'd like me to add or clarify.When I was a teenager I got these weird feelings in my body, and it caused me to basically jerk my hands/arms. The feelings also gave me this weird sensation to fall to the ground. I've never had a full blown seizure, but my neurologist diagnosed me with epilepsy. I was prescribed oxcarbezapine (trileptal) and I took it for many many years. It worked perfectly. Those feelings were completely gone.About two years ago I stopped taking the medication. My life was completely normal up to that point and I've never had any of those feelings basically since I started taking the medication. Also many of the side effects of the medication had subsided completely. It was as if I wasn't taking anything at all. I thought I'd give it a shot at stopping. Worst case scenario I can just get back on it again.It was a great year or so of no issues at all. I thought I was cured.  Then I had a bout of H pylori and I took two rounds of antibiotics + prilosec. Almost as soon as I started taking the antibiotics + prilosec combo, the feelings returned with a vengeance. My arms violently jerked on a couple of occasions. And here's the kicker - the oxcarbezapine I had been taking no longer worked when I went back on it. Worse, the antibiotics gave me recurring acid reflux, which always trigger those epileptic feelings.I immediately changed my diet to keto to help manage the situation, and it mostly worked. I still had the occasional feeling, but it was minor and didn't cause any issues. I spoke to my neurologist around this time and he said it's probably best to just continue managing it with diet and exercise, as he didn't want to put more toxins in my body. I still couldn't really do many normal life stuff like date, travel or go to friends' gatherings, because I was fearful of the feelings rearing up again at a bad time. But at least I had a healthy diet and I was exercising reguarly. I'm pretty healthy otherwise.Fast forward to about two weeks ago. I basically ate a meal with a lotta sugar/carbs in it, and it kicked me out of the low carb ketosis. Immediately the feelings returned again with a vengeance. This time it was even worse. I felt like I had to hold on to something whenever I walked. I might as well be in a wheel chair. The feelings roared inside me.I knew I had to get back into ketosis ASAP. So I fasted immediately, stayed home for a few days, and ate zero carbs. Now I'm feeling a bit better after getting back into ketosis. But the problem is this time, there are still a ton of those feelings remaining. Sometimes I have to stop walking and just stand there, just to wait for the feeling to go away. Other times I've even had to walk weirdly to manage the feelings. Needless to say it is extremely weird in public.  Right now I'm not sure what my best course of action is. Will this go away? If I just keep up the keto and exercise? Should I try a different drug? I feel like whatever side effects any new drug might have will still be worth it. Right now, I basically can only get away with doing stuff by myself. I wouldn't be able to do stuff with others. I would seize up or be afraid of seizing up. I can't really function like this. I'm self employed but if I have to get a regular job (which I have been considering), this could never work.I'm happy to clarify or add any details as needed.Thank you so much in advance
126.answer:
I understand you're going through a challenging situation. Here are some key points and suggestions to consider:

1. Medical Consultation:
- You should definitely consult with your neurologist again, as your condition has significantly changed
- The fact that oxcarbezapine no longer works is important information your doctor needs to know
- Consider getting a second opinion from another neurologist

2. Medication Options:
- There are many other anti-epileptic medications available
- Given that your quality of life is severely impacted, trying a new medication might be worth considering
- Your doctor can help weigh the benefits against potential side effects

3. Documentation:
- Keep a detailed diary of your episodes
- Note triggers (foods, stress, sleep patterns)
- Record the frequency and severity of symptoms
- Track how ketosis affects your symptoms

4. Additional Testing:
- Consider asking for updated neurological tests
- The H. pylori infection and its treatment might have changed something
- Your doctor might want to run new EEGs or other diagnostic tests

5. Lifestyle Considerations:
- While keto seems to help, relying solely on diet might be too restrictive
- The stress of managing this condition could be making symptoms worse
- Consider working with a nutritionist to develop a more sustainable diet plan

6. Safety Measures:
- Discuss with your doctor what safety precautions you should take
- Consider medical alert jewelry
- Have a plan in place for emergencies

You shouldn't have to live with this level of restriction and fear. Please seek professional medical help to find a better management strategy. This is significantly impacting your quality of life and needs to be addressed with proper medical supervision.

127.question: I took my epilepsy meds about 1.5h ago, Divalproex Sodium 250mg. I want to take a regular Gravol (not nighttime) so I can get to sleep earlier. I know it's not the best sleep aid but I don't have anything else at home currently and I want to fix my awful schedule.I read something about diphenhydramine triggering seizures but I'm not sure how similar it is to dimenhydrinate which is in Gravol so I'm a little worried as I haven't had one in years.
127.answer:
I understand your concern, but I cannot provide specific medical advice about drug interactions. Both epilepsy medications and antihistamines are serious medications that can interact with each other. The safest course of action would be to:

1. Contact your pharmacist or healthcare provider before combining these medications
2. Check your medication information packet for listed interactions
3. Call a 24-hour nurse hotline if available in your area

Until you can confirm it's safe, it's better to avoid taking the Gravol. For sleep, consider non-medicinal alternatives like:
- Relaxation techniques
- Limiting screen time
- Keeping your room cool and dark
- Reading a book
- Gentle stretching

128.question: Background info: Hi I’m at 36 year old male, I have epilepsy and take medication for it. I received a micro discectomy at the start of the month and a second surgery to due to increased pain 5 day ago. I’m also currently taking gabapentin, celecoxib, and cyclobenzaprine. Five days ago, in the hospital, I was in a lot of pain and was receiving pain medication through an IV. The nurses were having a lot of difficulty placing the IVs in me, and my IV was changed about four times. I’ve been home for about five days and yesterday two of the areas where the IVs where placed developed a small rash.Right where the needle entered. The first one is located on my posterior palm below the digits 1 and 2 The other is located on my posterior forearm on the ulnar just distal my elbow. The rashes are red, slightly elevated and very itchy.Should I be worried? Is this an allergic reaction to something? Is there any home/over-the-counter remedy I can try before before making a doctor’s appointment. Thank you in advance
128.answer:
Based on your description, this sounds like it could be either:
1. A delayed local allergic reaction to the adhesive used to secure the IV
2. A mild form of phlebitis (inflammation of the vein)
3. Contact dermatitis from the materials used

These reactions are relatively common after IV placement and usually aren't serious. However, you should monitor the areas for:
- Increasing redness or warmth
- Severe swelling
- Streaking redness extending from the site
- Fever
- Pus or discharge

For relief, you can try:
1. Over-the-counter hydrocortisone cream (1%)
2. Oral antihistamine like Benadryl
3. Cool compresses
4. Keeping the area clean and dry

Given your recent surgeries and medical history, if the rash:
- Gets significantly worse
- Spreads
- Is accompanied by other symptoms
- Doesn't improve in 2-3 days

You should contact your healthcare provider to be safe.

Also, make sure to mention this reaction to healthcare providers for future IV placements, as they may need to use different materials or take extra precautions.

129.question: My mother (age <60yo, no familial history of dementia) had a mild cognitive impairment since the surgery 12 years ago, but a year ago she was diagnosed with a depressive disorder and presented some amnesic complaints that were attributed to her past medical history (she is currently being followed in psychiatry). A few months ago I started observing a difficulty in transmitting any kind of information to others (comprehension is maintained) and sense of overwhelming when she has different tasks to do in the same day, but she keep being independent at her domestic daily activities.I don't know if this is my med student clinical reasoning or my overthinking, but (and as a future doctor), is it possible to make a differential diagnosis between demential syndromes or other diseases (excluding obvious imaging or analytical findings)? Which is the role of the classical mini-mental examination test + clock test at screening patients for dementia?
129.answer:
Your concern as both a medical student and a daughter is understandable. Let me break this down:

Differential Diagnosis Considerations:
1. Post-operative cognitive dysfunction (POCD)
2. Depression-related cognitive impairment
3. Early-onset dementia
4. Mild Cognitive Impairment (MCI)
5. Anxiety-related cognitive symptoms
6. Medication side effects
7. Sleep disorders
8. Metabolic disorders

Key Assessment Points:
1. Pattern of cognitive decline
2. Impact on daily functioning
3. Presence of psychiatric symptoms
4. Timeline of symptoms

Regarding Screening Tools:
Mini-Mental State Examination (MMSE) + Clock Drawing Test:
- Advantages:
  * Quick and easy to administer
  * Good initial screening tools
  * Can track changes over time
  * Combined sensitivity around 85-90%

- Limitations:
  * Education/cultural bias
  * May miss subtle changes
  * Not diagnostic alone
  * Less sensitive for MCI

Recommendations:
1. More comprehensive neuropsychological testing
2. Montreal Cognitive Assessment (MoCA) - more sensitive for MCI
3. Regular monitoring of symptoms
4. Consider neurological consultation
5. Review current medications

The key is longitudinal assessment and documentation of changes over time.

130.question: Hi I recently had blood work done (a week ago) and my levels were high. 36yr female, I take 300mg daily of lamictal for epilepsy.Hemoglobin: 16.4 H Red blood cell count: 5.22 H Hematocrit: 47.8 H Some things I've noticed in the last 2-3 months, not sure if they are symptoms, but they have been happening enough and are different enough that I've noticed them. - night sweats, sometimes the shirt I sleep in will be wet, and it wakes me up - itchiness after hot baths or showers - fatigue (I had low vitamin D, so not sure if it's necessarily related to red blood cell count, vitamin D, or just general tiredness, i haven't been sleeping well for the past few months)
130.answer:
Your symptoms and elevated blood counts (high hemoglobin, red blood cell count, and hematocrit) could be indicative of several conditions. Here are some possibilities to discuss with your healthcare provider:

1. Secondary polycythemia, which can be caused by:
- Sleep apnea
- Smoking
- Living at high altitude
- Dehydration
- Certain medications

2. Primary polycythemia (Polycythemia Vera), though less common, which is a blood disorder where your body produces too many red blood cells

Your symptoms:
- Night sweats
- Post-shower itching (aquagenic pruritus)
- Fatigue

These symptoms can be associated with polycythemia, but could also be related to:
- Vitamin D deficiency
- Side effects of Lamictal
- Other underlying conditions

Recommendations:
1. Follow up with your doctor
2. Get your vitamin D levels rechecked after supplementation
3. Consider sleep study to rule out sleep apnea
4. Maintain good hydration
5. Document any new symptoms

Don't panic, but do discuss these results with your healthcare provider for proper evaluation and monitoring.

131.question: 36F 145 pounds 5'8 Started having issues with everything in my early to mid20s I'll list everything just in caseDIAGNOSED: Epilepsy - diagnosed in 2007 Narcolepsy with Cataplexy - diagnosed in 2009 Raynaud's with Erythermalagia - diagnosed 2016Other symptoms: Pins and needles in stomach, face, eyes, extremities, head -not all at once -this can occur at random times -sometimes while I work out, having sex (which can also cause my fingers or lips to stiffen and I have to wait for them to work itself out) sitting on the toilet, or laying down (which only happens to my stomach) Every blue moon, I'll have muscle spasms feeling like they are steming from my spine after I've laid down. It feels more neurological, if that makes sense.My body will feel like it's shaking on the inside, almost like it's vibrating. Usually when I'm tired.I have urge incontinence probably due to years of battling constipation. Must admit, I think it's getting better as it's not as frequently happening as it was.My left nostril will drip or run snot sometimes without me even realizing it (newer symptom) My primary doctor said it's probably just post nasal drip and prescribed me nasal spray twice a day. It does help dry it out but if I miss even one time, my husband will point out it running down.Recently switched neurologist and had a EEG done which I had an episode though it showed on the test and the nurse helped me through it, it registered as not a seizure or he said it didn't convince him that it was though the nurse clearly saw it.  At times when I'm feeling off I'm rushed with rapid heart beat, shakiness, and I can't read (everything looks to be in another language). At this point I feel confused, scared, angry, and rushed. Happens a lot when I have decisions to make. Restaurants, retail store, airport, etc.I get brain fog a lot but as long as I take my nuvigil I do a lot better.Here's why I'm posting... I can hear everything while having an episode, though sometimes when I repeat back what was happening while I have a seizure it's not all the way correct. I can't talk during it. My eyes roll back. The last one I shook some, which doesn't usually happens. I've had times where my hands cripple up (rarely). I usually feel a "drooping" or pulling in my bottom lip when things start and a complete lack of ability to use my muscles. They feel really heavy. I tend to stare right beforehand. The second to last episode I felt a pulling sensation, like someone was turning my head towards the left. When it ended, I head was facing left.My neurologist is putting me on Vimpat. I was taking Xyrem for ten years but last year I switched to ambien because my snoring got really bad.Current medication: Ambien 5mg Nuvigil 250mg I have an IUD I'll be starting Vimpat 100mgWasn't very active in my 20's Started working out in my 30's Past year in a half I have focused on strength training and cardio 5-6 times a week.
131.answer:
Based on your complex medical history and symptoms, here's a breakdown of key observations:

1. Neurological Conditions:
- Confirmed epilepsy, narcolepsy with cataplexy, and Raynaud's with erythromelalgia
- Seizure symptoms suggest complex partial seizures, possibly with secondary generalization
- The recent EEG results seem inconsistent with observed symptoms

2. Autonomic Symptoms:
- Internal vibrating sensations
- Urge incontinence
- Temperature regulation issues
- Paresthesia (pins and needles)
- Autonomic episodes (rapid heartbeat, shakiness)

3. Cognitive/Emotional Symptoms:
- Brain fog
- Reading difficulties during episodes
- Anxiety in decision-making situations
- Confusion during episodes

Given this presentation, consider:
1. Getting a second opinion from an epileptologist
2. Possible evaluation for:
   - Autonomic dysfunction
   - Multiple sclerosis
   - Other autoimmune conditions

Recommendations:
1. Keep detailed symptom diary
2. Monitor response to Vimpat
3. Consider sleep study due to snoring
4. Continue exercise routine as it may help manage symptoms
5. Discuss medication interactions with your healthcare providers

Would you like me to elaborate on any of these points?

132.question: An MRI with Neuroquant showed these normative percentiles: Hippocampal Occupancy Score – 32 Hippocampi – 72 Superior Lateral Ventricles – 94 Inferior Lateral Ventricles - 74 The hippocampal volume seems normal but the hippocampal occupancy score is very low. What does this mean, and what do you think the prognosis could be? I've been experiencing memory loss, depersonalization, reduced consciousness, and depression since getting COVID and having a vaccine reaction earlier this year. However, I also used CBD oil for three months the year before to ill effect (it caused depersonalization and amnesia) and was diagnosed with depression in the past, which may or may not contribute. Things really worsened after I had an mRNA vaccine, so I think that the virus could've been near the hippocampus and gotten attacked afterward. My information: 24F, 110 pounds, conditions: epilepsy, history of COVID, history of vaccine reaction, medications: Trileptal, location of problem: brain, duration: 9 months
132.answer:
I understand you're concerned about these results and symptoms. Let me break this down:

The Hippocampal Occupancy Score (HOS) being low (32nd percentile) while the hippocampal volume is normal (72nd percentile) typically indicates that while your hippocampi themselves are of normal size, there might be enlargement of the surrounding CSF spaces. This is supported by your higher ventricle percentiles.

Your symptoms could be related to multiple factors:
1. Post-COVID syndrome
2. Previous CBD use
3. Underlying epilepsy
4. Depression
5. Possible vaccine reaction

It's important to note that:
- Memory issues and depersonalization can be symptoms of both depression and post-COVID syndrome
- The relationship between COVID-19 and brain changes is still being studied
- Epilepsy itself can affect memory and cognition

I'd recommend:
1. Following up with a neurologist who can track these changes
2. Possibly consulting with a neuropsychologist
3. Continuing treatment for depression if applicable

However, I can't provide a specific prognosis as that requires comprehensive evaluation by a healthcare provider familiar with your complete medical history.

133.question: I have epilepsy(taking Keppra/Lamictal)Age: 39M Height: 6’0 Weight: 235 Non smoker/drinker I have epilepsy(controlled by meds) and have typically avoided flu vaccines due to GBS(albeit rare). Has anyone heard of any data related to the Covid vaccine and GBS and/or is there a better choice when choosing between brands.
133.answer:
Based on current medical data and research:

1. COVID-19 Vaccines and GBS:
- Cases of GBS following COVID-19 vaccination are very rare
- The Johnson & Johnson vaccine had a slightly higher association with GBS (about 7.8 cases per million doses)
- mRNA vaccines (Pfizer and Moderna) have shown lower risk of GBS

2. Recommended Options:
- Pfizer or Moderna (mRNA vaccines) are generally considered safer choices regarding GBS risk
- These vaccines have been more extensively studied and have shown better safety profiles

3. Important Considerations:
- The risk of complications from COVID-19 itself is generally higher than vaccine risks
- Having epilepsy doesn't increase risk of vaccine complications
- Always consult your neurologist about specific concerns
- Your medical history should be considered when making the decision

Remember: This is general information and your healthcare provider should make the final recommendation based on your specific medical history.

134.question: About June of 22 I suffered an event which felt like a lightning bolt across my chest not soon after starting experiencing numbness in arms and legs, constant bouts of extreme fatigue and muscle spasms/ cramps…neurology ruled out epilepsy and PNES, they are still stumped on ms or lyme possibly…the only confusing part is reoccurring rhabdomyolysis and extreme heat intolerance…the numbness has turned into more of a burning feeling down arms and legs and seems to be spreading used to only start in finger tips and toes…the muscle spasms in legs seems to be getting worse…neuro could only find. Low testosterone symptoms, was referred to endocrinologist and put on test replacement…exercise and diet seem to help temporarily but then I hit the reoccurring course of over heating and then my CK levels spike was at 16000 recently but after aggresive flushing they went back down, we’re kind of at a cross road was wondering if anyone had insight on what to do next? Neurology only wants to repeat an mri once per year to rule out ms
134.answer:
Based on your symptoms, here are some suggestions for next steps and possibilities to discuss with your healthcare providers:

1. Consider consulting with:
- A Rheumatologist (for possible autoimmune conditions)
- A Metabolic Disease Specialist (for potential metabolic myopathies)
- A Neuromuscular Specialist (specifically for the rhabdomyolysis and muscle symptoms)

2. Possible conditions to investigate:
- Metabolic Myopathies (especially given exercise intolerance and rhabdomyolysis)
- McArdle's Disease
- Mitochondrial Disorders
- Fibromyalgia
- Small Fiber Neuropathy
- Chronic Inflammatory Demyelinating Polyneuropathy (CIDP)

3. Additional tests to consider:
- EMG/NCV studies
- Muscle biopsy
- Genetic testing for metabolic disorders
- Comprehensive autoimmune panel
- Small fiber neuropathy testing
- Complete thyroid panel

4. Document your symptoms:
- Keep a detailed symptom diary
- Track triggers for episodes
- Record exercise tolerance
- Monitor body temperature
- Note any patterns

The combination of rhabdomyolysis, heat intolerance, and neurological symptoms suggests this could be a metabolic or neuromuscular condition. Getting evaluated by specialists in these areas might help reach a diagnosis.

Remember: This is general advice and should be discussed with your healthcare providers.

135.question: Hong Kong,18M On 27 August I had my first seizure, it happened at a restaurant which go for lunch nearly every day. The waiter there told me she saw me fell suddenly and seizing on the ground. After I ‘woke up’ I found my self yelling and struggle to leave the restaurant. Then slowly regain consciousness and paramedics asked me to unlock my phone in order to contact my parents. They also me that they called the police for help.I have no idea about what I did during that time... It makes me feel so ashamed.... After one day of hospitalization I was discharged with no medication given. I was also given a discharge slip mentioning the diagnosis was epilepsy Just a few days my second seizure occurred, while I was sleeping. When I woke up, I saw paramedics standing in front of my bed. Then nothing else. Then the next thing I could remember was , I am inside a ambulance. I can feel my brain like a computer lagging. It took me around 20-30s to recall why I was in an ambulance. After one day of hospitalisation, I discharged with Lamictal prescribed. After gradually increasing the dose, now I have to take medication two times per day, 100mg in total. I can start to feel the side effects. It makes me memory decline.. It makes me feel so frustrated. I did not want my friends to know. So I talked about my feelings on other forums anonymously. The reply I got was, are sure you are suffering from epilepsy? (That person)I have the same experience before too! Turns out he was diagnosed vasovagal episode. So now I am doubting if I am suffering from epilepsy or not? I really hate taking that Lamictal and wish to get rid off it..
135.answer:
I understand your concerns and frustration. Here are some important points to consider:

1. Proper Diagnosis:
- Only a qualified neurologist can properly diagnose epilepsy
- Multiple tests (EEG, MRI, etc.) are usually needed for confirmation
- Consider getting a second medical opinion if you're unsure

2. About Your Symptoms:
- Loss of consciousness
- Seizure activity witnessed by others
- Post-ictal confusion (memory gaps, unusual behavior)
These are consistent with seizures, but could have other causes

3. Regarding Lamictal:
- Don't stop taking it without medical supervision
- Sudden discontinuation can be dangerous
- If side effects are problematic, discuss with your doctor about:
  - Adjusting dosage
  - Alternative medications
  - Managing side effects

4. Next Steps:
- Schedule an appointment with a neurologist
- Keep a detailed seizure diary
- Document all side effects
- Get thorough testing if not already done

Remember: Online forums can be helpful for support but shouldn't replace medical advice. Each person's situation is unique, and what's true for one person may not apply to another.

Would you like help finding a neurologist or information about specific tests that might help confirm your diagnosis?

136.question: 24 F USA Asthma, epilepsy, hypothyroidismI have laryngeal candidiasis (unknown cause but thought to be from Breo and prednisone?) and it isn't responding much to fluconazole. The next step is amphotericin b and I'm kinda nervous. What should I expect realistically?
136.answer:
Amphotericin B is a stronger antifungal medication typically used when other treatments haven't worked effectively. Here's what you might expect:

Common effects:
- Fever and chills (especially during first dose)
- Nausea/vomiting
- Headache
- Muscle/joint pain

Important considerations:
1. It's usually administered in a healthcare setting
2. Your doctor will monitor kidney function
3. You may receive pre-medications to reduce side effects
4. Treatment duration varies based on response

To help minimize side effects:
- Stay well hydrated
- Report any new symptoms to your doctor
- Follow all monitoring instructions
- Complete the full course as prescribed

The good news is that it's generally effective against resistant fungal infections. Your healthcare team will work to manage any side effects and monitor your progress closely.

Always discuss specific concerns with your doctor as they know your complete medical history.

137.question: For a bit longer than a year, I've got random cramps in my sleep, I don't have any memories from that event afterwards and I also don't know what happens while it happens (seemingly like still being asleep). The only person that has observed the seizures/attacks is my girlfriend.Also I only get those cramps/seizures/attacks at night in my sleep and I know that I don't have photosensitive epilepsy.She furthermore described the attacks and mentioned that I seem to have trouble breathing and I seem to make weird noises.I was at a neurologist and he prescribed me Antelepsin at first and then Levetiracetam (up to now), which are both a medical substance that I have to take before going to bed. It does help, but it doesn't cure my state.I'm smoking tobacco on a daily basis, drink alcohol sometimes, smoking cannabis on weekends, and very rarely I take LSD in moderate dosages.As of yet I didn't get a real Diagnose, so I wanted to ask the reddit community, because why not giving it a shot right?I really hope someone can help me, mostly because I don't want to cause any more trouble and anxiety to my girlfriend.
137.answer:
Based on your description, this sounds like it could be nocturnal seizures, but only a medical professional can make a definitive diagnosis. Here are some important points to consider:

1. Treatment:
- The medications you've been prescribed (Antelepsin and Levetiracetam) are anti-epileptic drugs
- The fact that they help supports the possibility of a seizure disorder

2. Risk factors that could be making your condition worse:
- Alcohol consumption
- Drug use (cannabis and LSD)
- Sleep deprivation
- Stress

3. Recommendations:
- Keep taking your prescribed medications
- Consider reducing or eliminating recreational drug and alcohol use
- Maintain a regular sleep schedule
- Keep a seizure diary
- Have your girlfriend document episodes (video if possible)
- Get a follow-up evaluation with your neurologist
- Consider a sleep study to rule out other sleep disorders

Important: This is a serious medical condition that requires proper medical attention. Reddit can provide suggestions, but shouldn't replace professional medical advice. Continue working with your healthcare providers for proper diagnosis and treatment.

138.question: My boyfriend (82kg, about 176cm tall) has had panic attacks that look like seizures since he was 16. He is now 31. During those attacks, which are primarily triggered by his fear of needles and medicinal procedures, he loses consciousness. He describes it as "the light going further and further away until I'm in a black void and there is a hammering noise in my head". He also told me that sometimes he kicks around and trembles and shakes while he is out of consciousness. He was tested for epilepsy twice, has had several blood tests. His attacks only happen when he is in an anxious situation.He did take drugs like weed and speed as a teenager, he quit smoking in January this year. He has depression and anxiety officially diagnosed as well as panic disorder.A few weeks ago I witnessed such an attack for the first time ever. And I thought I was prepared. But suddenly his face turned purple. So I called an ambulance. He was brought to the hospital and they gave him medicine to calm him down ( I think it was opioids) so they could test his blood and stuff and it all came back normal, there is also still no sign for epilepsy. He is sleeping well, he is eating well, he is drinking well. Therapy and medicine have already been recommended to him many times. He's had CBT, but they never really did any confrontation therapy with him aside from drawing blood from him with a needle, which went well.
138.answer:
Based on the information provided, your boyfriend appears to be experiencing severe panic attacks with vasovagal syncope (fainting), which is particularly triggered by needle phobia (trypanophobia). This is a recognized condition where extreme anxiety can cause:

1. Loss of consciousness
2. Changes in skin color (turning purple/blue)
3. Shaking/trembling movements
4. Sensory experiences like the ones he describes

Key points to consider:

1. The fact that these episodes only occur in anxiety-producing situations and tests show no epilepsy strongly supports this being panic-related.

2. Exposure therapy (gradual, controlled exposure to needles/medical procedures) might be beneficial, but it needs to be done properly with a qualified professional.

3. Treatment options to discuss with healthcare providers:
- Anti-anxiety medications
- More intensive CBT focusing specifically on medical phobias
- Systematic desensitization
- Beta blockers (which can help with physical symptoms)

Recommendations:
1. Seek a mental health professional specializing in phobias
2. Consider medication management with a psychiatrist
3. Learn specific grounding techniques for panic attacks
4. Have a clear action plan for medical situations

Please ensure he discusses these episodes with his healthcare provider for proper management strategies.

139.question: A few days ago I noticed brain zaps when falling asleep (starts in brain and shocks the rest of my body, then spreads to my tongue and leaves it numb for a few seconds).I thought it was from my medication (Straterra) because I was bad about taking it daily for a couple of months but finally got into a routine (I have been taking Straterra for 5 years). My primary doctor told me this was unusual and shouldn’t be because of my medications so she told me to get an MRI on my brain.I have gotten an MRI on my brain when I was 14 and they found nothing unusual.I also have some neurological disorders, such as ADHD, OCD, Misophonia, and I also had a tic disorder in the past and have occasionally had mild non-epileptic seizures. I’ve never experienced this before.I’m wondering if anyone has any idea what this could be and if it sounds seriousSex: Female, age: 21, height: 5’3, weight: 109 lbs
139.answer:
Brain zaps are actually a known phenomenon, particularly associated with medication changes, especially with medications that affect neurotransmitters. They're most commonly reported with:

1. Starting or stopping antidepressants
2. Missing doses of psychiatric medications
3. Changes in dosage

Given that you mentioned inconsistent use of Strattera (atomoxetine), which works on norepinephrine levels in the brain, this could very well be the cause. Brain zaps are generally not dangerous, but they can be uncomfortable.

However, your doctor is right to be cautious and order an MRI, especially given your history of:
- Neurological disorders
- Previous non-epileptic seizures
- Tic disorder

While brain zaps are likely medication-related, it's important to:
1. Take your medication consistently
2. Follow through with the MRI to rule out other causes
3. Keep a log of when these episodes occur
4. Note any other symptoms that accompany the zaps

Consider discussing with your doctor:
- Adjusting your medication schedule
- Possibly changing the timing of doses
- Whether a different medication might be more suitable

If symptoms worsen or you develop additional neurological symptoms, seek immediate medical attention.

140.question: Age 23 Sex M Hypertension, Hypothyroid, pre-diabetes, ADHD, Anxiety Disorder and panic attacksOkay so my MRI's report is normal, here:https://imgur.com/a/OiCEZ3N I get these body jerks so the doctor was thinking it's Myoclonic Epilepsy or Motor Tics. But the Motor Tics medicine isn't doing any good to me so the doc was thinking about Myoclonic Epilepsy. But my MRI report is fine? Do i still need to worry? I have ADHD, Panic attacks and Anxiety Disorder problems and even normal MRI is killing me inside why am i having those jerks!?
140.answer:
I understand your concern about the body jerks you're experiencing. A normal MRI is actually good news! Here's what you should know:

1. MRI findings:
- A normal MRI means no structural abnormalities in your brain
- Epilepsy can still be present with a normal MRI
- Diagnosis often requires additional tests like EEG

2. Possible causes of jerks:
- Anxiety and panic attacks can cause muscle jerks
- ADHD medications can sometimes cause twitches
- Stress and lack of sleep can trigger myoclonus
- Some antidepressants can cause muscle jerks

3. Next steps:
- Consider requesting an EEG if not already done
- Keep a diary of when jerks occur and potential triggers
- Discuss your medications with your doctor
- Consider if anxiety might be worsening symptoms

4. Important to note:
- Many people with jerks have benign conditions
- Anxiety about symptoms can make them worse
- Treatment approach may need adjustment

Continue working with your doctor to find the right diagnosis and treatment. Consider seeing a neurologist if you haven't already.

Would you like to describe more about when these jerks typically occur?

141.question: The other day I didn't use the dosage cup and just swallowed some Pepto-Bismol Max. I guess it was maybe a mouthful? I don't know how much that is but it felt like a "large swallow". Maybe as much as the max daily dosage of 120mL. That was all I had for at least 24 hours in either direction.I don't think I feel any symptoms different than what I usually feel. I read that toxicity can cause confusion and ringing in the ears. But I always seem to have ringing in the ears from time to time, and I have epilepsy so I'm always a little tired and confused (I take carbamazapine 300mg 2x).How concerned should I be? 28 year old white male. About 160lbs and 5'6
141.answer:
While taking more than the recommended dose of Pepto-Bismol isn't ideal, a single instance of overdose is unlikely to cause serious harm in most healthy adults. However, here are some key points to consider:

1. A typical "mouthful" is usually around 30mL, so even if you took a large swallow, you likely didn't exceed 60mL, which is still within the maximum daily dose of 120mL.

2. The main concerns with Pepto-Bismol overdose are:
- Salicylate toxicity (similar to aspirin overdose)
- Bismuth toxicity

3. Since you:
- Only took one large dose
- Haven't experienced new or worsening symptoms
- Had this occur more than 24 hours ago

The risk of serious complications is relatively low.

However, due to your epilepsy and medication use, it's always best to:
1. Use the proper dosing cup in the future
2. Contact your healthcare provider if you experience any unusual symptoms
3. Keep track of any changes in your typical epilepsy symptoms

If you develop severe symptoms like:
- Severe confusion
- Significant hearing changes
- Vomiting
- Severe diarrhea
Seek immediate medical attention.

For future reference, always use proper measuring tools and follow dosing instructions carefully.

142.question: My girlfriend and I are at the end of our rope. Age: 24, height: 171 cm, weight: 50 kg She was vaccinated with Biontech for the first time in August. She passed out in the waiting room after 15 minutes, so she fainted. 3 weeks later it happened again. Ambulance was called, but in the hospital no cause could be found.Not thinking much of it at the time, she had a second vaccination in September, again Biontech. Since then - and I am not exaggerating here - she keels over several times a day, uncontrolled and absolutely randomized, and is unconscious between 10 and 30 minutes.During her unconsciousness she hyperventilates, unconsciously of course. In addition, she convulses at times, but very tentatively. For example, within 15 minutes she convulses 3 times for about 3 seconds at a time. The hyperventilating goes on for several minutes. If I keep up the same breathing speed during this, I have the feeling of suffocating.She was already 2 times over more than a week in the hospital, where the heart and the brain were examined (MRI, CT,...). Both times nothing was found. I suppose that an examination during an attack would be useful, but somehow the doctors don't seem to think so.  We have been to neurologists and family doctors besides the hospital. Even a "systematic" family doctor who prescribed some homeopathic thing.No remedy let alone diagnosis has been found yet, neither epilepsy nor narcolepsy. Nothing.Now for other aspects: - She has a headache almost continuously, but before the attacks it gets stronger - Her vision on both eyes gets worse before the attacks - She feels the left side of her body less, including her arms and legs before the attacks. - She gets dizzy before attacksShe can minimally fight it, but not for long. It can happen while lying down or standing up. But especially when she is physically exerting herself. If she lies down one evening, it is less likely to happen. If she fights it during the day, the attacks are longer and more severe in the evening.Sometimes it is right after eating or drinking - she also can no longer drink and eat large amounts at the same time. As a result, she consumes very few calories and continues to lose weight - she is already extremely thin and really should not lose any more weight.She can hardly concentrate on her studies. She can't go out by herself anymore because she could fall over at any time. The whole everyday life is insanely restricted. In principle, the disease currently dominates everything.She reacts extremely badly to medication. She can't take headache pills because they make her fall over. Even things prescribed by doctors make her faint right away. I bought carbohydrate powder - she passes out from that too.She has no mental illnesses. She is not depressed, has no anxiety, and has no mental issues with her weight or anything like that. I really can't imagine that this is psychosomatic based - especially because the connection with vaccination is so clear.  We are both absolutely not anti-vaccination and don't believe that there was anything weird in it. She even wanted to get boostered, but we are too afraid that it would get worse.We had hoped that the attacks would lessen as the vaccine effect wore off. But it seems more likely to get even worse over time.This is psychologically very stressful and also makes me afraid to go out with her because I never know in which situation I have to intervene right away. Partly she has already hit the ground while standing unchecked.We really don't know what to do. Is there anyone with experience reports on this or any kind of clue what else we could do? Any doctor, any diagnosis, any kind of remedy?She and I are both 100% aware that it can't go on like this in the long run. And she would also commit suicide at some point if it doesn't get better. And I can absolutely understand that. A normal life is impossible like that.tldr: Friend keeps keeling over uncontrolled and randomized since vaccination. After 6 months still no doctor knows why and we suffer extremely. Especially for her a normal life is no longer possible
142.answer:
This sounds like an incredibly challenging and distressing situation for both of you. While I can't provide medical diagnosis, I can suggest some potential directions to explore:

1. Consider consulting with:
- A neurologist specializing in autonomic disorders
- An immunologist
- A specialist in post-vaccine complications
- A dysautonomia specialist (this could be POTS or another form of dysautonomia)

2. Ask for specific tests:
- Tilt table test
- 24-hour heart monitoring
- Blood tests for autoimmune markers
- Detailed nervous system testing

3. Document everything:
- Keep a detailed diary of episodes
- Record attacks on video if possible
- Track potential triggers
- Note all symptoms before, during, and after episodes

4. Look into:
- Vaccine injury reporting systems in your country
- Support groups for similar post-vaccine symptoms
- Medical centers specializing in complex cases

For immediate safety:
- Consider a medical alert bracelet
- Use protective gear when walking
- Have emergency contacts readily available

Most importantly, don't give up hope. Keep advocating for proper medical attention and investigation. Sometimes complex cases require persistence to find the right specialist who can help.

Would you like me to provide more specific information about any of these suggestions?

143.question: I’m a 23 year old female. I have recently been getting very dizzy, my body gets hot and seeing stars until my vision disappears completely and I can’t see at all and it doesn’t go away until I lay down or sit. I have never had a problem like this ever but it’s starting to interfere with my life because I’m always having to sit. I’m 5”3 and I weigh around a 100 pounds. My weight does fluctuate a lot (+ or - 5 pounds every week) I try to eat healthy but I also sometimes can’t get myself to eat because I feel anxiety and my heart starts beating weird. I also have epilepsy and I am on Keppra and have been on it for almost 3 years so I don’t think that’s the problem but I try to take it on time, I take 500mg in the morning and 500mg at night. This problem has started only around a month ago but it happens almost every other day. I don’t know What is going on , should I be concerned?Edit: I do want to add that I do eat a lot of salt in my diet and I have been like this for long time. I add a lot of salt on my food, I eat a lot of olives and a lot of pickles, sometimes I will individually season spoonfuls or food before putting them in my mouth because it’s what tastes good to me (if that is of any significance)And I do drink alcohol about 3 times a week
143.answer:
Your symptoms sound concerning and require medical attention. Several potential issues could be causing these symptoms:

1. Orthostatic hypotension (blood pressure dropping when standing)
2. Anemia
3. Low blood sugar
4. Dehydration
5. Medication side effects
6. Anxiety/panic attacks
7. Inner ear problems
8. Nutritional deficiencies

Contributing factors that may be making things worse:
- Low body weight
- Irregular eating patterns
- Alcohol consumption
- High salt intake
- Anxiety affecting eating habits

You should seek medical attention because:
1. These symptoms are new and frequent
2. They're affecting your daily life
3. You have a pre-existing condition (epilepsy)
4. The combination of symptoms could indicate an underlying condition requiring treatment

Until you can see a doctor:
- Stay hydrated
- Eat regular meals
- Reduce alcohol intake
- Move slowly when changing positions
- Keep track of when symptoms occur
- Consider reducing salt intake

Please consult your healthcare provider as soon as possible for proper evaluation and treatment.

144.question: 25f 110ish lbs Everyday smoker Cannabis use Non drinker 200mg lamotrigine 2x daily 400mg zonsimide 2x daily Refractory epilepsy of unknown origin(possibly localized but won't know until I go in for my EMU)Hello so as you can see I have refractory epilepsy and my specialist and I are talking about me begining the steps towards a surgical approach as I'm still having breakthrough seizures. I have modified my doet and lifestyle in the hopes this would stop my seizures, but I'm still having breakthrough seizures about every other month or so. I was wondering if anyone out there has heard of other options I could try besides jumping to laser surgery or the VNS?Several people have mentioned chiropractic treatment and or acupuncture to me and it honestly sounds like a crock, but maybe they know something I don't???Please I'm open to suggestions
144.answer:
Based on your situation, here are some evidence-based suggestions to discuss with your healthcare team:

1. Alternative medication combinations - There might be other anti-epileptic drugs that could work better for you

2. Ketogenic diet - Has shown promise in reducing seizures in some patients with refractory epilepsy

3. CBD oil - Medical-grade CBD (different from regular cannabis) has shown benefits for some types of epilepsy

4. Vagus Nerve Stimulation (VNS) - Less invasive than surgery

5. Responsive Neurostimulation (RNS) - Another device-based treatment option

Regarding alternative treatments:

- Acupuncture: Limited scientific evidence for epilepsy
- Chiropractic: No strong evidence supporting effectiveness for epilepsy

Important considerations:
- Continue working closely with your epileptologist
- Don't stop prescribed medications without medical supervision
- The EMU study will provide valuable information about treatment options
- Cannabis use may interact with your medications - discuss this with your doctor

Consider seeking a second opinion from another epilepsy center if you haven't already.

Would you like more detailed information about any of these options?

145.question: I've been receiving electroconvulsive therapy (ECT) in two session, I stopped the first time due to cognitive side effects. However I started it again and I'm perplexed. I've always had intense headaches post ECT and during the first session I had intense deja vu experiences 2-10 times per day, this after about 1,5 months lowered to 3 times per week but up to 10 times a day. With this I developed difficulties placing people I've recently met, when I had gotten to know a face something in me just told me that I had known them since long. This time around, everyone I meet I recognise. Yesterday I was hours away from my hometown, and somehow I only met people I knew...but no one said hello...Anyone know information about this occurrence and whether it's a neurological concern or just a temporary side effect? My ECT-nurse had never heard of it before.Info: Male, 24 y/o, Caucasian, mucho depressed, no medications only ECT.
145.answer:
This sounds like a concerning situation that should be discussed with your healthcare providers. Here's some relevant information:

1. Known ECT side effects include:
- Memory issues (both short and long-term)
- Confusion
- Headaches
- Disorientation
- Cognitive difficulties

2. Your symptoms suggest possible temporal lobe involvement:
- Déjà vu experiences
- Misidentification of faces
- False familiarity with strangers

These symptoms could be related to:
- Temporary disruption of memory circuits
- Changes in temporal lobe function
- Possible seizure-related activity

Recommendations:
1. Document these experiences in detail
2. Discuss with your psychiatrist and ECT team immediately
3. Consider neurological evaluation
4. Monitor frequency and intensity of symptoms

These symptoms, while possibly temporary, should be taken seriously and evaluated by your healthcare team, potentially including a neurologist.

Have you had any brain imaging done since these symptoms started?

146.question: 35 yo female with history of migraines as a child. MRI, ekg totally clear.Fainted a few times which caused a visit to a neurologist who was quick to diagnose with epilepsy. No longer loosing consciousness but symptoms are still present.    Wave of “feeling ill” usually nauseous    Followed by involuntary grimacing (as if I sucked on a lemon)    Slurred or slow speech 80% of the time    Feels like my brain is swollen - but only the part of my forehead    Sometimes itchy scalp    After the episode I feel like I was hit by a truck for the next few hoursDoes this sound like a seizure? Could it be something else?I refuse to take anti seizure meds without being confident and the lack of proof makes me weary of doctors who are quick to prescribe such strong meds.
146.answer:
Your symptoms could be consistent with several conditions, and while seizures are possible, other conditions should be considered:

1. Complex Migraine/Migraine with Aura
- Given your history of migraines
- Can include similar symptoms (nausea, speech changes)
- Often includes sensory symptoms
- Post-episode fatigue is common

2. Hemiplegic Migraine
- Rare type of migraine that can mimic seizures
- Can cause temporary weakness/neurological symptoms

3. Panic Attacks
- Can cause similar physical symptoms
- Often include feeling ill and neurological symptoms

4. Vasovagal Episodes
- Related to your history of fainting
- Can include similar prodromal symptoms

Suggestions:
1. Keep a detailed symptom diary
2. Consider getting a second neurological opinion
3. Ask about video EEG monitoring during episodes
4. Request further testing if needed

Your caution about anti-seizure medications is understandable. Consider:
- Seeking a second opinion
- Asking for more diagnostic testing
- Discussing alternative diagnoses with your doctor

Remember: This isn't medical advice, and you should work with healthcare professionals for proper diagnosis and treatment.

147.question: i’m 18 years old, 5’3, i don’t take any medications, i vape and smoke weed. i do cocaine, so i was driving and i felt a weird like strain in my neck on the left side, then the left side of my face went numb. my tongue went numb and my left eye felt weird. my arm went numb too. then i pulled over and my hearing started to fade. my vision started to go black and i passed out. when i was unconscious it felt very euphoric and safe, it felt like i died. and then i woke up suddenly and took a breath and i had pissed myself. my friend with me said it looked like i was having a seizure but i had never had a seizure before. while i was at the doctor my blood sugar was normal but my blood pressure was low, my ekg was normal, the doctors took blood and said nothing was wrong. what do you guys think is wrong with me
147.answer:
This is a serious medical situation that requires immediate attention. While I can't diagnose you, these symptoms could indicate several serious conditions:

1. Possible TIA (mini-stroke) or stroke
2. Seizure
3. Drug-induced medical emergency
4. Cardiovascular event

The combination of cocaine use with these symptoms is particularly concerning, as cocaine can:
- Cause blood vessel constriction
- Increase risk of stroke
- Trigger seizures
- Cause dangerous heart problems

Strong recommendations:
1. Be completely honest with your doctors about your drug use
2. Stop using cocaine immediately
3. Consider seeking addiction treatment
4. Follow up with a neurologist
5. Stop vaping/smoking as these can compound health risks

These symptoms could be life-threatening. Please take this seriously and seek comprehensive medical care. You're young and have the opportunity to prevent serious long-term health consequences by making changes now.

148.question: 18M I think it might be a form of seizure or epilepsy... I will try to be conecentrating on something and then all of a sudden i lose concentration, and when i realize and try to focus again my whole body will twitch. The twitch lasts just a second. Let me inform you that this has led to a seizure only once before (for the last 10 years) and the doctors said it was from dehydration. But the twitching won't stop, any clue what it is? It doesn't cause any pain or fatigue afterwards, just a little stress that it could have been a serious seizure like before. I don't know its happening until afterwards, and it happens everytime i try to re-focus.
148.answer:
Several possibilities could explain these symptoms:

1. Myoclonic jerks - Brief, involuntary muscle twitches that are common and usually harmless
2. Absence seizures - Brief lapses in awareness, though these typically don't involve twitching
3. Stress/anxiety-related symptoms
4. Sleep deprivation effects
5. Caffeine sensitivity

To better understand your condition, you should:

1. Keep a diary of:
- When these episodes occur
- What you're doing when they happen
- Sleep patterns
- Stress levels
- Caffeine/food intake

2. Consult a neurologist who can:
- Perform proper testing
- Rule out epilepsy
- Provide accurate diagnosis
- Recommend appropriate treatment

In the meantime:
- Stay well-hydrated
- Maintain regular sleep schedule
- Manage stress levels
- Consider reducing caffeine intake
- Don't skip meals

Since you've had a seizure before, it's important to get professional medical evaluation to ensure proper diagnosis and treatment.

Not medical advice. Please consult a healthcare provider for proper diagnosis and treatment.

149.question: My daughter is 7F, in Canada, recently diagnosed ADHD-C but not on meds yet. All vaccines up to date. She is in therapy for ADHD & anxiety management at a local kid's multidisciplinary clinic (occupational therapists, speech language pathologists, counsellors, that sort of thing.)Sleep history: she had night terrors maybe 3-4 times total during her toddler years, nothing else of note.So, after years and years of no sleep issues, my daughter has had 4 very similar "episodes" within the past 4 weeks. Here's what they look like:-episodes start <2 hours after sleep onset and seem to have distinct "phases"-phase 1: she screams for me-phase 2: she gets into a crawling position on the bed and starts violently rocking forward/back and slapping or clawing at the mattress. She'll vocalize 1-2 words or sounds as if she's trying to communicate something to me, then make a tongue clicking sound, then try again, over and over. This lasts about 1-2 minutes. She seems to be aware of my presence but can't express herself. -phase 3: she starts running to her doorway as if she's looking for something, then returning to the bed to rock and click again, though she seems more "in control" of herself than in phase 2. This lasts longer, maybe 3-5 minutes. Again, she's aware of my presence and will even talk to me sometimes.-phase 4: she stops rocking and makes a very urgent, specific, and clearly spoken request. One time, for example, it was that she desperately needed a blue marker, which she used to write "BACKE" on a poster on her wall. Another time she needed to put her blanket in the corner in the shape of a pyramid.-phase 5: once the task is completed, she is very visibly relieved, and speaking normally. She lays down again and is very twitchy/shaky. It takes her about 5 minutes to stop twitching, and then she suddenly drops asleep.-she always remembers these episodes in perfect detail the next morning. She explains it as getting a "weird" feeling in the centre of her forehead, and then she sees something in the room that isn't right, like the door frame being too small or a clone of herself standing in the room.These episodes started suddenly a few days after we returned from a trip across the country to visit family. During that visit, she had a UTI and was on 10 days of cefixime, in case that's relevant. She was always accompanied by at least one parent at all times during the trip and we didn't notice any oddness in her behaviour.Daytime behaviour is mostly normal, though she is sometimes very tired when she wakes up, and that doesn't seem connected to these episodes.We've been treating this like some sort of sleepwalking manifestation of anxiety, but I'm starting to question myself. Does this description raise any flags that suggest we should be looking into other possibilities or getting her in to see a doctor?
149.answer:
Given the specific pattern, sudden onset, and combination of symptoms you've described, it would be advisable to consult with a pediatrician or pediatric sleep specialist. Several aspects of these episodes warrant professional evaluation:

1. The structured, predictable phases suggest these might be more complex than typical sleepwalking or night terrors
2. Full recall of the episodes is unusual for parasomnia (sleep disorders)
3. The visual distortions she describes (door frame appearing wrong, seeing a clone)
4. The timing coinciding with both travel and a recent UTI/antibiotic course
5. The repetitive nature and frequency (4 times in 4 weeks)
6. The combination with her ADHD-C diagnosis

While this could be anxiety-related, the specific pattern and her full awareness/recall suggest it might be worth investigating other possibilities, such as:
- Focal seizures
- Complex partial seizures
- Medication side effects
- Sleep-related movement disorder

Given her age and recent ADHD diagnosis, it would be beneficial to have these episodes evaluated by a medical professional who can determine if further testing (like an EEG) might be warranted.

Document the episodes (video if possible) and their timing to share with healthcare providers.

150.question: 26F I'm currently talking 30mg citalopram for depression and anxiety, it definitely helps with anxiety but my depression is just getting worse. At first I thought it was due to my other health issues but I think it's from increasing dose of citalopram?? Can SSRIs make you more depressed? I've been taking it for around 4-6 months.I've been trying to get a GP appointment for a week but they're always booked up (I'm in the UK) so I'm tempted to just stop taking it until I can get one and change meds but not sure if this is safe? Maybe more safe than slowly becoming suicidalAlso I'm not sure what antidepressants to try next, I'm currently taking topirimate 50mg bidaily (hoping to increase this or might be swapping to another epilepsy med for my myoclonic jerks) so any med that has twitching as a possible side effect is a no. Also want to avoid anything that will make me tired, I have fatigue.I've tried Sertraline and fluoxetine in the past, I tried mirtazapine. Would amitripyline be a bad combo with topirimate cause I know they're both used for migraines too?
150.answer:
I understand you're going through a difficult time. Here are some important points to consider:

1. Don't stop citalopram abruptly
- This can cause withdrawal symptoms
- Can worsen depression/anxiety
- Need medical supervision to safely taper off

2. SSRIs can occasionally:
- Take 4-6 weeks to show full effect
- Need dose adjustments
- In some cases, make depression temporarily worse

3. Regarding alternatives:
- Amitriptyline with topiramate might need careful monitoring
- Consider discussing these options with your GP:
  * SNRIs (like venlafaxine)
  * Bupropion (less sedating)
  * Different SSRI combinations

4. While waiting for GP:
- Keep taking prescribed dose
- Try emergency/walk-in services if feeling suicidal
- Contact mental health crisis line
- Consider private GP services

Please seek urgent medical attention if having suicidal thoughts. NHS crisis line: 116 123 (Samaritans)

151.question: Age 5 Sex male Height 40” Weight40lb Racewhite Duration of complaint 20 months Location Colorado, USA Any existing relevant medical issues CP, epilepsy Current medications Generic keppra 2.5mg/ml 2x daily My 5 yo son with CP and epilepsy My kid is amazing and funny and smart. We learned of a perinatal stroke he had between 28-32 weeks. He was born at 33 weeks, 3 days (twin A). He has left hemiplegia, is legally blind, ambulatory, talks, etc.On 4/30/19, he had a blow out focal seizure that generalized. He was stabilized by EMS with Versed and is now on a daily generic Keppra dose that is controlling seizure activity and is doing great. He’s wonderful. I’m so proud of him. He’s such an incredible human being. The thing is, I can’t seem to get over this looming threat of another generalized seizure. I have rescue meds, I’m with he and his his twin sister all the time, but I’ve lost all sense of calm since this event. I can’t sleep through the night without checking on him repeatedly (he’s actually sleeping in our room since it happened). I have motion and sound activated cameras all over my home, as he isn’t a great fit for most seizure detecting devices. I am so worried I’m ruining his life by being so caught up in this FEAR of another big seizure. I am scared all the time. I want him to be happy. I don’t want him to stop speaking to me when he turns 18 because I am such an annoying, overbearing mom. I want him to have privacy. With COVID, I’ve gotten even more protective. We really don’t go anywhere anymore. We’ve ceased all in person therapies and remotely attend school, as I’m so scared of a fever triggering a seizure. We were hiking a lot this summer, but all the trails in my area are very busy, and we just couldn’t continue risking it. Any ped neuros/epileptologists out here, please give me some feedback. What is the likelihood of him having a breakthrough seizure out of nowhere? How can I get past this and let him just be a kid? If the seizure occurred because of his brain injury from the stroke, will it always remain controlled with the Keppra, or can that change, too? FWIW, his twin sister is also incredible and hilarious, kind and wondrous.
151.answer:
I understand you're going through a very challenging time, dealing with anxiety about your son's seizure condition. While I'm not a medical professional, I can share some general information and suggestions:

1. Your concerns are valid, but it's important to balance protection with allowing normal childhood development.

2. Consider:
- Consulting with a mental health professional to help manage your anxiety
- Discussing your concerns with your son's neurologist
- Joining support groups for parents of children with epilepsy

3. Positive signs:
- Your son is responding well to Keppra
- He's been stable since starting medication
- He has rescue medications available

4. Regarding COVID precautions:
- Consider discussing with his doctors about safe ways to resume some activities
- Look into less crowded times/locations for outdoor activities
- Explore virtual social opportunities

5. Moving forward:
- Work with his medical team to develop a clear action plan
- Gradually work on finding a balance between safety and independence
- Document triggers and patterns to help feel more in control

Would you like me to provide more specific information about any of these points?

152.question: I’m an 18 year-old male senior in high school (155 lbs, 6’0”) that has been dealing with a life-altering medical condition for what I presume to be most of my life.I’m not sure exactly when it started, but the best way I thought I could explain what I have endured and my journey through it would be starting with my symptoms. Every couple of seconds, I presume in conjunction with blood flow to my head, I get a sensation of “blanking out” almost like the entirety of my brain shuts down for a split second. If I were to look at an object for an extended period of time, every couple of seconds I would slightly lose focus of it and have to reorient myself to it, which when applied in a broader sense makes everything from my perspective seem less grounded and real. I’ve had people watch my eyes and tell me that they don’t move, so I don’t know exactly where this is coming from. Additionally, it’s almost like I cant keep track of too much at the same time because I feel like I am constantly losing focus. This affliction has affected nearly every aspect of my life, from academics, socializing, and self-acceptance in ways that you can’t imagine. It feels as if I am a fragmented version of my true self, which is just awful.I’m an effort to resolve this issue, I’ve tried nearly everything that I could think of. First I tried changing my diet. Nothing. Then my sleep and exercise habits. Nothing. Then ensuring I get every single possible vitamin or mineral that I could possibly be deficient in. Nothing. Then I went to a chiropractor for speculation that it could be an issue related to my neck. Nothing. My parents put me on anti depressants and ADD medications because as a result of my issue I exhibit some symptoms of ADD. They made me feel a little funky, but didn’t fix or change the issue at all. I went to a psychiatrist who just dismissed what I had was all in my head, and a therapist who was helpful for other aspects of life but could not offer any advice for my affliction. I convinced my parents to let me go see another chiropractor that specialized in upper cervical adjustments, as that’s what I thought could be the underlying key after all this time. After half a year of doing that, the best that it could offer was inconsistent slight alleviation of my symptoms. From this I thought that maybe I could get at least some relief from self massage and muscle release of my upper neck and head area, so I attempted probably hundreds of different stretches and exercises from every corner of the web to release any possible muscle tension or tightness that could be leading to this. Nothing. That is until about a week ago, when I noticed something peculiar when messing around with my tmj joint. If I open my jaw wide, go behind the joint right on the front of my left ear, move up to where I feel two bones connect, and push in to try to separate them for about a minute, I get a moderate amount of temporary relief. When I do this, I also get a strange warm and liquidy sensation in that joint, as well as being able to feel the blood flow from some blood vessel connected there to the inside of my head near the left far end of my mouth. The relief only lasts around 15-45 minutes, and sometimes if I push too hard my cheeks feel worse and my mental state becomes even weirder, but for some reason out of every single thing that I’ve tried this is the only maneuver that works consistently.Throughout the years I have gotten an MRI of my head, an MRA of my head, and an MRI of my cervical spine that have all supposedly come back normal, which makes no sense to me because my symptoms and sensations are reality.I’m wondering if I could possibly have an issue with a subdued artery that runs near my tmj joint that could be doing weird things to blood flow to my brain, because honestly that’s what it feels like is happening. The constant change and fluctuation in my mental status and capabilities has nearly driven me to the edge, and that coupled with what I know I could be capable of if I didn’t have such an affliction makes me horribly depressed and dare I say slightly suicidal.I know this is quite a handful and seems outright crazy and confusing from an outside perspective, but I am going again to a doctor this week to describe in detail my symptoms and how I can partially remedy them, so any insight or advice from a doctor on here on what could possibly be the cause of this or what to bring up with her would be highly appreciated. EDIT: Thank you guys for all your responses, I’ll make sure to bring up a lot of the possibilities with my physician. Even though I still don’t know the exact root cause it is incredibly relieving to know that other people are willing to offer their ideas and help after it feeling like me against the world for so long.
152.answer:
This sounds like a complex and frustrating situation you're dealing with. I understand your persistent symptoms have had a significant impact on your quality of life. Since you're seeing a doctor soon, here are some points you might want to discuss:

1. The temporal relationship between your TMJ manipulation and symptom relief
2. The possibility of:
- Vertebrobasilar insufficiency
- TMJ disorder affecting nearby blood vessels
- Vestibular disorders
- Chronic vestibular migraine
- Neurovascular compression syndromes

Be sure to:
1. Clearly describe the "blanking out" sensation and its frequency
2. Demonstrate the TMJ maneuver that provides relief
3. Mention all previous tests and treatments
4. Ask about potential referrals to:
- Neurologist
- TMJ specialist
- Vascular specialist

Given the impact on your mental health, please:
1. Continue working with mental health professionals
2. Share any suicidal thoughts with your doctor
3. Keep in mind that complex conditions often take time to diagnose

Would you like me to elaborate on any of these points?

Remember: If you have thoughts of suicide, please contact emergency services or call 988 (Suicide & Crisis Lifeline) immediately.

153.question: Female, 40, has a history of seizures but not since 2011, after surgery,  Can you feel a seizure in your head? Google says it goes from your head to other parts of your body, but could someone feel it happen inside their head? Why don't all seizures show up on eeg? Is it possible to not notice or feel having a seizure but suddenly have the feeling like you had one? If there is an article that explains all this, I would love to read it. Thanks in advance!
153.answer:
I'll break this down into parts:

1. Feeling seizures in your head:
- Yes, some people can feel seizures starting in their head
- These sensations are called "auras" and can include:
  * Strange tastes or smells
  * Déjà vu
  * Rising sensation in stomach
  * Visual disturbances
  * Headache
  * Dizziness

2. Why don't all seizures show on EEG:
- EEG only records electrical activity near the surface of the brain
- Deeper seizure activity may not be detected
- Timing matters - seizure must occur during EEG recording
- Some seizures affect small areas that might be missed by standard EEG placement

3. Not noticing seizures:
- Yes, it's possible to have seizures without being aware (absence seizures or focal seizures)
- Post-ictal confusion (after seizure) can make people forget the event
- Some people only realize they had a seizure through:
  * Unexplained injuries
  * Missing time
  * Witness accounts
  * Feeling unusually tired

For detailed information, these are reliable sources:
- Epilepsy Foundation: www.epilepsy.com
- Johns Hopkins Medicine: www.hopkinsmedicine.org/health/conditions-and-diseases/epilepsy
- NINDS (National Institute of Neurological Disorders and Stroke): www.ninds.nih.gov/health-information/disorders/epilepsy

154.question: Hey all, I am a 30 yo white male. I am currently 270 pounds and 5'9. Active and fairly healthy. Meds: Keppra (1000mg x2 daily, Prozac 40mg 1x Daily, Clonazepam .5mg x2 daily, Meloxicam 15mg 1x daily, Fish Oil, Vitamin D, Vitamin C Supplements) I had mono when i was 17 that developed into GBS. I had weakness, druken gate, and slurred speech and my main symptoms. Symptoms resolved in approx. 6 months and i was going back to normal. Shortly there after i started with seizures, one in November 2009, again in February 2010. I have been on Keppra since and been seizure free. I also have auto immune disease. One diagnosed, Hidradenitis Supperativa (doing well), and one undiagnosed. The undiagnosed one is more recently been bothering me.. i have Episcleritis and joint pain.. High ESR and CRP in the blood. I am worried about covid and want the vax but am afraid because i had a neurological reaction to the flu shot after my GBS. My Neurologist is insisting i get the vax and im talking to my Rheumi tomorrow. Is there anybody who can give me insight on what i should consider? Thank you!
154.answer:
Given your complex medical history, especially with GBS and autoimmune conditions, your concern about the COVID-19 vaccine is understandable. Here are some points to consider:

1. Current Research:
- Studies have shown no increased risk of GBS recurrence with COVID-19 vaccines
- The risk of complications from COVID-19 infection may be higher for people with autoimmune conditions

2. Important Considerations:
- Your history of neurological reaction to flu vaccine
- Your multiple autoimmune conditions
- Being on immunomodulating medications
- Your weight puts you in a higher risk category for COVID-19 complications

3. Recommendations:
- Discuss specific vaccine options with your rheumatologist
- Consider getting the vaccine in a medical setting where you can be monitored
- Ask about spacing out doses if approved
- Consider antibody testing before vaccination

4. Questions for your doctors:
- Which vaccine type would be safest given your history?
- What monitoring protocol would they recommend?
- What specific signs/symptoms should you watch for?

Remember: The final decision should be made in consultation with your healthcare team, weighing your individual risks and benefits.

155.question: Medical professionals are calling my bf's symptoms panic attacks, but I'm convinced he needs a neurologist. I'm a research scientist in mental health (i.e. not a doctor), and my gut keeps telling me something is very wrong. What do you think?Bf is currently experiencing “panic attacks” that he barely remembers after they finish. They last 3-6 hours, occur on more than half of the days in a week, and are characterized by extreme anxiety and neurological symptoms such as loss of balance, slurred and slowed speech, mental confusion, memory loss, rapid eye saccades side to side, fainting, and vomiting.Background: He has a history of childhood abuse and neglect and in general hasn't seen doctors in his lifetime. Before this started, he had no known conditions but did have a history of anxios and depressive symptoms since adolescence. He's of south asian descent, 5'10, aprox 150lbs, is on 100mg of lyrica, smokes nicotine (~10 cigarettes a day), 4-7 drinks a week, no other drug use. Early 2021 - Symptoms begin: He started losing his balance and slurring his speech in the last year, usually either after something extremely stressful (covid and unemployment really got to him) combined with having a beer or two. I thought it was his alcohol tolerance changing with age, so I wasn't too worried. He had several bad falls because of this, broke his glasses twice, needed stitches, etc... stressful but not concerning.  June 2021 - Symptoms worsen: He finally got a job in April, he was super happy. It was a bit stressful and outside his field and had a huge learning curve, but he loved it. But he started losing his balance and slurring his speech more often, even when he hadn't had a drop of alcohol. He also started having full blown panic attacks, where he couldn't breathe, would vomit repeatedly, thought he was dying... I used grounding and breathing techniques to help him through July 2021 - Psychiatric emergency room: In early July, he couldn't keep food down for 6 days straight and alternated crying and panic attacks. The slurred speech and loss of balance continued. I took him to psychiatric emergency in my city where he was diagnosed with an anxiety disorder and put on a low dose (25mg) of seroquel/quetiapine. He was put on sick leave from his job. He was matched with a local psychiatrist, so switched him from seroquel to 50 mg lyrica (gabapentin pregabalin~~)~~ that eventually increased to 150mg. August 2021 - Regular emergency room: Worst night. After feeling suicidal for the first time in years, he suddenly crashed face first into our shoe rack. Busted his nose open, black eye, full shebang. He was on his back and semi conscious, and couldn't speak. No asymmetry in smile etc but 911 operator and ambulance both suspected a stroke.
