213.question: 24F In less than a month, 5’4”, 114 lb, white. Marina, and occasional Tylenol. 9 months Postpartum, Arthritis, Depression, and Anxiety. No other drugs, or conditions. I’ve been having seizure like things for about 4 months, the Dr’s are confused by the full list of the symptoms, but believe they are seizures. It started with dizziness 6 months ago. So they want me to come in for observation with an EEG running on me for up to 5 days. See what can be crossed out from it. The last two EEG’s showed nothing. ( a 30 min & and 2 hour one.) So what should I expect going in? What types of tests do you do on someone after Epilepsy is ruled out? What other options are there? I’m scared.. I’m a new mom, and some days I’m terrified to care for my baby.. Now I have to leave her for days. Full list of symptoms Stage 1- The warning stage: I feel like how you feel going in an elevator (how different parts of you are moving at different speeds) with my head/ brain mixed with a non painful head smack. I start loosing the ability to talk, and my legs start collapsing Stage 2- In the episode: I keep consciousness, loose all motor control and look dead. My mouth opens up, and I slosh to a side. My eye lids flutter, pupils dilate, and my eyes shift around in all directions. I can hear, see and think. I just can’t move. Lasts between a 10 seconds to a minute or so Stage 3- Recovery: Varies based on severity and how many I have had in succession. Which has been up to 8 or more back to back. Then I have confusion, stuttering, and muscle weakness. As well as occasionally stabbing pain inside bones down one of my arms. Which arm is not constant. I can have 3-50 a day, and some days. If I am lucky I wont have any. I get them a lot dealing with baby, but sometimes when I am alone or asleep (I can tell because if I wake up after having them I have to walk on my knees so I don’t fall. Too weak otherwise.) And I’m slowly getting more permanent symptoms like a slight stutter, memory issues, and difficulty finding words. Example A, I didn’t have any “episodes” yesterday, but couldn’t get the word bacon out, and then I forgot the word entirely. I have also forgotten pumping out more milk than usual for baby, and thought I had nothing. Apparently I was extremely exited. I’m not expecting a diagnosis, just any information would be lovely. Also anything your patients did to pass the time would be nice. Other tips for this. Also if you have any ideas of something I should bring up to the Dr’s that they might not be considering as an option.
213.answer:
Given your complex symptoms, here are some thoughts and suggestions:

For the hospital stay:
- Bring comfortable clothes, entertainment (books, tablet, etc.)
- Personal hygiene items
- Snacks (if allowed)
- Photos of your baby to help with the separation
- Phone charger
- Something to document your symptoms/experiences

Possible conditions to discuss with doctors:
1. PNES (Psychogenic Non-Epileptic Seizures)
2. Vestibular disorders
3. Postpartum dysautonomia
4. Conversion disorder
5. Multiple sclerosis
6. Postpartum thyroid issues
7. Autoimmune conditions
8. POTS (Postural Orthostatic Tachycardia Syndrome)

Tests they might consider:
- Tilt table test
- MRI with contrast
- Thyroid panel
- Autoimmune panels
- Vestibular testing
- Neuropsychological evaluation
- Blood pressure monitoring

Questions to ask:
1. Could postpartum hormones be contributing?
2. Should you see a neurologist specializing in movement disorders?
3. Could anxiety be amplifying symptoms?
4. Are there any medication interactions?

Remember to:
- Keep a detailed symptom diary
- Note triggers or patterns
- Record videos of episodes (if possible)
- Document time of day/circumstances

This must be incredibly challenging as a new mom. Consider asking for a mental health referral to help cope with the stress and anxiety this is causing.

214.question: Height: 5'5" Weight: 140 Race: White Drinking/smoking/recreational drugs: No Medications: Adderall (10mg)I had left temporal lobe epilepsy as a child; from 7 weeks of age to about a year I was having 4-5 grand mal seizures a day. From about 1-2 I had one or two drop seizures a week. During early childhood I also had several complex partial seizures a week. My last EEG until just recently was at about 14 ¬— at that point I still had "slowing in the left temporal lobe." My recent EEG was completely normal.I've been trying to figure out how much of my current difficulty functioning (including difficulty with concentration, fatigue, anxiety, depression, and memory issues) are more tied to PTSD or remnants of damage done by all the seizures. As far as I know, I haven't had seizures in many years. The PTSD is tied to a number of events both as a child and as an adult.I was also knocked unconscious once at about 14, in a riding accident. My helmet cracked all the way through (back of the head), but I wasn't out for very long. Maybe less than a minute. I never went to a doctor for it.If PTSD is playing a big part in my difficulties, a stellate ganglion block is an option I'm interested in investigating more... but it won't help me if my issues are long-term consequences of all those seizures.Who would best be able to help me figure out what to do? I could consult a neurologist, or get a comprehensive evaluation by neuropsych. The department that mentions doing nerve blocks is the pain center. I can't afford to keeping piling on medical bills, so I'd appreciate any insight on who would be most likely to be able to help, and also on what kind of long-term consequences one might expect to see from my sort of seizure history. (And how likely is it that I'm just in the clear now, as far as epilepsy goes?) Thanks for reading. I have been seeing a therapist, but as an LCSW she can't really speak to the MD side of these issues. I can't keep going like this.
214.answer:
Based on your complex medical history, here's my analysis:

1. A neuropsychological evaluation would likely be most beneficial as your first step because it can:
- Assess cognitive functions comprehensively
- Help differentiate between neurological and psychological causes
- Provide objective data about any lasting effects from seizures
- Guide treatment decisions

2. The multiple factors that could be contributing to your symptoms include:
- Early childhood seizures and potential developmental impacts
- Traumatic brain injury from the riding accident
- PTSD
- Possible continued subclinical seizure activity

3. Long-term consequences of early childhood seizures can include:
- Memory issues
- Attention/concentration difficulties
- Processing speed changes
- Anxiety and depression
- Fatigue

4. Regarding your epilepsy prognosis:
- A normal EEG is very positive
- However, given your extensive early history, continued neurological monitoring would be prudent

Recommendation:
Start with a neuropsychological evaluation, as this will provide the most comprehensive assessment and can help direct further treatment decisions, whether neurological or psychological.

This approach would be most cost-effective as it can guide more targeted interventions rather than pursuing multiple specialists simultaneously.

215.question: Hello! I saw on the internet that occasionally some epilepsy medications such as Lamictal can react to HRT. This reaction can cause an increase in seizure activity. That of course is not my specific question.My question is does Depakote 1000mg therapeutic level, and Keppra 1000mg once at night reactive towards HRT treatments. As I am considering going through the process of transferring my gender from male to female via HRT treatments and I am rather worried that this may cause an increase in my seizures.My seizure disorder is: Juvenile Myoclonic EpilepsyDrugs I currently take: 1 1000mg Depakote pill in the AM, 1 1000mg Depakote pill in the PM, 1 1000mg Keppra pill at night. 1 Calcium/Zinc/Magnesium supplement pill in the AM, 1 Vitamin D pill in the AM. 1 3mg meletonin pill prior to bed. 10mg of Adderal when needed.Epileptic triggers: Sleep, anxiety.
215.answer:
I need to be clear that I cannot provide specific medical advice about drug interactions, as these can be complex and potentially serious. This is a discussion you should have with your neurologist and endocrinologist, as they can:

1. Review your specific medical history
2. Consider potential drug interactions
3. Monitor your levels during transition
4. Adjust medications as needed

However, I can share some general information:

- Hormone therapy can affect how the body processes anti-epileptic drugs (AEDs)
- Some AEDs may affect hormone levels
- Regular monitoring of both hormone and AED levels is typically necessary
- Many people successfully manage both epilepsy and HRT with proper medical supervision

Important steps you can take:
1. Consult with both your neurologist and a gender-affirming care provider
2. Have them coordinate your care
3. Consider keeping a detailed seizure diary during transition
4. Report any changes in seizure patterns promptly

Your healthcare providers can develop a personalized plan that safely manages both your epilepsy and transition goals.

216.question: Sex: Female Age: 21 Location: Europe Diagnose: Epilepsy (diagnosed two years ago) Medication: Timonil retard, MedotriginHello. It is very hard to describe, but I will do my best. I have been having some problems.It started about two years ago. It just appeared out of nowhere. My world started looking weird. Everything I saw was like in a movie or dream, everything was moving so slow and colours were just strange. I could see things happening around me, I heard people talking and everything, but I couldn't react. It just seemed so hard. It happened very often, it usually lasted for a few hours and after these "episodes" I became too tired, so during these days I slept for like 15 hours a day. When I fainted, my mum made me go to doctor. I underwent MRI and EEG. The results were great, the doctors saw nothing. But after my complaining, I was diagnosed with epilepsy with absence seizures. I got mediacation, first only medotrigin, which I still take twice a day. It helped, but only for a short time, so my doctor gave me another pills, timonil (once a day). But that didn't help either. I need to visit my doctor every 3 months when I undergo EEG exam. The results are always good, so my doctor doesn't seem to believe me.The thing is that my condition has gotten way worse in the past 2-3 months. These "episodes" happen very often, almost every day and they again take hours, sometimes even longer than before. I am very sensitive to light and noise, I can't even work normally. I am scared of doing anything because sometimes it happens that I just start looking at something and suddenly I stop reacting, people just talk to me and I don't respond. And sometimes I even don't remember anything. I got depressive and I cry a lot because I can't live like this. Is it really just epilepsy?
216.answer:
Based on your description, while you have been diagnosed with epilepsy, your symptoms could be consistent with several conditions, and it might be worth exploring these with healthcare providers:

1. Depersonalization/Derealization Disorder (DPDR):
- Your description of the world looking unreal or dream-like
- Feeling disconnected from your surroundings
- Altered perception of time and colors
- These symptoms lasting for hours

2. Temporal Lobe Epilepsy:
- Can cause altered consciousness
- Can include sensory changes
- Memory gaps
- Sensitivity to light and sound

3. Complex Partial Seizures:
- Can cause altered awareness
- Episodes can last longer than typical absence seizures
- Can include memory gaps

Recommendations:
1. Seek a second opinion from another neurologist
2. Consider consulting a psychiatrist (as DPDR can co-exist with epilepsy)
3. Keep a detailed diary of your episodes
4. Request video EEG monitoring for longer periods
5. Consider testing for other underlying conditions

Your symptoms are significantly impacting your quality of life, and you deserve to have them taken seriously. Please advocate for yourself and seek additional medical opinions if needed.

Would you like me to provide more specific information about any of these conditions or recommendations?

217.question: So over the last 10 years, I have had ongoing fainting episodes with no real answers. I have been mostly evaluated by cardiologists who say it is vasovagal but no trigger has been identified. I have an implanted loop recorder which shows my heart slowing and then pausing. The pauses last anywhere from 5-13 seconds. Before the episode, I do get a “warning” which helps me get into a safer (usually) position. I get a really strong sense of deja vu and everything feels really surreal and like it has happened before even though I know it hasn’t. I regain consciousness pretty quickly but have a range of issues for the next few hours/day including being foggy headed, bad short term memory over the next hour or so, getting cold, digestive issues etc. not to mention it worries the people around me :)Mostly these episodes have occurred when I’ve been sitting however in the last 6-12 months they have started occurring while I’ve been in different positions (sleeping while laying flat and most recently while standing.) The frequency has also started to increase and I feel like my memory is getting worse as well. It’s always been a bit of an issue but it seems like I am forgetting more and more “medium range” events/things. Like things that have occurred in the past few months/years or things people have told me in the past few weeks. In the beginning these episodes were occurring once every six months but now they are coming as close as 4 weeks apart which an average of every second month. There seems to be an underlying pattern of these episodes occurring in the week before my period and sometimes when I have been dealing with stressful situations. I do manage my stress through meditation, gym,counseling etc and don’t feel like I am acutely stressed when I have these episodes.The cardiologists I’ve seen have advised that I should drink a lot of water and make sure I get up from my desk and walk around every 30 minutes or so. I have taken their advice but my condition just seems to be slowly getting worse and now they want to talk about a pacemaker. I’ve had another episode today and am feeling very frustrated and like my doctors aren’t listening to me.I am pretty fitness minded so I have a sit/stand desk and a water bottle with measurements to see how much water I’ve drank. Today, I was standing when I had the episode and had just been walking around . I had drank over 1 liter of water, eaten breakfast and lunch with a snack and it was approximately 2pm. I do not at all get the feeling that this is related to my water intake or sitting/standing. I have a referral to a neurologist (10 years ago I saw a neurologist but was told it was cardiac related) but have to wait two more months for the appointment. I guess I’m just wondering if any of the doctors out there could provide me with any insights or ideas to give me some comfort during the next two months? Could this be a form of temporal lobe epilepsy or something related to hormones? I have read some research papers saying that sinus pauses are an atypical symptom of epilepsy but that it does happen? Anyway, thanks in advance, anything is really appreciated!
217.answer:
Based on your detailed description, there are several aspects that suggest this might be more complex than simple vasovagal syncope:

1. The strong déjà vu sensation and feeling of unreality before episodes
2. Memory issues (both short and medium-term)
3. Post-episode symptoms
4. The pattern related to menstrual cycle
5. Increasing frequency of episodes
6. Occurrence in various positions
7. Cardiac pauses (which could be primary or secondary)

These symptoms, particularly the déjà vu and memory issues, could indeed suggest temporal lobe involvement. Some possibilities to consider:

1. Temporal Lobe Epilepsy (TLE):
- The déjà vu, memory issues, and autonomic symptoms fit
- Can cause ictal bradycardia and asystole
- Often has a hormonal connection

2. Autonomic dysfunction:
- Could explain the cardiac pauses
- May have hormonal influences
- Can worsen over time

While waiting for your neurology appointment:

1. Keep a detailed diary of:
- Episodes (time, position, activities)
- Menstrual cycle
- Sleep patterns
- Stress levels
- What you ate/drank
- Any triggers you notice

2. If possible, have someone video record an episode

3. Consider asking for:
- EEG monitoring
- Brain MRI if not done recently
- Hormonal workup
- Autonomic function testing

It's reasonable to seek a second opinion and push for a more comprehensive evaluation beyond just the cardiac aspect.

218.question: Female, 20, 5"7", 250lbs, CaucasianNo drug use, no current medication,For the past 6 years I've been having what I think is sleep paralysis fits, the symptoms are like this:I have a weird feeling before sleeping, I can't describe it but when i feel it i know i'm gonna fall into sleep paralysis. then I can't move anything, i'm aware of of my surroundings, scary ominous aura, and sometimes theres this loud ringing, like so loud I feel it in my head pulsing, then pain in my body like fingers being pushed in my sides, and even i sometimes feel my body...buzzing? or shaking fast i dont know if its happening IRL or just in my sleep, or a part of my brain feels like electricity, its usually painful, but there was one time it felt...kinda not bad...like a brain massage, then it went down my back. I don't know how to describe it... it was non painful once, other than that it's usually painful. and I sometimes...float out of my body....like i see from a different view. and occasionally hear voices, if i slip into a scary fit, It's sometimes growling or a loud high pitched whistle. muscle pains, and I can feel my mouth moving while its happening, like if i try to speak. and I sometimes feel like I'm spiralingthen after all of that I usually wake up feeling drained and sore, and my head is foggy and feels like i'm lagging behind a bit. it stays with me the entire day, I can power through it now that I'm older, but when I was a teenager it dragged me down, and I had to post-pone daily activities because of the after effects. it comes in bouts, like some months it'll happen for at least 2 weeks, then disappear for a little, then come back.  usually for me I think being sleep deprived is a trigger for it, I used to stay awake for days at a time because of it, it was a cycle, be sleep deprived> trigger it> be afraid to sleep so i force myself to stay awake> be sleep deprived> trigger it. but recently it was under control, but I stood up a 4 hours past my usual sleeping time and it happened. and I always sleep on my side, and may have undiagnosed sleep apnea, so I sleep elevated.it's been making my life really hard...I'd almost gone a week without it happening.....l just woke up from one and my neck feels sore, I usually dismiss this as sleep paralysis but after thinking about the "brain electric feeling" and I'm scared, sleep paralysis isn't dangerous, but if I'm having seizures it's dangerous isn't it? I can't go to a doctor right now, because I have no healthcare, and I live with immunocompromised family members, so I can't go as much as I would like to, I can't risk it because of covid. any advice would be helpful....I'm sorry for being all over the place and writing so messy, I'm kinda foggy right now....Thank you for reading,
218.answer:
Based on your description, you appear to be experiencing a combination of sleep paralysis and possibly other sleep-related phenomena. Here's a breakdown:

1. Sleep Paralysis:
- Inability to move
- Awareness of surroundings
- Feeling of presence/ominous aura
- Auditory and sensory hallucinations
- Out-of-body experiences

2. Additional symptoms suggesting possible:
- Hypnagogic seizures
- Sleep-related migraine
- Narcolepsy
- Sleep apnea

Recommendations:

1. Immediate steps:
- Establish a regular sleep schedule
- Sleep on your side
- Avoid sleep deprivation
- Practice good sleep hygiene
- Consider using a sleep tracker app

2. When possible, seek medical attention:
- Consider telehealth options
- Look into sliding scale clinics
- Explore free/low-cost health clinics
- Consider sleep study when feasible

While sleep paralysis itself isn't dangerous, some of your symptoms (especially the electrical sensations) should be evaluated by a healthcare provider when possible. In the meantime, maintain a sleep diary to track episodes and triggers.

Alert: If symptoms worsen significantly or you experience new concerning symptoms, seek emergency care despite COVID concerns.

219.question: Male 18 75kg 6ft black I started having these episodes last December. So basically it lasts about 5-10seconds and it's where I do something normal and then I recognize soenthing (like deja Vu) then shortly after my head begins to hurt and I get really dizzy and it brings me to a memory (it's the same memory when I always get these episodes) and then after 10 second me have gone I completely forget what that memory was. Now that is not what concerns me. But I've had this other type and I've had it twice so far..The first time maybe in May..and I wake up for work and I feel completely dazzed off..but then I'm okay..dad drives us into work and then I get so nauseous..I go home and I take a nap..I'm okay.. The next day my co worker tells me that he saw me and I told him I didn't recognize him and that I didn't know what to do..(I kind of remember it but not really).Now the reason why I'm writing this is because I had a crash recently and I woke up feeling that exact same way..I go to work and I'm with my mum and we crash into a wall and the car is totalled.. I remember 5minutes before the crash and I remember 5seconds being in the ambulance and a bit in hospital but my memory of the past week before that went.. I can remember bits of the previous week but it's not all there..I came out of the crash uninjured and same with the family.I take no medication I drink and social smoke like every 2 weeks with my friends.Had a panicked attack at work Thursday and had to go home cause I started crying thinking I have a tumor in my brain or epilepsy or something...and a friend suggested it could be an aura epilepsy..
219.answer:
Based on your symptoms, you should seek immediate medical attention. These episodes could be consistent with several neurological conditions, including but not limited to:

1. Temporal lobe epilepsy (which can cause déjà vu, memory issues, and altered consciousness)
2. Migraine with aura
3. Post-concussion syndrome (especially given the recent crash)

Concerning symptoms include:
- Recurring episodes of déjà vu with headache
- Memory loss
- Periods of confusion/disorientation
- Changes in consciousness
- Nausea
- Dizziness

Important next steps:
1. See a neurologist as soon as possible
2. Consider getting an EEG and brain imaging (MRI/CT)
3. Keep a detailed diary of these episodes
4. Avoid driving until cleared by a doctor
5. Reduce alcohol consumption and smoking as these can affect neurological symptoms

This is not something to ignore or self-diagnose. A proper medical evaluation is essential for your safety and well-being, especially given the recent car accident and ongoing symptoms.

220.question: I am 30F, 5'1", 110lbs, caucasian. I have hypothyroidism (Hashimoto's) and I take Synthroid 88mcg/daily. I was 21 the first time I fainted on an airplane, it's happened 6+ times in the air since. I have also fainted on land in various situations starting around age 13.My primary issue is fainting on airplanes, particularly long-haul flights. I have a 14 hour flight coming up and will be traveling alone so thought I'd ask here for advice, prevention methods, etc. What usually happens is I get suddenly very dizzy, hot and clammy, my ears start ringing loudly and then I pass out. I'll wake up about a minute later surrounded by concerned flight attendants and passengers. I've always been seated, although several times it's happened immediately after waking up. Sometimes the flight attendants bring me juice or water, or they ask the captain to turn the cabin temperature down. Afterward I feel pretty tired and shaky for the rest of the day.The most recent time this happened (about 6 months ago), I was sitting next to a nurse who woke me up with a sternum rub. She suggested I get checked for diabetes. Other people have said to get checked for epilepsy.I've seen my GP as well as specialists - neurologist, cardiologist, endocrinologist. They ruled out epilepsy, heart condition, or diabetes. Normal tests results across the board.As for the maybe 10+ times I've fainted while not on an airplane, it's usually been attributed to heat, dehydration, period pain, or not eating. I struggled with disordered eating as a teenager (never diagnosed but definitely an issue; I eat well and frequently now). Doctors have said "drink more water", "eat more salt", and (my favorite) "sometimes girls faint"  Here's are some things I do to help with flying:- wear compression socks- no coffee day of, no alcohol in the week leading up- eat salt tablets periodically throughout flight- drink about 64 oz of water while in the air (depending on length of the flight)-regular, filling meals the night before and day of the flightI'd love to hear any insight into fainting, what might be causing it, or advice on how to prevent it in the air. It's so embarrassing and it makes me anxious to fly. Thank you so much for any input!!
220.answer:
Based on your description, this sounds like it could be Vasovagal Syncope, which is the most common cause of fainting. The symptoms you describe (feeling hot, dizzy, clammy before fainting) are typical of this condition. The triggers you mentioned (heat, dehydration, pain) are also common triggers for vasovagal episodes.

On airplanes specifically, several factors can increase the risk:
- Lower cabin pressure and oxygen levels
- Prolonged sitting
- Dehydration from dry cabin air
- Disrupted sleep patterns

Your current prevention strategies are good. Here are additional suggestions:

1. Medical:
- Consider asking your doctor about midodrine or other medications that can help prevent fainting
- Ensure your thyroid levels are well-controlled, as thyroid issues can affect blood pressure

2. During flight:
- Do frequent leg exercises in your seat
- Get up and walk when possible (every 2-3 hours)
- Consider an aisle seat for easier movement
- Alert flight attendants about your condition before takeoff
- Keep a small fan for air circulation
- Consider wearing a medical alert bracelet

3. Prevention:
- Increase salt intake 24-48 hours before flight
- Practice counter-pressure maneuvers (tensing legs, crossing ankles)
- Try to maintain regular sleep schedule before travel
- Consider wearing an abdominal binder

You might want to ask your doctor about tilt-table testing to confirm if it's vasovagal syncope and discuss specific treatment options.

221.question: When I came down with epilepsy in 2010, I began having a strange change in energy level. At first I thought it was just the medication, but when I go on r/epilepsy and explain it, nobody responds. I don't think they are experiencing the same thing, even though most of them take keppra like I do.Basically, I was going through a big weight loss leading up to the epilepsy. I lost 65 pounds. I would go to the gym for 1 - 1.5 hours and do 20 mile hikes on the weekends. Things were looking up. I even got a new relationship and was about to start a new career in EMS.Then I woke up in the hospital. I had a huge seizure in my sleep and my wife saved my life. I lost my future career and even my job, because I lost my license.So once things stabilized a bit, I tried to reestablish my habits. I found that I had no energy at the gym. After 15 min working out, I would feel like I was going to literally pass out. I would feel this way on short hikes, too.Over time, I was discouraged by my sudden change in performance to where I was less and less motivated. I literally couldn't exercise. I gradually gained all the weight back. If I explain any of this to a doctor now, they will just kind of roll their eyes at me. They think I lost my energy because I'm fat, not the other way around. They don't care to listen.I've been researching a little into leaky gut etc but I think it's hard because people are barely scratching the surface. Do I have seizures because of autoimmune disease?
221.answer:
I understand your frustration, and it's valid to question the connection between your epilepsy, energy levels, and overall health. While I can't diagnose you, I can share some relevant information:

1. The connection between epilepsy and fatigue:
- Post-ictal fatigue (after seizures) is common
- Many people with epilepsy report chronic fatigue
- Research suggests epilepsy can affect mitochondrial function (energy production in cells)

2. Medication effects:
- Keppra (levetiracetam) can cause fatigue as a side effect
- Some anti-epileptic drugs can affect metabolism

3. Autoimmune connections:
- There are known autoimmune epilepsies
- Some research suggests gut health may influence both seizures and energy levels
- Inflammation can play a role in both epilepsy and fatigue

Suggestions:
1. Seek a neurologist who specializes in epilepsy (epileptologist)
2. Request testing for autoimmune markers
3. Consider keeping a detailed symptom diary
4. Look into getting a second opinion

Your experience sounds valid and deserves proper medical attention. The relationship between exercise intolerance and epilepsy is complex and not fully understood by many healthcare providers.

222.question: 25F - Last week I laughing gas at the dentist for the time, next day I had an episode with seizure-like movements, hyperventilating and was unable to move or speak. Ever since I’ve been experiencing “freezes” and difficulty processing. Waiting for neurologist appt.Last Tuesday, I had a filling done at the dentist and they gave me laughing gas the first time. It hit me pretty hard - I was given oxygen for 10 mins after and could still barely walk or talk. It took several hours for it to wear off. Wednesday morning, I felt completely fine. Around 1pm, I suddenly felt really bad - extremely nauseous, hot, and faint. Starting writing a simple email and just could not make sense of any of my thoughts or even string a sentence together - very strange feeling of nothing making sense, like I was in a dream. Had real difficulty moving my hands on the keyboard and could not coordinate my fingers to even type properly. My head kept falling back involuntarily. I was going to tell my boss I felt bad, next thing I know I’m sitting on the floor hyperventilating. According to my coworkers, I slammed my hands down on my desk and pushed myself backwards in my chair against the back of my cubicle, and was taking big loud gasping breaths as if I was choking. They helped me to the floor - I don’t remember this. They called 911 because they thought I was having a seizure. I was on the floor for 20 mins hyperventilating - I was aware of others around me but could not shift my gaze from the corner of the ceiling. I also could not move or talk. Paramedics came and took vitals and everything was fine apart from elevated heart rate. Went to the ER, they took bloods, EKG and head CT and all came back clear. Dr said it could be seizure but unlikely, or just a bad reaction to the laughing gas. He referred me to a neurologist for more testing. Basically every day since, I’ve had daily moments of “freezing” which last 10-20 secs. One time I was eating a sandwich, talking to my husband and my body just froze up and I was unable to speak and just felt completely blank and frozen - unable to speak and shift my gaze. Another time we were walking through target and my legs got really weak and locked up, and I felt an “aura” feeling, was unable to speak and just felt completely stuck and removed from reality. I’ve also noticed difficulty processing people talking to me - I’ve been having about 5 second “lags” which isn’t normal for me. Any idea what this could be? FYI no personal history of panic attacks or any anxiety, no family history of seizures, neurological issues etc.
222.answer:
This sounds like a concerning situation that requires medical attention, which you're already seeking with a neurologist - that's good. While I can't diagnose you, I can share some relevant information:

Your symptoms could potentially be related to:

1. Delayed reaction to nitrous oxide (laughing gas):
- Can occasionally cause neurological symptoms
- May deplete vitamin B12 levels, which can cause neurological issues

2. Possible seizure activity:
- Your "freezing" episodes could be focal seizures
- The initial episode has some characteristics of a complex partial seizure

3. Non-epileptic seizures (PNES):
- Can be triggered by stressful events
- Present similarly to epileptic seizures

Important steps you're already taking:
- Seeing a neurologist
- Getting medical attention promptly
- Documenting your symptoms

Suggestions while waiting for your appointment:
1. Keep a detailed log of episodes
2. Have someone video record an episode if possible
3. Avoid driving until cleared by your doctor
4. Consider having someone stay with you

Seek immediate medical attention if:
- Episodes become more frequent/severe
- You develop new concerning symptoms
- You feel unsafe

These symptoms warrant thorough neurological evaluation, which you're pursuing. Make sure to tell your neurologist about all details of the initial dental visit and subsequent symptoms.

223.question: I suffered from this as a baby (parents said I almost died at birth and they had to put me in really cool environments and use ice at the hospital since I had low oxygen at birth. For a few weeks I was on some baby monitor ( I was also a c section) did a bit of searching online but couldn't find much discussion about this.About me currently Im a 28 year old Male 28M , the birth asphyxia obviously happened during birthAre there things happening during birth asphyxia that could leads to other issues? I suffer from ADHD or ADD which makes me wonder if this came from birth asphyxia and I have definitely had reactions to strong flashing lights when I was a teenager (still do a bit) i read that seizures could be a complication from birth asphyixia.
223.answer:
Birth asphyxia (also called perinatal asphyxia) can indeed have long-term effects on development and health. Here are some key points about birth asphyxia and its potential consequences:

Possible long-term effects:

1. Neurodevelopmental issues:
- ADHD/ADD
- Learning disabilities
- Processing disorders
- Memory problems
- Executive function difficulties

2. Neurological conditions:
- Seizure disorders
- Epilepsy
- Sensitivity to lights (photosensitivity)
- Motor control issues

3. Other potential impacts:
- Behavioral challenges
- Speech delays
- Vision problems
- Hearing issues

Research has shown connections between:
- Birth asphyxia and ADHD
- Oxygen deprivation and seizure susceptibility
- Perinatal complications and various neurodevelopmental disorders

If you're concerned, consider:
1. Discussing your birth history with your healthcare provider
2. Getting a neurological evaluation if needed
3. Working with specialists to manage specific symptoms

Remember that many people who experienced birth asphyxia develop normally with no significant long-term effects, but monitoring and appropriate support can be helpful.

224.question: Age – 25 Sex – Male Height - 183cm 6ft Weight - 92kg 200lb Race – Caucasian Duration - Last 3 months Symptoms ive experienced over the last 3 months Around 2months ago i was experiencing Phantom smells, brief periods of 3-4second smells; started off as a blood smell and then startedto get them more frequently and smells were sometimes oranges/flowers. I Have since had an EEG that said i had no Temporal Lobe Epilepsy. I've not had these smells for a few weeks in the last 2 weeks i have started to notice eye floaters that follow where my eye goes only in sunlight. I have also noticed Bright flashing lights from the outter right corner of my eye. Some less worrying symptoms i have had. Sometimes 1 ear will get a high pitch noise that starts loud and fades out Muscle twitching hadaches sometimes. nothing severe Lightheadedness that may be related to anxiety/ or my low iron Sometimes cant think of the word i was thinking of or lose train of thought. Feel like im staring through what im looking at, kinda get daydreamy i guess? Also i do have a front tooth that is decaying / has a hole between the front and front right I have Severe anxiety and depression; and have been through a period of very high stress the last 3 months after breaking up with my long term partner. Is it possible that stress can do all these things to the body... my GP dosent seem worried about brain tumours but i am.
224.answer:
Based on the symptoms you've described, it's understandable why you're concerned. Let me break this down:

Your symptoms could indeed be largely related to stress and anxiety, which can cause many physical symptoms. Here's why:

1. Stress-related symptoms:
- Phantom smells (phantosmia)
- Muscle twitches
- Headaches
- Lightheadedness
- Brain fog/difficulty finding words
- Dissociation ("staring through things")

2. Normal/Common phenomena:
- Eye floaters (especially visible in sunlight)
- Tinnitus (high-pitched noise in ears)
- Brief memory lapses

Important points:
- The clean EEG is reassuring
- Your GP's lack of concern is positive
- The timing coinciding with high stress/breakup is significant
- Your existing anxiety/depression can amplify physical symptoms

Potential contributing factors:
- Low iron levels
- Dental infection (decaying tooth)
- Severe anxiety
- Depression
- Recent emotional trauma

Recommendations:
1. Address dental issues (infected teeth can cause various symptoms)
2. Get iron levels checked/treated
3. Consider counseling/therapy for stress management
4. Have an eye exam for the floaters/flashes
5. Continue monitoring symptoms with your GP

While brain tumors are scary, your symptoms are more consistent with stress/anxiety, especially given the timing and circumstances. However, if symptoms worsen or new ones develop, always follow up with your healthcare provider.

225.question: Hello all, I had a question about my medication and fasting, if that's alright. I take Keppra twice a day (500mg each), once in the morning and once at night. With Ramadan approaching I was wondering how much time there needs to be in between taking one pill at night and one in the morning, thanks.Let me know if I need to add anything else.
225.answer:
The typical recommendation for Keppra (levetiracetam) is to take doses approximately 12 hours apart. However, since this involves anti-seizure medication, it's very important to:

1. Consult your neurologist or prescribing doctor before making any changes to your medication schedule during Ramadan

2. Discuss with them specifically about safe timing between doses during fasting hours

Since anti-seizure medications are crucial for seizure control, your doctor might need to adjust your dosing schedule or provide specific guidance for the fasting period.

For accurate medical guidance, please provide your doctor with:
- Your usual medication timing
- Your planned fasting schedule
- Any history of seizures
- Other medications you take

Keep in mind that some scholars provide exemptions from fasting for people with medical conditions that require strict medication schedules.

226.question: Recently I got a hickie, and tons of people started telling me to be careful because I could die, and stuff. Is it that dangerous? Male 17, epilepsy, anxiety, question: are hickies dangerous?
226.answer:
Hickies (also known as love bites or kiss marks) are generally not dangerous for most people. They are simply broken blood vessels under the skin caused by suction, similar to a bruise. However, there are some rare cases where excessive force during the creation of a hickey could potentially cause problems:

1. Very rare complications that have been reported:
- Blood clots (extremely rare)
- Minor nerve damage (temporary)
- Stroke (extremely rare and usually requires other underlying conditions)

2. Basic safety guidelines:
- Avoid extremely forceful suction
- Don't allow hickies near major arteries (especially on the neck)
- If you experience unusual pain or symptoms, seek medical attention

Given your medical history (epilepsy and anxiety), it's always best to:
1. Be moderate with any physical activity
2. Consult your doctor if you have specific concerns
3. Be aware of your body's reactions

While the risks are generally very low, being mindful and avoiding excessive force is recommended. The stories about deaths from hickies are extremely rare cases and often involved other contributing factors.

227.question: 30 AFAB, 158cm/61kg, hispanic, Symptoms: lightheadedness, fatigue, darker urine, light periods. flu-ish [see below] since a month ago.Diagnoses: Epilepsy, ADHD, Endometriosis, 5cm ovarian cyst, migrainesMedications: Lamotrigine 225mg, Ibuprofen for endometriosis pain, very occasional Concerta, haven't used it for a few months, melatonin over the summer (stopped it about two months ago)Others: Drink 1-2 drinks monthly, Slowly stopping smoking down from 6 to 1-2 per day and 1 light snus, last two days have started taking Vitamin D and I have been using a therapy lamp for 20 min every morning for the last two weeks. Good, balanced diet and drink a lot of water. No drugs.Concerns: bad family history of cancer - quality of life affected.In Norway. What should I look out for to justify going to the doc? I would just live at the doctor's if I went every time something happens, especially since I have had several issues since I was a kid, but I also want to be mindful to not ignore things that might be important. I also tend to write off things as just depression/hormones, and once it was an iron deficiency, for instance. Thank you in advance!!   No idea what is related, so I will list things that have changed just in case, in order of concern. EELING FAINT/FATIGUE: I can't exercise much because I feel super lightheaded and I can't do some exercises now because I feel I am going to faint and I have had to cut down my training sessions. Thought I wasn't eating enough, but upped protein intake and started tracking calories and I am at maintenance level.  DEMOTIVATION: I want to be lying on the couch a lot even though it hasn't been typical of me. I am very demotivated, like nothing excites me and I can get a bit weepy (but I have had recurrent trouble with depression in the past so it might be that not being able to do much is making me lightly depressed...). I just moved to a nordic country, so thinking it might be related to the change into the autumn season, I am using a therapy lamp and started taking vitamin D. The lamp worked the first week. URINE: Every time I pee, it used to be clear because I drink so much water and now it is always very yellow no matter how much water I drink. LIGHT PERIOD: My period has become super light since last September, but the last 2-3 times I hardly have had it. I have taken a pregnancy test every 4 weeks just in case. All negative. I used to have 1 very, very heavy day changing tampon at least once an hour and some spotting after. A few years ago it was 3-4 of these very heavy days. OVARIAN PAIN: I have a 5cm cyst (found 10 years ago, grown from 2.5cm) that feels fuller and tender. It has been hurting me so much more than usual, cramping several times this last month and it hurts when I stretch or when I do certain exercises. I only mention this in case you know whether exercise or stretching can cause it to burst or twist the ovary to avoid it or in the off chance that it might be cancer related. I feel my hunger increased, but it might be unrelated, more nausea than usual. I have also been feeling like I am catching a flu constantly and I have already had what seems like a cold twice this month.
227.answer:
Based on your symptoms, you should consider seeing a doctor for the following reasons:

1. Changes in menstrual pattern combined with ovarian cyst symptoms:
- The significant reduction in menstrual flow
- Increased pain from the ovarian cyst
- Risk of cyst complications (torsion or rupture)

2. Persistent fatigue and lightheadedness:
These could indicate:
- Anemia (given your history of iron deficiency)
- Thyroid issues
- Vitamin deficiencies
- Medication side effects

3. Changes in urine color despite adequate hydration could indicate:
- Liver function issues
- Dehydration
- Medication side effects

Red flags that warrant immediate medical attention:
- Severe sudden abdominal pain (could indicate cyst complications)
- Extreme dizziness/fainting
- Fever with severe pain

Recommended actions:
1. Schedule a check-up to:
- Monitor the cyst size
- Get blood work done (CBC, thyroid, vitamin levels)
- Review current medications

2. Keep a symptom diary to share with your doctor

Your symptoms seem significant enough to justify a medical visit, especially given your family history of cancer and multiple chronic conditions.

228.question: I’m (40F) 5ft 8, 164lbs, caucasian. Medications: Lamotrigine and Sertraline Health conditions: ADHD, Tourette’s, epilepsy and severe degenerative disc disease. I don’t have a current issue but every time I’ve had surgery I wake up completely full of beans, even when I’ve just woken up in recovery. I will stay hyper for hours afterwards and not feel surgical pain for the same amount of time. It can be quite funny, I talk at 100mph and can’t stop giggling. I don’t feel sick at all and always want water and food immediately. Drs/nurses etc have commented it’s like I didn’t even have surgery, but I’ve never asked if there’s a reason why. I’m not sure if it’s related but codeine does absolutely nothing for me and I always need extra anaesthetic at the dentist. I’ve never been told I’m difficult to put under GA. Thank you in advance, I’ve been wondering for years.
228.answer:
This is an interesting reaction pattern that could be related to several factors:

1. Paradoxical reaction to anesthesia:
- Some people can have atypical responses to certain anesthetic medications
- This might explain your heightened energy and mood post-surgery

2. Fast metabolism of pain medications:
- Your mention of codeine ineffectiveness and needing extra dental anesthetic suggests you might be a rapid metabolizer
- This could be due to genetic variations in your CYP2D6 enzyme system

3. Potential interaction with your regular medications:
- Lamotrigine and Sertraline might influence how your body processes anesthesia
- ADHD can also affect how some medications work in your system

4. Endorphin response:
- Surgery is stressful for the body, which can trigger a strong endorphin release
- This natural "high" might be more pronounced in your case

To get a definitive answer, you might want to:
1. Discuss this with an anesthesiologist
2. Consider genetic testing for medication metabolism
3. Keep a record of these reactions for future procedures

This isn't medical advice - please consult your healthcare providers for personalized guidance.

229.question: 20 year old old Female. I’m taking 500mg of Keppra every morning for my epilepsy and I’ve been on it for about two years. I’ve just recently stopped taking amitriptyline 25mg about a week now. I’ve been going through the withdrawals but it’s been easing and the symptoms weren’t too bad besides the chills and shakes. I also take Ventolin inhalers for my asthma as well as paracetamols for migraines here and there. Anyway, I’ve had this sort of pain months ago. The stomach pain was unbearable and lasted a week or so until it soothed. It completely went away after a month or so. I think the annoying part was I constantly felt like I needed the bathroom. After the first day I didn’t actually need to use the bathroom but it just constantly felt like I did. It was very uncomfortable. I think eating made it worse but I can’t be too sure. I stopped drinking sodas or spicy foods and drank decaffeinated green tea with honey everyday. It went away and now suddenly it’s back. I’m also late with my period by 23 days but I usually have irregular periods. My stomach gurgles a lot too. If my stomach pain isn’t so bad it’s me needing to use the bathroom or my stomach making noises. My distress triggers anxiety attacks and that also doesn’t help.
229.answer:
Based on your symptoms, there are several possible causes to consider:

1. IBS (Irritable Bowel Syndrome):
- Can be triggered by stress/anxiety
- Causes stomach pain, gurgling, and frequent bathroom urges
- Often affected by diet

2. Medication-related issues:
- Keppra can cause gastrointestinal symptoms
- Amitriptyline withdrawal might affect gut motility
- The combination/changes in medications could be contributing

3. Menstrual-related:
- Delayed period could be causing abdominal discomfort
- Hormonal fluctuations can affect digestive system

4. Other possibilities:
- Food intolerances
- Gastritis
- Anxiety-induced gastrointestinal symptoms

Recommendations:
1. Consult your healthcare provider, especially given:
- Recent medication changes
- Recurring symptoms
- Delayed period

2. Consider:
- Keeping a food diary
- Stress management techniques
- Continuing with the dietary changes that helped before

3. Monitor:
- Timing of symptoms
- Any additional symptoms
- What makes it better/worse

This needs professional evaluation to determine the exact cause and appropriate treatment.

230.question: Gender: Female, Age: 9, Height: Idk tbh, Location: Head, How long ago: 1 week.So my co-workers daughter was just diagnosed with grey matter heterotopia. She was crying her eyes out today, and I felt really bad. She brings her daughter to work quite often and we love her here. She is a wonderful kid, and we were all really sad with the news. I was hoping to shed a little bit of light, maybe some information on what their options are. They have to wait until October for their doctor to talk to them about the subject while her daughter still has seizures and her parents just suffer. I wanted to brighten up her day, and even if the news are bad or there aren’t many options... at least I wanna give her some clarity. Any and all responses are welcomed.Thank you!
230.answer:
Grey matter heterotopia is a rare neurological condition where grey matter (brain tissue) is located in the wrong place due to problems during brain development. Here's some important information:

Key points:
1. It's a congenital condition (present from birth)
2. Severity and symptoms can vary greatly between individuals
3. The most common symptom is seizures, which can often be managed with medication

Treatment options typically include:
1. Anti-epileptic medications to control seizures
2. Regular monitoring by neurologists
3. In some cases, surgery might be an option if the heterotopia is causing severe symptoms
4. Physical, occupational, or speech therapy if needed

Positive aspects:
1. Many children with this condition can live normal lives with proper medical management
2. Research and treatment options continue to improve
3. Support groups and resources are available for families

Ways you can help:
1. Offer emotional support
2. Share reliable information resources
3. Help maintain normalcy at work
4. Consider connecting them with support groups

Recommended resources:
- The Child Neurology Foundation
- The Epilepsy Foundation
- Local neurological support groups

While waiting for the appointment, they can:
1. Keep a detailed seizure diary
2. Document any questions for the doctor
3. Connect with other families through support groups
4. Focus on maintaining regular routines

It's important to remember that each case is unique, and the doctor will provide the most appropriate guidance for their specific situation.

231.question: 25F, 200lb, 5’4, asthma, current medications wellbutrin SR, vyvanse, lexapro, montelukast, spironolactone. i do not drink any alcohol, use cannabis 5-7x a weekOccasionally, I will have an intense sensation of deja vu, followed by a sensation that I can only describe as disoriented. It’s almost like a combination of intense nausea, dizziness, and confusion, which will be very intense for a few seconds before dissipating. After the initial peak, I will feel “weird” for anywhere between 10 mins to a half hour afterwards, sometimes I will be nauseous for awhile, sometimes I will need to lay down, sometimes I feel too overwhelmed to socialize, etc. (I do sometimes experience deja vu WITHOUT the weird sensations too, just the general feeling of unease that comes with a cognitively dissonant experience like deja vu.)This used to happen a lot more as a kid, and stopped for awhile, but recently it’s happened once or twice and made me wonder why it happens. When I was younger I think I used to be able to “control” whether it progressed if I caught the sensation early enough? For example, if I started having that “I’ve been here before” feeling, if I leaned into it and tried to figure out if it was a dream, what came next, etc, the strange feelings would come on; occasionally if I tried to move on from the topic it would just stop at the deja vu and leave me just a little bit weirded out by the experience.I do tend to remember my dreams very vividly, and I have read online that people who do tend to be more susceptible to deja vu. Occasionally I can even tell when I have the sensation and am in fact experiencing the set-up to a dream (i.e opening a closet and then waiting for the “next scene” so to speak from the dream). I am just curious if this is normal, if these weird feelings are just part of deja vu or if it’s something else?
231.answer:
The symptoms you're describing - intense déjà vu followed by disorientation, nausea, dizziness, and confusion - could be consistent with temporal lobe seizures or focal seizures. These types of seizures don't necessarily involve convulsions and can present with the exact symptoms you've described.

The ability to "control" or anticipate the progression of symptoms, the vivid dream recall, and the sensation of knowing what comes next are also commonly reported features of temporal lobe seizures.

This is something you should discuss with a neurologist, especially since:
1. It started in childhood
2. Has a clear pattern
3. Includes physical symptoms beyond just déjà vu
4. Affects your ability to function normally for a period afterward

While déjà vu alone can be normal, the combination of symptoms you're describing warrants professional evaluation. A neurologist can perform tests like an EEG to determine if these episodes are seizure-related and recommend appropriate treatment if necessary.

It's also worth noting that some of your medications (particularly Wellbutrin and Vyvanse) can lower the seizure threshold in some people, which might be relevant to discuss with your healthcare provider.

232.question: ’m a 60yr old fit male with Gerd due to a Hiatal hernia. Have been on PPIs for 22 years. Have had a history of passing out on occasion after weight lifting/working out. Doctors did cardio tests /tilt table with no results for explanation. One neurologist said I had epilepsy another one said absolutely not. No one seemed to take into account the PPI and Gerd condition and that this only happened after work outs. Could the weight lifting be affecting the Vagus nerve and causing the light headedness and the seizure like passing out episodes?
232.answer:
Yes, it's possible that your symptoms could be related to vagal nerve stimulation triggered by the combination of your hiatal hernia, GERD, and weightlifting. Here's why:

1. Vagal nerve involvement:
- Weightlifting can increase intra-abdominal pressure
- This pressure can affect your hiatal hernia and trigger vagal nerve stimulation
- The vagus nerve regulates heart rate and blood pressure

2. Vasovagal syncope:
- Can cause fainting due to sudden drop in heart rate and blood pressure
- Often triggered by physical strain
- Can sometimes appear similar to seizures (convulsive syncope)

3. PPI long-term use:
- May affect mineral absorption (especially magnesium)
- Could contribute to cardiac rhythm issues
- May influence blood pressure regulation

Suggestions:
1. Consult a gastroenterologist familiar with GERD/hernia exercise complications
2. Consider keeping a detailed workout/symptom diary
3. Modify exercise technique to reduce abdominal pressure
4. Get evaluated for magnesium levels if on long-term PPIs

Always seek professional medical advice for proper diagnosis and treatment.

233.question: 29F, height 165cm, weight 74kg, caucasian. I do not smoke or have regular dairy. Weekly alcohol consumption would be 2-7 standard drinks per week at most.  also regularly have lean meat and 3 veg for lunch and dinner and a fruit smoothie for breakfast. Current diagnoses: epilepsy, mild chronic pancreatitis Regular medications are: AM: 500mg Kepra, vitamins D+magnesium PM: 500mg Kepra, vitamin D+magnesium I am awaiting follow-up with a gastroenterologist about why my pancreas could be nibbling on itself (lypase has been found to be between 70-100 on multiple occasions). I have a history of treating my anxiety with alcohol and fast food but over the last 8 years or so (since my early 20's) I've gone to therapy and gotten it really well under control. I never had these symptoms before when I had unhealthy habits but over the last year my pancreas has not been having a good time. Every month or 2 I get these very specific pains that I now know is mild chronic pancreatitis. It's never brought on by a change in routine, it's always random.
233.answer:
Based on the information provided, here's an analysis of your situation:

Key Points:
1. You have well-controlled epilepsy on Keppra
2. You maintain a generally healthy lifestyle now
3. Elevated lipase levels (70-100)
4. Recurring pancreatic pain every 1-2 months
5. Past history of alcohol use and poor diet, but improved for 8 years

Possible considerations for the pancreatitis:

1. Autoimmune factors: Sometimes pancreatitis can develop from autoimmune conditions
2. Genetic factors: Some people have genetic predispositions to pancreatitis
3. Structural issues: Such as pancreatic divisum or other anatomical variations
4. Previous damage: Although your lifestyle has improved, there might be some residual effects from past habits
5. Medication effects: Some medications can affect pancreatic function

While waiting for your gastroenterologist, you might want to:

1. Keep a detailed food and symptom diary
2. Avoid known pancreatic irritants (alcohol, fatty foods)
3. Stay well hydrated
4. Consider asking about pancreatic enzyme supplements
5. Discuss with your doctor whether additional imaging (such as MRCP) might be helpful

This is a complex situation that requires professional medical evaluation. The random nature of the attacks suggests there might be underlying factors beyond dietary triggers.
